PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT LEGISLATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation for an amendment announced.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report entitled Hong Kong: The transfer to sovereignty , together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In four weeks time, on 1 July 1997, at the end of one and a half decade's negotiation, Hong Kong will be transferred from British to Chinese sovereignty. For Hong Kong it brings to the end 150 years of British rule. Hong Kong is in a unique position. It is to be decolonised by having its sovereignty handed not to itself but to the power from which it was first severed. The transition involves a nation and a fellow former colony of the United Kingdom, both of great importance to us.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia‐China relationship is expanding and multifaceted, highlighted by last week's visit of the Chinese Vice Premier, Mr Zhu Rongji. It is a relationship in which there is enormous scope for growth but a need for understanding of respective national interests and attitudes. The Australia‐Hong Kong relationship is equally long standing and productive, but with our common language base it has been somewhat closer. Australia's relationship with Hong Kong has enhanced its entry into China. It is to be hoped that the change of sovereignty will improve and not lessen that.

It was because of the importance of both Hong Kong and China to Australia that the committee decided to embark on this inquiry. It seemed important to set out for the members of the Australian Parliament the nature of the agreement that had been reached between Britain and China, not only because some doubts and uncertainties had been raised about the implementation of the joint declaration and the basic law but also because an understanding of the detail would be helpful in shaping the best policy towards the new Hong Kong.

The inquiry was advertised on 7 September 1996. It received 36 submissions and a large number of exhibits. It took evidence at public hearings in Australia and most valuably visited Hong Kong in late January where the committee was able to hold discussions with a very wide range of people right across the political spectrum, including Governor Chris Patten, and from both government and non‐government organisations. Visits were made to the border and to inspect the new infrastructure projects, the airport at Chek Lap Kok and the bridges and linking road and rail systems that have been built to connect them to Hong Kong, and the Lantau link. These projects are impressive in their scale, in the engineering skill that makes them possible and in the confidence in the future they assert. The committee is most grateful to the Australian government officials who worked on the organisation of the visit to Hong Kong and most appreciative of the hospitality and time given by all those who briefed us.

I was able to return to Hong Kong in April this year and then meet the chief executive designate, Mr Tung Chee Hwa. He gave very clear assurances about his intentions to preserve Hong Kong's way of life and to govern Hong Kong with the interests of the people of Hong Kong very much in mind.

The period of transition, 1984 to 1997, has not always been smooth or optimistic. In 1989 the dramatic events in Tiananmen Square shook Hong Kong's confidence to its core and in the last five years arguments over changes to the legal and political systems still create grave doubts and even the events over the last weekend highlighted that.

The views put to the committee ranged from cautious optimism to apprehension and these are reflected in the report. Optimism about the future of Hong Kong rests, we were told, on the rational and pragmatic nature of the Chinese government and its recognition of the value of Hong Kong to China. It also rests on the agreement of the Chinese to a novel treaty that guarantees one country, two systems and Hong Kong people governing Hong Kong. This week Mr Zhu Rongji emphatically reiterated these promises when he said:
China would unswervingly implement the principle of one country, two systems . . . we have the ability and the confidence to ensure long‐term stability and prosperity of Hong Kong.

Optimism is encouraged by the robust state of the territory's economy, the autonomous representation of Hong Kong on a number of international economic bodies, such as the WTO and APEC, its maintenance of a separate currency and its own stock exchange, and its status as a separate customs territory. There is a depth of skill in the financial and legal institutions which should provide the basis for continuity. Hong Kong has a sophisticated common law system, an independent judiciary, a vigorous Chinese and English language media and an impartial and apparently honest public service and police force.

Many apprehensions raised by people in Hong Kong and in Australia are detailed in the report. These relate to the vulnerability of pivotal legal and political institutions. Whereas the legal institutions are well established, the political institutions, especially of the democratic kind, are new and fragile. Of concern are the creation of a second legislature, the Provisional Legislative Council, without constitutional basis; the intention to repeal laws which protected basic freedoms of speech and assembly; the broad and vague definitions of subversion in article 23 of the Basic Law; the uncertainty about the timing and nature of electoral laws to be set in place by the Provisional Legislature; and the capacity of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress to intervene in Hong Kong's government under the auspices of article 158 of the Basic Law.

These are classic ways to undermine democratic accountability and as such encourage corruption not only of the political process but ultimately of the economy as well. Hong Kong's prosperity and stability are at issue and of interest to the region and the world. While cautiously optimistic, the committee has recommended an annual report for the next five years.

I would like to compliment Mr Peter Nugent, the chair of the subcommittee, and in particular Margaret Swieringa, Jon Merrill and other staff of the committee for the excellent work they did in the preparation of this report. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the tabling of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the transfer of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty—an event which will be one of the defining moments at the end of the twentieth century. No‐one should underestimate the practical and symbolic significance of the transfer of power on 1 July. Fundamentally it is about China's re‐emergence onto the world stage as an absolute front‐rank player. Hong Kong has been one of the most powerful symbols of the unequal treaties between China and the European colonial powers. But in less than a month the Union Jack—for Chinese nationalists the symbol of a hated colonial past—will quietly flutter down. At the same time, China will incorporate what is perhaps the greatest symbol of Chinese success and prosperity, doing so at a time when its own economic progress continues to move ahead in leaps and bounds.

SPEECH.PARA: That economic performance is undeniably impressive. China's economy has been growing at around 10 per cent a year for the past 15 years. From July, with Hong Kong, China will be the sixth largest trading nation in the world. Soon after the year 2000, China's trade with Japan will overtake the volume of trade between Japan and the United States. With the reforms under way, China is likely to sustain this growth well into the next century, with commentators agreeing that by 2020 China will have the biggest economy in the world: according to one World Bank study, some 25 per cent larger than second placed United States.

The implications for Australia in these broad trends are profound. Almost all of the things we take for granted in our current external environment will no longer hold. Our region and indeed the world will be changed, and the biggest geopolitical force in that transformation will be the rise of China. We do not know precisely how these changes will unfold but the fate of Hong Kong will certainly be a critical element in determining how China interacts both with our region and with the wider world, and how we and our friends and neighbours engage with China.

This reality, together with our substantial commercial and consular interests in Hong Kong, illustrates Australia's profoundly important stake in a smooth and successful transfer to Chinese sovereignty. Central to this outcome lies the maintenance of a high degree of autonomy and the freedom guaranteed to Hong Kong under the Joint Declaration and the Basic Law, continuation of the rule of law, the maintenance of democratic institutions and processes, an independent judiciary, a free media and the continuation of Hong Kong's open economic system.

The whole world will be studying very closely the process of transition in the months and years after 1 July. The stakes for China, Hong Kong and the Asia‐Pacific region are high indeed. The challenge for the international community, and for Australia in particular, is to draw all we can to support a smooth and successful transition. Our response to developments will need to be balanced and constructive, based on mature consideration of the underlying political dynamics both in Hong Kong and in China itself.

In this regard, the committee's report provides some very useful benchmarks with which to evaluate the success of the one country, two systems formula. As the report states, the transfer of Hong Kong represents a profound challenge to Australian diplomacy. It is likely to test Australia's commitment to support and promote two of our absolute core values: democratic processes and human rights. In the debate on this subject on 14 October I said there should be no weakening of Australia's support for democratic processes and human rights in Hong Kong. I remain absolutely convinced of that. Australia should be prepared to use all appropriate means, both public and private, and leave China and the world in no doubt about our strong support for these fundamental principles.

Since last October, however, we have seen the Howard government take a very different path with its decision to relegate the issue of human rights to a private, behind‐closed‐doors dialogue with China. Regrettably, the government has already chosen this course on human rights. Foreign Minister Downer once spoke of consistency and principle in respect of these issues, but the government will now hear no evil, see no evil and speak no evil. For this compliance we are told that the Howard government is in China's good books—for the moment at least. But the Australian message to the people of Hong Kong and to campaigners for democratic institutions, such as Martin Lee, could hardly be worse. They now know that they cannot rely on Australia to speak up. The lesson for China is also very clear: wave a stick—in this case, wave a big stick—and offer the carrot, and the Howard government will do as it is told.

It may be thought that silence on human rights issues will bring Australia diplomatic and economic benefit. That is certainly the government's view. But no other country has ever advanced its long‐term national interest through the expedient abandonment of principle and democratic values. The fundamental challenge for Australia in the next century is to maintain our core values and our commitment to protect and promote human rights in a profoundly different international environment. Hong Kong should provide a clear demonstration of our preparedness to so this. The Howard government will profoundly fail our national interest if it fails this test.

I join with the Chairman of the joint standing committee, Mr Sinclair, in thanking the members of the Human Rights Subcommittee, particularly the Chairman of the committee, Mr Peter Nugent, for the work they have done in preparing this report. I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As has already been mentioned, less than a month from today the sovereignty of Hong Kong will be transferred from the United Kingdom to China. For Britain it marks the end of the colonial era. It is a unique transfer of sovereignty from one power to another, but not to independence or to self‐government as we have become so used to these days. For China, the return of Hong Kong is the reclamation of a significant part of its territory. For the people of Hong Kong the change and the nature of the central power probably could not be greater.

SPEECH.PARA: China and Hong Kong have a natural connection in geography, culture, heritage and language. The return of Hong Kong to China will create and encourage a very important synergy. But it also raises some interesting questions and some concerns. Those concerns range from the democratic process, the repeal of some of the human rights ordinances, media self‐censorship—or, as it was put to us by a number of people in Hong Kong, commercial decisions—control of the judicial process, the status of refugees, the regional human rights dimension and whether the Hong Kong people can take their destiny and independence into their own hands.

Australia's interests in Hong Kong are substantial. We have pragmatic concerns for investments in trade, political concerns for regional stability, and humanitarian concerns for the continued wellbeing of a neighbouring people and for the preservation of democratic and liberal values—something which Australians consider to be of intrinsic worth. There are 30,000 Australians in Hong Kong. In 1995 Hong Kong was our 10th largest trading partner. With its merger with China it will become even more important.

This inquiry was not about whether the transfer of sovereignty should take place. The inquiry was very much directed at the process of transition and informing the members of this parliament about a highly significant event in our region, with possible implications for our vital interests.

BREAK.PARA: I echo the comments of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) about the number of submissions, our public hearings, our visit and the range of people we saw in Hong Kong. We are appreciative of the efforts all those involved made in that connection. We saw a broad range of people in Hong Kong, and that was very important. As chair of the sub committee, I would like to thank the members of the committee for their assistance. I would particularly like to thank the secretary, Margaret Swieringa, assisted so ably by Jon Merrill and Peter Ratas.

I draw the attention of the House to the conclusion sections of the report and the 26 recommendations. One of the key findings was that we concluded that the reforms Governor Patten had proposed—somewhat belatedly—were in the spirit and the strict letter of the agreement made between Britain and China, although the PRC has made it very clear that they have a different view.

One of the phrases that is used frequently in connection with Hong Kong and the changeover is `the through train', describing what was in place before 1 July and what will be there afterwards. Quite clearly, the political through train was derailed by the installation of the new legislative council and the doing away with the old one, but the administrative, economic and judicial through trains appear to be on track.

It is important to say that, having considered the legal and institutional assurances provided by the Chinese government through the basic law, the robust state of the territory's economy and trade relations and, perhaps most importantly, its increasingly lucrative role as a trade intermediary to China, it is difficult not to approach the central question of Hong Kong's economic future from a confident perspective. However, in the light of the civil, legal and political issues that have occupied much of this report, it is equally difficult not to be cautious about the economic implications of Chinese political control over Hong Kong.

Ultimately, it is that political control which is going to be the key thing. It is essential to recognise that China is the new sovereign power and that Hong Kong will be affected—and its fate governed—by the changing political and economic landscape of China. Our interests in Hong Kong will, therefore, be influenced by developments in China and our relationship with China.

It seems to me that we have got a lot to do with China in the future. We are very concerned about how the Chinese authorities and the new Hong Kong authorities will react after 1 January. We have been assured at the highest level in China that things will be governed according to the promises that were made, and it is very much hoped that those promises are stuck to. On behalf of the committee, I can say that it is very much hoped that Hong Kong will continue to prosper in the future, for the benefit of the people of Hong Kong, of China, of the region and, in particular, of this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Hong Kong will be seen by many as the challenge of the future. In an age when we are familiar with colonies obtaining their independence from a colonial master, Hong Kong—I think uniquely—has, in effect, exchanged one colonial master for another. Many would argue that, as the lease entered into by Britain some 99 years ago has expired, China is merely reasserting its sovereignty—a sovereignty that has, in one way or another, been under challenge since the first unequal treaty of 1842. Some are disappointed that Hong Kong was not permitted to become a separate independent state in the international community, but that is speculation about what might have been rather than the reality of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The report tabled shows that Hong Kong is important to Australia for trade and investment and because of the many people from Hong Kong who have made Australia their home. As a parliament and as a nation, we have had a long and historic link with Hong Kong. We must always have genuine concerns about the human rights of its citizens but, I must say, our credibility when pontificating on human rights has been somewhat diminished by some of the decisions taken by Australia over recent months. I do not think we sent any reassuring messages of support for human rights or gave much comfort to those concerned with human rights in Hong Kong by our recent vote at the Human Rights Committee, regardless of what the reasons were.

Hong Kong will be in the situation of being a country within a country. There will be strict border controls, passage of people will be controlled and it will, in many respects, be more difficult after the transfer of sovereignty for someone living in Shanghai or Beijing to visit Hong Kong than it is today. Will human rights be protected? I suspect that human rights may be different in interpretation. It seems to me inevitable that there will be some readjustment regarding the rights of people. For example, the press at the moment is engaging in a form of self‐censorship, and this will continue. Chinese officials will argue that they have not imposed restrictions, but a newspaper proprietor or editor will know, without being told, about certain things they can publish and other things they cannot publish.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not confined to China.

—No. The same will probably occur with dissent. During our visit to Hong Kong, many suggested the Singapore model as an appropriate model for Hong Kong. Everyone knows what a vibrant, enthusiastic and dynamic opposition there is in Singapore! Yet commercial activity flourishes in Singapore, and that is the key to Hong Kong. The economic activity in Hong Kong is staggering. The economy is one that is the envy of much of the world. It is in everyone's interests for this to continue. I suspect that Beijing will not impose too heavy a hand on Hong Kong, but there will be a hand imposed. It will indeed be one nation, two systems. The people of Hong Kong will have more freedom than is currently enjoyed by citizens in other parts of China, but whether they have total freedom, as we understand it, will again be a matter of interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: Life for most Hong Kong citizens will go on much as it does today. The British have been making much of the denial of human rights in Hong Kong—and especially of the abolition of the elected legislative assembly. As part of China, Hong Kong will have more freedom than its people have had for many years under British rule. China has rightly pointed out that the system under the basic law is more democratic than the British offered. The British were very late in giving the Hong Kong Chinese any say in the running of the colony, were quick to stamp out any form of dissent and did not show too much concern about imprisoning critical editors when it suited them. Had Britain been a more benevolent overlord and involved the Chinese more, then the criticism that Britain makes today—or at least that it made under the Tories—would be much more valid. As it is, they appear to many of us to be somewhat hypocritical.

I am sure everyone in parliament wishes Hong Kong every success as it embarks on the uncharted course of having a different system within an overall sovereign state. I would like to compliment the chairman of the committee, Peter Nugent, and the staff—Margaret Swieringa, Jon Merrill and Peter Ratas—for the work they did. I would like to particularly compliment Margaret Swieringa for the dedication she has shown to the compiling of this report. We will watch Hong Kong's future with great interest. Perhaps the chicken will not have to be killed to warn the monkey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, I present the committee's report entitled Aspects of youth suicide .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the report I have just tabled deals with one of the most tragic events experienced by our young people in Australia today. The number of young Australians, especially young men, who commit suicide has risen rapidly over the past 20 years to the extent where it is now one of the highest rates in the industrialised world.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, in acknowledging the severity of this trend and in order to express their concern and the concern of the federal parliament, undertook to conduct a seminar at Parliament House to promote the necessity for direct action at the national level.

A measure of the commitment of the federal parliament to the conduct of this seminar and the committee's report was attested to by the presence of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who opened the seminar and who has strongly supported a national response to the tragedy of youth suicide. The committee was also fortunate to have the expertise and cooperation of four eminent practitioners in the field who provided presentations to seminar participants on the demographics of youth suicide, social and psychiatric factors involved and the provision of support services.

I would like to place on the public record my appreciation, and that of the committee, to Dr James Harrison, the Director of the National Injury Surveillance Unit at the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, Associate Professor Pierre Baume, who is the Director of the Australian Institute for Suicide Research and Prevention, Professor Robert Kosky, the Director of the Department of Psychiatry at the Adelaide Women's and Children's Hospital, and last but by no means least, Dr Meg Smith, the Chairman of the Youth Suicide Prevention Advisory Group for assisting in the conduct of the seminar.

In an attempt to involve a cross‐section of organisations and individuals working directly with youth suicide prevention, invitations were also extended to participants representing peak health and community groups and local organisations and youth workers, academics and professionals who all had an opportunity to make a personal contribution to the day's proceedings. As well as committee members, 14 other members and senators attended the seminar. It is important to recognise that no-one has a monopoly on good ideas and commonsense, and it was wonderful not only to have a contribution from the parliament but also to have input from the community, particularly those who have been fighting this problem at the coalface.

Committee members considered that the information provided at the seminar should be disseminated as widely as possible and, for this reason, resolved to produce a summary report which would further focus discussion. The report also contains a series of recommendations designed to improve the current delivery of services and provide a national structure to refine prevention programs based on more reliable evidence based research.

The major recommendation of the committee is that a national advisory council on youth suicide prevention be established to provide strategic advice to the Minister for Health and Family Services on youth suicide prevention and related matters. While a Youth Suicide Prevention Advisory Group currently exists, the committee does not consider that this organisation has sufficient direct input into policy making at a high enough level to achieve the results required. For this reason, the committee has recommended that the new advisory council on youth suicide prevention be administratively resourced by the Department of Health and Family Services, reporting directly to the minister, and that it be chaired by an expert person with a high profile in the field and have its membership determined personally by the minister.

In addition, the proposed council should produce a comprehensive work plan within six months of its establishment and revise and update this plan annually. The council should also be responsible for creating appropriate arrangements for consultation and cooperation among governments and the community at all levels.

BREAK.PARA: The recommendation for the establishment of the council is the most important step in increasing the government's responsibility and effectiveness and for this reason is listed as priority No. 1. It underpins the other recommendations and applies an overarching structure to engineer and further develop appropriate responses to the urgent need for direct action.

Consequent upon this is the recommendation to establish a research advisory committee to assist and advise the National Health and Medical Research Council on the management of research projects and grants and ensure consistency with national research priorities. This recommendation gives emphasis to the current fragmented and inconsistent approach to national data collection and provides a mechanism to improve research administration and funding.

Finally, as a third priority, the committee has made specific reference to several strategies to increase public awareness, to assist the medical system to identify young people at risk of suicide and to improve data collection. These would all be achieved by the establishment of the bodies referred to earlier.

Mr Speaker, I hope that all members of this House will read the committee's report and urge the government to act on its recommendations. This tragedy, which is increasing daily, will not diminish by itself, and we do not have the luxury of waiting for someone else to act for us. This is truly a national responsibility and must be accorded the highest national priority. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), am pleased to be able to speak briefly on the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs entitled Aspects of youth suicide . The seminar organised in February this year provided not only all of us in this House but also those intimately involved in this tragic area—the peak health and community groups, the local organisations, youth and street workers and professionals and academics—with an invaluable opportunity to gain some up‐to‐date evidence on this very pressing issue—and what an issue it is. I am sure all members in this place can tell this House of first‐hand stories of the tragedy that is youth suicide.

SPEECH.PARA: For me, over the last couple of weeks I have been touched by, first of all, a mother asking for my assistance in bringing her 16-year-old daughter home from Western Australia, who had just hung herself after having an argument with her 17-year-old boyfriend. One of my staffers' male friends, a 24-year-old, could not see a way out of his many problems so he drove deep into the bush, into part of the electorate close to my office, and used the old tried and true method of attaching a rubber hose to the exhaust pipe to end his life.

Australia as a nation has an absolutely appalling record when it comes to the tragic death of our youngsters, those between the ages of 15 and 24. Excluding several Baltic countries, Australia, New Zealand and Norway have the highest death rates per hundred thousand young people when it comes to suicide—Australian males at 25 per 100,000 and females at just over five per 100,000. They are bland statistics to some; to others it means that, for 1995, the most recent year for which data has been collected, of the total deaths of young males between the ages of 15 and 24, 25 per cent can be attributed to suicide and for females, 17 per cent. In evidence to the seminar, Dr James Harrison from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare stated:

As I said, the deaths themselves are in some sense the tip of an iceberg. We do not have anywhere near such a good sense of the other parts of the iceberg. We do have some sense of those cases which resulted in hospital admission for apparently self‐destructive or suicide attempting behaviour. Overall, there are about 10 times as many hospital admissions for this sort of problem as there are deaths . . .

If you look at our report, just glance at the females, those who have tried and were unsuccessful, and read the report when it comes to what they are going to do the next time or the next time. The problem facing us is: what can we do about this upward spiralling social problem?

BREAK.PARA: One problem highlighted during the seminar was that youth suicide research needs to be coordinated at a national level. Those of us who can remember when our national road toll reached epidemic proportions will remember that we as a nation reacted with the introduction of national requirements relating to seat belts, alcohol levels in drivers, speed limits and modifications in the way the cars were manufactured. The time has come for such a national strategy to be put in place for our young people to ensure that the loss of hundreds of young Australian lives will soon be properly addressed.

The recommendations that the honourable member for Fisher mentioned must be addressed immediately by all of us in a multipartisan way so that the many hundreds of young people who tragically lose their lives can leave at least some memorial in that the hope they thought was not there is there and we can put in place ways of addressing this absolutely appalling and tragic situation. I recommend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elson, Kay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Every day in this place we speak on a range of issues of national importance, but I do not believe there is a single issue of greater importance to each of us, or to us collectively as a nation, than the welfare of our young people, which is why the report tabled today and the government's increasing focus on youth suicide is such an important step forward in recognising this growing problem and finding ways to deal with it as a community.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1995, there were 350 young male suicides and 84 young female suicides. These represented about a quarter of all young male deaths and 17 per cent of our young female deaths. Since the 1960s, rates of suicide among young men have almost trebled; in women they have doubled. It is sobering to remember that for every suicide there are many attempted suicides. Literally thousands of young Australians are attempting to take their lives every year. This is surely every bit as tragic and as urgent as many of the other problems we have discussed in this House in recent weeks.

BREAK.PARA: The report tabled today does not, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said in the opening of the youth suicide seminar held here in Parliament House, pretend to `have all the magical solutions', but it does outline some priorities to ensure that, firstly, the government has a working plan to tackle this problem and regularly reviews its progress in meeting the objectives of that plan; secondly, research into this problem is properly coordinated; and, thirdly, the government takes immediate action in the following ways: establishing a depression awareness campaign, adopting standard procedures for treating a young person who has attempted suicide, reviewing current funding and redirecting some of that funding to more appropriate programs and ensuring consistency and data collection at all government levels.

I believe the last point is important. The committee, and certainly I personally, found it very difficult to get up-to-date figures in order to fully gauge the extent of this problem. I believe that three essential priorities outlined in this report provide a commonsense approach to the problems in both the long and the short term. All the members of the committee agree that it is important to take both long‐ and short‐term approaches if we are to properly address this issue, which is why I think it is instructive to look at the three major factors influencing young suicidal people, outlined in points 25 to 34 of the report.

Various sociological factors have been identified in countries with high suicide rates, and they include a high divorce rate, high youth unemployment, high female employment, extremely high alcohol consumption, a high number of unwanted pregnancies and low church or religious participation. Some of these factors are obviously beyond the direct control of government, but there are many ways we can play a role in helping alleviate problems such as youth unemployment and family breakdown. The report's conclusion, paragraph 50, states:

Throughout the seminar, the family was raised as a major influence on young people's lives. For many young suicidal people, depression combined with chronic family discord was stated to create overwhelming distress.

Perhaps it is not surprising that, while successive governments have placed less emphasis on the welfare of the family unit, suicide rates have soared over the past 30 years. I am certainly pleased to be part of a government which is committed to restoring the value of the family rather than regarding it as old fashioned or passe.

Our policies are aimed at rewarding parents who take on the crucial role of raising children, recognising the important job they are doing and helping them to build and maintain family ties by relieving financial pressures. That does not mean getting caught up on definitions of families. It means delivering real assistance to ease so many of the pressures that modern day families face. I believe this approach is crucial as part of the long-term solution to youth suicide.

We owe it to our children to ease the pressures on them. There is a mountain of evidence which suggests that the best place this can be achieved is in a nurturing and happy family unit. Of course, that is not the whole answer either and I do not pretend the problem is that simple. As Professor Kolsky told the suicide forum, the mystery of suicide is hidden and buried in the minds of a young person, beyond words in many cases.

I urge the government to consider very carefully the main priorities outlined in this report and to take urgent action on them. They provide an important first step forward in helping unravel the mystery of youth suicide, hopefully to save some of the young lives that are tragically lost in our community each year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to have the opportunity to speak to this report today. In our community we see many tragic ways by which people can die, but it seems to me that suicide, particularly among our younger people, has to be one of the most tragic—the tragic loss of a young life, the loss of the potential, the loss of a loved one, the loss of a young person possibly tormented by mental illness and the devastation left for the loved ones to cope with.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous government, through its Here for Life program, had committed $13 million over four years, from 1995-96 through to 1998-99, in an attempt to seriously begin to tackle this awful social problem. We should note that we are just over halfway through that particular program and it is continuing. Commendably, the current government, in its 1996-97 budget, committed $19 million over three years through its national youth suicide strategy—in total, $32 million.

I commend both this government and the former government for making these commitments; however, I must admit to a slight disappointment, or in fact frustration, that during our committee briefings and meetings it became evident that there was little if any apparent serious connection between those two programs.

During our one-day seminar, we heard many people from the community and from government and non-government sectors explaining and commenting on a large number of programs, projects and pilots at all levels around the country but with little if any apparent coordination overall. The whole of the committee tended to continually note this as we progressed through our inquiry. It is fair to say that some of the people at the seminar knew of the work of some others, but the whole subject seemed to be screaming out for coordination, for a central focus, for guidance.

The question of data collection was one of the most frustrating aspects of this whole inquiry for me. As the member for Forde (Mrs Elson) said just a moment ago, the lack of comprehensive data seemed to frustrate not only us but more so the people who were trying to deliver some of the services on the ground.

Whilst I must agree to a certain extent with the comments of the member for Forde regarding family breakdown, we must also remember that with the lack of that comprehensive data we have no way really of knowing whether these young people are coming from the most loving, together families or from the families with the most discord—whether they are from families who go to church every Sunday or whether they are from families who are unemployed. That is the problem we have as a community. One of the most important things this whole new coordinated approach should take on immediately is a comprehensive collection of that data so that we actually do know what we are talking about.

A statistic that I found most alarming and which I think illustrates how careful targeting is needed is that 60 per cent of successful or completed suicides have a known record of a previous attempt. This begs the question: are we doing enough in the follow-up, the post‐incident counselling, the family counselling? It seems not, although we must note that in the Here for Life program there is a pilot under way looking at that very aspect.

The recommended establishment of a national advisory council on youth suicide prevention, along with a research advisory committee, is essential if we as a community—not as a government, but as a community—are serious about this matter. All the work, research and knowledge already there through the Here for Life initiative, the youth suicide prevention advisory group and all of the people we met at the seminar must be used, built on and added to.

I very much look forward to the ongoing commitment of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) in the work that I know he and his department are going to be required to undertake when, hopefully, this government takes on the recommendations or priorities of this summary report.

As a fairly new member to this place I must say that the work of a committee like this is the real work of a parliament. I would like very much on behalf of my colleagues on the committee to thank Bjarne Nordin from the secretariat and his colleagues Bronwen Jaggers and Kate DaDeppo, who really made our work so much easier and made certain that we had all of the information we required during the deliberations. I, too, join my colleagues in commending this summary report to the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this report of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs I think it is worth reminding ourselves that the health and well-being of young people and the extent to which we protect and nurture the vulnerable and care for their ideals are critical measures of any society. In returning to what the member for Franklin (Mr Quick) said, in relation to youth suicide we are now where we were with road trauma in the early 1970s. What is most important now is for the parliament and the incumbent government to realise that we need a nationally focused coordinated program which brings together all of those strands which contribute to the causes, prevention and treatment of youth suicide.

SPEECH.PARA: Amongst all of the things that might be attributed to it, I think we need to stop and ask ourselves whether our society is failing because, more than anything else, what we have done over the last 20 years is create a culture in which young people feel they have nothing more than themselves in which to believe. The mesh of values which holds this country together unfortunately in recent years has fallen apart. I can think of no issue of greater importance to the parliament than that of trying to protect the health, sense of belonging and meaningful purpose of young Australians. I commend the report most enthusiastically to the parliament and to the government.

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Some members may be aware that I chaired a committee which reported in November 1994 and which looked at the child support scheme. With the passage of time, a couple of things have become clearer to me. Firstly, the individual committee members who served on that committee have been inadequately recognised for the contribution they made—in fact, for the bipartisan way committee members tackled what is a very difficult issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, it never occurred to me that nearly three years would have elapsed and that only the easiest of the recommendations—53 in all—would be tackled by my government and the present government and that the remaining more difficult policy issues would be and continue to be unresponded to. It is with a degree of frustration that I have brought this private member's bill forward, the Child Support Assessment Amendment Bill 1997. I suppose I am a little embarrassed that it picks up only the formula changes recommended by the committee. I emphasise that this is a private member's bill; it has not been endorsed by my party. In fact, if I reflect on the three years, I am a little surprised that the caucus has never really had an opportunity to vote on these measures or any of the other recommendations.

The formula changes recommended in the report are quite modest. They are the very minimum that needed to be changed in the committee's eyes in the absence of decent research. Let me run through them. For the non-custodial parent, it is an increase of 20 per cent in the living allowance. The cap has been reduced from 2½ times average weekly earnings to twice times average weekly earnings, consistent with the necessity no longer to go to the Family Court for a variation of the assessment. The disregarded income of the custodial parent is reduced from average weekly earnings to the pension free area, but with a softening of the withdrawal rate from dollar for dollar to 50c in the dollar.

Last but not least, there is a minimum child support assessment for every person, whether they are employed, unemployed or self‐employed, of $260 per annum. Some may take issue that this is going to cost more to collect than it is worth, but it is a matter of principle that every parent should contribute towards the upbringing of their children. Hence, that is why that provision is there.

I find it ironic that, three years after the report was tabled, we as parliamentarians still cannot agree about some of the principles in the report. That is, the scheme should really be about children and not about how much money can be clawed back to the Department of Social Security. The ever increasing staff numbers in the agency—some might say the explosive staffing increase in the agency—are unsustainable.

We need a child support scheme that is a safety net—that is, that interferes in a minimal way in the lives of people and only when necessary and that the private arrangements people can come to are the best arrangements but that when things break down the agency is needed. Most particularly, we need to change this scheme from one about salary and wage earners to one that encompasses everyone, thereby repairing the income base, ensuring that the professionals and the self‐employed also pay child support and the draconian enforcement measures in the bill are implemented.

I sincerely hope as a member of parliament that I can stand up in this parliament and support a government—any government—that produces legislative changes to the child support scheme. I have waited for three years. I have to confess that I do not think the government will give this bill precedence, but the need for reform is urgent. I seek leave to present an explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Leave granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Religious Freedom of the Baha'is in Iran

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That this House:

(1) strongly condemns the death sentences for apostasy imposed by the Iranian courts on Mr Musa Talibi and Mr Dhabihu'llah Mahrami, two members of the Baha'i Faith, particularly noting the gross violation of freedom of religion these sentences involve in contravention of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Iran is a party;

(2) strongly condemns the imposition of death sentences against two other Baha'is, Mr Kayvan Khalajabadi and Mr Bihnam Mithaqi, held by the Iranian authorities, again for reasons arising from their religious beliefs;
(3) calls for the immediate revocation of all such death sentences and the immediate release of the individuals involved;

(4) deplores the continuing practice in Iran of short and long term detention of Baha'is for their religious beliefs and other grave breaches of human rights against the Baha'is in Iran, including the banning of the sacred institutions of the Baha'i community and the criminalisation of membership of these institutions, denial of education and employment of individual Baha'is, the continuing failure to remedy the confiscation and destruction of holy places and community and personal property of Baha'is, continuing restrictions on freedom of movement and the right of assembly, and discrimination by the judiciary;

(5) calls on the Government of Iran to ensure that no more Baha'is are subjected to sentences of death or imprisoned for their religious beliefs and that all current sentences of this nature against Baha'is are revoked and the individuals involved immediately released;

(6) notes with concern Iran's failure to respond to the recommendations of Mr Abdelfattah Amor, UN Special Rapporteur for Religious Intolerance, regarding the violation of religious freedom in Iran, and urges the Government of Iran to take immediate steps to implement all those recommendations, particularly as they relate to Baha'is and protestant religious minorities;

(7) notes also with concern the continuation generally of violations of human rights in Iran, including the high number of executions in the absence of internationally recognised safeguards, cases of torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, the failure to meet international standards with regard to the administration of justice and the absence of due process of law, violations of the right to peaceful assembly and restrictions on the freedom of expression, thought, opinion and the press and calls on the Government of Iran to ensure full respect for human rights within its borders; and

(8) commends successive Australian governments for Australia's long standing and continuing support of religious freedom of the Baha'is in Iran, particularly in UN forums, and urges that further bilateral and multilateral diplomatic measures be taken in support of religious freedoms of the Baha'is and religious freedom generally.

I am very thankful for the degree of support from all quarters within this parliament and both houses. The essential detail of this motion is to deplore the continued harassment, torture, imprisonment, confiscation of property and other actions against the Baha'i minority within Iran. The core of the motion is in its final point, which calls on the Australian government to continue our long-term support for religious freedom and to take `further bilateral and multilateral diplomatic measures to support the religious freedoms of the Baha'is and religious freedom generally'.

The list of acts against the Baha'is, particularly against democratic opposition, in Iran since 1979 is well known internationally. Amongst those actions are: the execution of at least 200 practising Baha'is; the current threat to a number of them that they also will be executed; the confiscation of their property; action by the government to deprive them of their right to inheritance; the closure of their educational institutions; their ban from government run educational institutions; the recent seizure of the statistical student records of the free university they established in an attempt to give members of their community education; the throwing out of 10,000 public servants because of their religious beliefs; the destruction of the 1844 site of the House of Bab, the establishment point of the religion, and its replacement by a road and car park; the sale of the original home of the founder of the religious group, the Baha'u'llah; and a series of measures that have been taken against the religion.

It is noteworthy that at the 53rd session of the Commission on Human Rights the Australian government at Geneva did indicate that it was disturbed by `continuing evidence of religious intolerance in Iran and strongly protests against the recent confirmation by the Supreme Court of Iran of death sentences for apostasy against two members of the Baha'i faith.'

The government of Iran attempts to put on another face to its theocratic‐run persecution of minorities. It is worth noting that Gholam Hoseyn Raubarpour, head of the Islamic Revolutionary Courts—saying that, rather than people being prosecuted and threatened with death for religious practices, they were actually supposedly being tried for spying for Zionism in Israel—said that since August 1983 `no-one will be prosecuted or punished for having a specific ideology or view'. That, unfortunately, is in sharp contrast to part of the verdict on Dhabihullah Mahrami, one of the people currently facing death, when it was stated by the Revolutionary Court in Yazd:
Concerning the charges against Mr Dhabihullah Mahrami . . . ie denouncing the blessed religion of Islam and accepting the beliefs of the wayward Baha'i sect. . .
He was facing conviction for:

Having committed the most grievous sin, he remains firm in his baseless beliefs, he has, on three consecutive meetings, while being of sound body and mind and in absolute control, announced his allegiance to the principles of Baha'ism . . .

Essentially, despite the public rhetoric and the international attempt by the government at some stages to say that they have abandoned these decisions and that they reversed them, fundamentally, the reality by the Iranian regime is a systematic persecution of religious minorities. As we have seen recently in the German court system, despite the fact that Germany is the main economic supporter of the Iranian regime, the court has indicated the degree of connection between the current regime and the terrorist measures conducted against the Kurdish minority as well. There are also systematic examples of persecution of the Sunnis and the Christians.

In conclusion, this private members motion does call for resolute continuing action by the Australian government on a multilateral and bilateral front to ensure that this issue does not disappear. It is in conformity with resolutions in the US Congress and a number of United Nations human rights committees. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Like the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), I would like to bring to the attention of this House the extent to which Iranian adherence of the Baha'i faith continues to be subject to the most appalling violations of their most basic human rights and liberties. Since the Islamic revolution, the government of Iran has carried out a systematic and organised attempt to destroy the Baha'i faith and demoralise its followers. At least 10,000 Baha'is are believed to have fled Iran since the late 1970s. Of the approximate 300,000 Baha'is who remained in Iran, over 200 have been killed, 15 others have disappeared and are presumed dead, hundreds have been imprisoned and tens of thousands have been deprived of real and personal property, jobs and educational opportunities. Baha'i holy places and cemeteries have been desecrated. Followers of the Baha'i in Iran today are forced to bury their dead in unmarked graves at a wasteland reserved for so-called infidels.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I had the opportunity to meet with certain members of the Baha'i faith who live in my electorate. I heard many appalling stories of persecution and discrimination of Baha'is by Iranian clerical and civil authorities. One story that particularly moved me was that of Kiarash Firouzi, a 21‐year‐old Iranian Baha'i now living in Australia. Kiarash's experience is unfortunately not an atypical one for an Iranian follower of the Baha'i faith. When Kiarash was five years old his father was arrested solely on the grounds of being a Baha'i. Shortly thereafter Iranian officials also sent Kiarash's grandfather to prison, again solely on the basis of being a Baha'i. Tragically, both men were executed within nine months of each other in the early 1980s.

Subsequently, Kiarash's family business and certain family properties were confiscated. After spending 10 months in prison, Kiarash's mother and uncle gathered family members and fled by motorcycle from Iran. Kiarash now resides in Sydney with his sister. They await their mother, who will be joining them soon.

The Baha'is in Iran seek no special privileges. Rather, they desire only the most basic civil, social, cultural and economic rights that we in Australia take for granted—rights to which all persons, irrespective of their religious beliefs, are entitled under the international covenants of human rights to which Iran is a party. Continued external pressure through resolutions such as those passed by the Australian parliament and other nation states and international bodies since the 1980s has been absolutely critical in stemming the worst of the persecution of Iran's Islamic regime towards the Baha'is and other minority groups.

Sadly, in the past several months there has been a deterioration of the situation of the Baha'is in Iran. As of March 1997, the Australian Baha'i community was aware of 14 Baha'is who are imprisoned because of their religious beliefs, of whom four have been sentenced to death. It is therefore critical at this time that Australia use all available communications channels in a systemic and organised fashion to urge the government of Iran to cease immediately its continuing flagrant and appalling mistreatment of followers of the Baha'i faith as well as other minority groups.

The issue of Iran's appalling human rights record is not a partisan one in this parliament. I know that my views on this matter are shared by the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Nairn), the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) in particular as well as the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith). I am confident that we can all agree here to condemn the Islamic Republic of Iran's failure to respond to the recommendations of Mr Abdelfattah Amor, UN Special Rapporteur for Religious Intolerance, regarding the violations of religious freedom in Iran and urge the government of Iran to take immediate steps to implement all those recommendations, particularly as they relate to the Baha'is.

BREAK.PARA: I am hopeful that condemnation from Australia and others in the international community will make it impossible for Iran's new government to continue the country's flagrant disregard of international norms and its commitment under the various international conventions to which it is a party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) acknowledges the growing use of and demand for the Internet in Australia;
(2) notes that a large number of Internet users are families and individuals; and
(3) affirms its support for untimed local calls for Internet users.

There are approximately a million Internet users in Australia, and this figure is growing weekly. The people who use the Internet are not necessarily university boffins or computer whizzes but ordinary people—mums, dads and kids. As the great benefits of the Internet are becoming known, small business is starting to use it just as big business has already discovered its value.

The Internet is an outstanding resource for every user—whether they want information on how to roast coffee beans, as I did recently for a colleague, or a virtual tour of the Louvre in Paris or real-time pictures of sunrise over Las Vegas. Why anyone would want to see that is beyond me, but it is there. My speeches, my press releases and my newsletters are all on the Internet—and some on the other side might say the same about that. I am proud to know that every one of my constituents with access to the Internet can access my home page so they can know what I am doing, what I am up to, and can judge me accordingly, and they can e-mail me to let me know how they feel—which they are doing in increasing numbers, I am happy to report.

BREAK.PARA: I also access home pages of individual parliamentarians of the United States and Britain and keep in touch with them via e-mail. My staff also keep in touch with their staff.

It is a brave new world of information and technology. Through Internet chat channels new friendships are being forged the world over. The globe is truly becoming a global village when a nurse in Washington, North Carolina, a dentist in Brescia, Italy, a writer in Perth, Australia, and a designer in Ottawa, Canada, can all get together and discuss family and day-to-day matters in a chat channel called CasinoBar—trivial stuff mostly but nevertheless stuff of good friendship and good fellowship. And that is just one of thousands of chat channels covering the full gamut of human interest topics the world over.

There is a cost to access the Internet. The user must have a computer and the associated software. The user must then access an Internet service provider at the cost of a local telephone call and, once connected, can then communicate with the world. Internet service providers charge either on a `duration of link' basis or by monthly, quarterly or annual fees. Competition among service providers has kept fees low and, combined with cost of a local call access, affordable for all consumers.

Affordability is one of the great things about the Internet and, for as long as users continue to have access to untimed local calls, this remarkable and exciting world bank of knowledge will continue to be accessed by mums, dads and kids throughout our community. I remain very concerned about the spectre of B-Party charging; that is, the charging of Internet service providers for receiving data calls. Such costs could do the same damage as timed local calls, for increased costs by ISPs would no doubt be charged back to the user.

I want to use an example provided by my constituent Peter Carnall of how the Internet is already economically beneficial to Australia. Peter's quarterly phone bill prior to being connected to the Internet was around $90. Twelve months later, after the installation of a second line, that bill is now $375 because of the phone calls to the many new friends around the world that he has made on the Net.

The multiplier effect is staggering. He now mails postcards and letters to his friends which he would not have done normally. He mails packages that would not normally have been sent. He has sent CDs, books and souvenirs of Australia. He has travelled throughout Australia to meet his new friends. He has purchased many Internet publications and annual subscriptions. And Peter is just one user out of almost a million. He is `on the net' only because of the current low cost. Higher charges either on an untimed basis or increased fees by his ISP will give him only one option: to go off-line completely.

For Australia to remain a traveller on the information superhighway, Internet access must remain affordable to everyone and, whilst untimed local calls for Internet users must continue, imposts on service providers to provide their services as economically as possible must not become a potential extra cost for the user.

I am delighted that the government has tackled the issue of untimed local calls positively and in the interests of the average Internet user. I would, however, be most alarmed if backdoor costs such as timed charges on Internet service providers meant that consumers would have to pay more for Internet access.

Australians are renowned for accepting and incorporating new technology in their daily lives. It is an unfortunate prospect that only the well off in our community may end up with access to the World Wide Web when it is a resource that must be available to everybody. I invite anyone listening or anyone who reads the Hansard to visit me at www.wantree. com.au/~stirling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Yes, and I reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to rise to support this motion about the Internet. Few generations have the opportunity that we have to preside over a major transition point in the affairs of the human race. In the developed First World countries like Australia, the industrial revolution is, on the time scale we usually associate with these things, rapidly giving way to the information age. Soon, electronic mail will exceed the more traditional `snail mail'—no disrespect to Australia Post intended. Data transmissions will exceed voice over our telephone lines.

SPEECH.PARA: The transition to a society dominated by digital information has been a sudden, almost brutal process as old ways of doing things have been swept aside in a few short decades since the introduction of the computer. The typewriter, the telex, carbon paper, vinyl records—all things most members of this parliament, even the younger members, grew up with—are now historic relics.

The telephone companies have also been caught in this rapid transformation of the economy and social context of society which has accompanied the headlong rush into digital technology in the developed world. They have been left with a network built at massive cost. The value of the Australian network alone is in the order of $20 billion. But this network was quite reasonably constructed to work best with phones when used in the traditional manner. This means that, say, if 10 per cent of users want to make a phone call at any given time, under those circumstances they will all get dial tone. The average call lasts less than five minutes and all the customers are satisfied.

We now have the digital age and the introduction of the Internet and the universal graphical web browser interface we use today. Now the World Wide Web dominates the telephone networks that were once designed for another purpose entirely. The consequences have been substantial. Telecommunications companies are now faced with a dilemma. Networks are expensive to build and maintain, but the marginal cost of a data transmission is falling fast as bandwidth increases. This explains the rush to add value.

Telstra and Optus are both investing massively in broadband services which deliver new content and hopefully generate new streams of revenue. But the issue of Internet use remains. The telecom companies assert that the networks are in danger of being swamped by calls which are held open for hours at a time and that more users now want access to lines at the same time. The spectre of picking up the phone and not getting any dial tone is raised. Is this threat real? That question has been pursued in the US of late and the answer seems to be that it is not. Internet users counter with the statistics of new second phone lines which have been installed for on-line access alone. These are a massive new revenue stream.

But the issue remains that the network was not built to cope with this deluge of data. In the recent major reform of telecommunications law, the government left open the option of timed local calls in this context. But the solution here is not timed local calls. That would act as a real and substantial disincentive for people to move to an on-line future. Rather, the network must grow and evolve. New transmission systems such as ATM and ISDN must become the norm.

Telstra has done some great research. My recent visit to the TRL labs at Clayton showed me that Telstra in particular is at the leading edge of innovation when it comes to the Internet age. Its cable modems are a thing of joy and beauty to a person who started out on-line with a 300‐baud modem from Dick Smith. The prospect of megabytes per second leaves me straining at the leash.

But timed local calls are a response of yesteryear. That answer looks backward, not forward. The real solution is to move from a plain, old telephone system to a communications system which is digital from end to end. If Australia is to be a major player in the international on-line economy, then this is a backdoor which should have been firmly slammed in the face of any telco that wants to exploit it. The prospect of timed local calls would kill the industry dead in its tracks and ensure that Australia is left behind.

The solution lies in the evolution of the network to technology which is indeed already available. Telstra unfortunately missed the bus on ISDN, and even the new On-Ramp access costs are way too high. That, however, must be the way of the future. I urge the government to reject the notion of timed local calls. That is a `back to the future' solution. The digital superhighway will brook no U-turns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a great believer in using every benefit modern technology can deliver. Because there are continuing advances in areas of information and communication technology, I wholeheartedly support this motion about the Internet.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently the Internet resource is doubling in size every 12 to 15 months. The last survey by Network Wizards was in January 1997. At that time it found 514,760 sites with the top level domain name `au', which users will know indicates an Australian site. Worldwide, it found over 16,000,000 hosts in total. The `au' top level domain name was the 10th most commonly used name. By country, Australia ranks sixth in the world in the use of the Internet.

There are many faces of the Internet, including those covering public policy matters such as censorship, ownership, security, terrorism and charging practices. If we accept the growing evidence that the Internet, as an electronic `world library', will largely replace the presently used information system, then the major issues that arise are access and cost of access. To use a conventional library in Townsville, there is a cost to get to the door. But, once inside, usage is unlimited and free. Good public policy would be best served with a similar philosophy for the Internet.

I strongly back Senator Alston's decision to prevent the introduction of timed local data calls. The view of Townsville Internet users, such as Tim Van Lint and Cathy Grainger, is that timed calls, whether charged to the originator or to the receiver, would seriously impact on the Internet usage of average people. Last week Jens Didriksen sent me a thoughtful e‐mail. He said:
If timed local calls were ever introduced, many current users of the Internet could not afford continuing access and would likely disconnect.

It's becoming more and more important for Townsville families, especially with school age kids, to be able to stay connected to the Net. The kids must get the opportunity to grow up with this rapidly changing technology. It gives them a head start.
If we are serious about working smarter, and yet again become the clever country, we really need to give the younger generations all the help we can.
We should support the current technology, encourage further development and innovations . . . we might not understand all of it—but our kids will—and do!

Considerable fears have been expressed to me via e-mail that the introduction of timed local data calls would force some Internet service providers out of the market. The Internet does create jobs. At a time when we are working to lower unemployment, it would seem short‐sighted to stifle what is a rapidly growing industry.

These days the Web is everywhere. Earlier this year, I was aboard the USS Independence about 200 kilometres off the coast of Queensland. Every office on the warship had access to the Net. I was able to send mail back to Townsville instantaneously and electronically from the Pacific Ocean. With the Internet you can look in on a space shuttle mission orbiting the Earth or browse through the pages of history in libraries located in Europe and America. Transcripts of speeches made by Presidents and Prime Ministers can be accessed and analysed minutes after they have been presented. This year's budget, of course, was available entirely and immediately on budget night. A few short years ago, we could only dream of these sorts of possibilities.

The level of interest in and awareness of the Internet is growing rapidly in Australia, and the home and family market is one of the fastest growing areas of all. The cost of the basic hardware and software needed to access e-mail and the Internet is now within the reach of the vast majority of Australians, and that cost is constantly falling. Each week and each month more and more Australians are discovering the Internet—discovering what it can do, where it can take them and what the boundaries are, and then pushing beyond them.

On a personal level, I find the Internet and electronic mail to be an increasingly important tool in my representation of the people of Townsville. I certainly want to see the benefits of the Net made available as widely as possible in an affordable way. I certainly thank the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) for moving this motion and I support it wholeheartedly.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Service Delivery Agency: St Albans Office

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The St Albans office of the Commonwealth Service Delivery Agency is a particularly busy office providing contact for many aged and disabled people along, unfortunately, with many unemployed people. It is also an office located very much in the heart of the most ethnically diverse part of Melbourne. It is an office, however, which does not have the most elementary service of all to many aged and invalid people in particular and that is a toilet or access to a toilet. Whilst, on superficial examination, that might seem an object of some wry amusement, the realities are that it causes considerable embarrassment to many elderly and disabled people who are visiting that office, particularly when they have quite inadequate English in many cases.

SPEECH.PARA: The nearest public toilet facility to the office is about five minutes walk away for a relatively fit person at the St Albans railway station, yet this is a very busy Commonwealth office. I understand that since 1994 the Department of Social Security has had an obligation to provide toilets for clients visiting the offices, but those offices such as St Albans which predate 1994 and are in somewhat antiquated buildings do not have the requirement. There is some provision, I understand, in emergency situations for a staff member to escort a client to a staff toilet, but that is not advertised and is only provided in emergency circumstances. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to pay tribute to a former mayor of the City of Stirling who passed away recently. Mr Satchell was a devoted community worker and very dedicat ed, over a decade, to the area as a local councillor. He was a founding member of the North Dianella Youth Club and heavily involved with the football club there. Mr Satchell was involved in the community when Dianella was young and opening up. He and his wife and family dedicated significant time to the community to ensure that facilities were provided for the local people to enjoy. The fact that the Dianella Community Recreation Centre was renamed the Jim Satchell Community Recreation Centre a few years ago is recognition of his tireless work for the community and on the council. On behalf of the electorate of Stirling, I would like to pass on my condolences to Maureen Satchell and her family on the passing of Jim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I raise this afternoon goes to the primacy of parliament. I refer, in doing so, to a decision of the Senate last Friday afternoon to reject the government's mean‐fisted attempt to restrict the availability of employment services on a free basis to all Australians. The problem is that in the lead‐up to the debate the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, in a bull‐in‐a‐china‐shop approach, threatened to withdraw the Reform of Employment Services Bill from debate in the Senate. We are not talking about mickey mouse expenditure items being covered by this bill; we are talking about expenditure of the order of $1 billion per year. Yet, in the lead‐up to the debate last Friday, the senator suggested to all who would listen that, so far as she was concerned, she was not going to allow accountability and, if need be, she would withdraw the bill before the Senate and seek to implement her changes to employment services by regulatory action.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the view that there is a requirement for accountability to this House. I thought that was what this new ministerial code of practice was about. I have a view that all Australians, especially those who are unemployed, irrespective of whether they are long‐term or short‐term unemployed, are entitled to a free employment service. But, more importantly, it is about the primacy of parliament. The Senate and the House of Representatives cannot be threatened by ministers who cannot get their own way that, if we do not buckle and give in to the suggestions by this government, things will not be debated. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jeanes, Susan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to inform the House that the South Australian state member for Reynall, Ms Julie Greig, has collected a petition with over 2,000 signatures to inform the House of the concern in my area for the car industry. Ms Greig has been working very closely with me, with the Southern Development Board, the local councils and the industry to ensure that those views of the industry are brought to the attention of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: The petition prays that the House will freeze automotive tariff cuts beyond 15 per cent post the year 2000 and to take urgent action prior to 2000 on micro‐economic reform and at the same time ensure predictability and certainty in the industry to provide assurance for the long‐term viability and competitiveness in our industry base—in particular, the South Australian motor vehicle industry.

As I said previously, Ms Greig and I have been working very closely with the industry. I have put in two submissions to the Productivity Commission's inquiry. We have assisted with the local southern region council submissions to the industry inquiry and with the local councils' inquiries. We do not perform stunts, as the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) performs. We will not be falling for his stunts. We are working very closely with the industry to make sure that this government hears its views and provides a framework within which the industry will continue to grow and thrive in South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday, my wife Jan and I attended the Blacktown City Festival. The festival itself is a week‐long display of local art and craft groups, choral society concerts and historical displays. It culminates in a street festival day with over 300 stalls. The highlight of the festival is a street parade by more than 80 floats and marching bands through the Blacktown CBD. This year's official guest was Hazel Hawke, who chairs the New South Wales Heritage Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The Blacktown City Festival began in 1975 as the Crafty Bunyip Festival. The festival originated through a committee—the Blacktown Community Council of the Arts—which aimed to encourage and develop arts, to share skills and information and to make the public aware of the development of artistic standards and abilities in Blacktown.
