In 1979, Blacktown City Council celebrated becoming a city, and what better way to celebrate than the whole community coming together in a major festival held in the main street of the new city. At this stage, Blacktown Council and the festival committee joined forces and presented the then largest festival Blacktown had seen. The Crafty Bunyip Festival became the Blacktown City Festival.

The rationale for the original Crafty Bunyip Festival still holds true today and is one of the driving forces behind the success of the festival week. The festival provides an opportunity for the community to meet, learn more about their community's resources, exchange cultural heritages and promote Blacktown city's cultural identity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the electorate of Lilley, and more particularly the suburb of Pinkenba, lost one of its hardest working community members: Ted Mailes. Ted could best be described as a good bloke who put his heart and soul into the betterment of his suburb and his local community.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Brisbane City Council planned to build a waste disposal plant at Luggage Point, near his beloved Pinkenba, Ted was so committed to his community that even the onset of cancer could not stop him from taking on the city council. Ted and his group, who called themselves the Bayside Residents Against a Toxic Site, fought tooth and nail against the waste dump and, in September 1996, their struggle was vindicated when the city council decided to abandon plans to build the toxic liquid dump at Pinkenba. The professional manner in which Ted Mailes and the BRATS committee conducted their `no dump' campaign is an example to all community groups on how to get things done.

Ted was always looking for ways to help his community. He was a regular visitor to my office with his concerns for the area, always asking for support for programs he and his group had in mind for the betterment of Pinkenba. Ted will be greatly missed. He was a big man both physically and in giving his all to the community. He will be sadly missed by us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Liberal Chief Minister of the ACT helped open the Mandir Society's new building yesterday. It might not surprise you, Mr Speaker, to learn that I was at the demonstration across the road.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for the demonstration across the road was that the 14 workers who were sponsored by the Mandir Society to come out here from India and build the thing were not paid. Rather, they were paid but they were paid at the appalling rate of 51c an hour.

The workers were accommodated in outrageous circumstances: an old hall with inadequate—or no proper—cooking facilities and washing facilities. They shared three rooms amongst the 14 of them. They were not paid superannuation and they were not paid living away from home allowance. They had no protective clothing, there was inadequate scaffolding during the construction of the building, there was no fall protection and there was no first aid kit on site. The list goes on.

These workers who were brought out from India to build the temple were treated in the most appalling way. I believe—and I believe the majority of Australians would agree—that 51c an hour in Australian society is unacceptable.

The company, in their defence, felt that it was more money than the workers would get overseas, but that is essentially saying that they should get less money because they came from overseas. It is a circumstance which I fear will escalate in this country in the absence of social security safety nets. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It was perhaps inevitable, when you tabled members' travel expenses last week, that some irresponsible newspaper would seek to inaccurately scandalise the list. Not surprisingly, it was Brisbane's Courier‐Mail that spread across its front page an article attempting to sensationalise members' travel. It is a shoddy piece of journalism from Matt Horan, in which he wrongly names what the paper said were the top 10 backbench travellers.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, Horan's list does not accord with the figures you tabled. He names the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) as the top spender when in fact he was only the third highest. The two highest were left off the list altogether. The list is headed `Backbenchers' but includes six ministers, shadow ministers or office holders, while leaving others off the list. The member named 10th actually ranked 18th. Mr Speaker, only two of the backbenchers named were actually in the list of top 10 spenders named in the list you tabled.

The journalist failed to mention that the claims were covering different periods and that some members have different travel entitlements than others. Members can expect their travel expenses to be subject to scrutiny, but they also have a right to expect newspapers and journalists to report the facts accurately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Parks Children's House will close effective from 6 June. This community based child‐care centre is located in the Parks Community Centre and it services the local community—the most disadvantaged area in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: After last year's savage budget cuts to child care, the centre only just managed to survive, but the cuts contained in this budget were the last straw. Adults re‐entering education to improve their lot in life, sole parents, families who are employed, the overwhelming majority where both parents work full time but earn a combined income of less than $500 a week, are the ones who are going to miss out because they cannot afford any increases in charges.

This is how the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of this country looks after our working poor—the people he refers to as `Howard's battlers'. Nothing is so far from the truth. The Howard government and the Olsen Liberal government in South Australia have crippled this area. The high school is closed, the child‐care centre is closed, the Skillshare centre is closing, legal services funding is almost non‐existent and community health services and public housing have been slashed.

The Parks Community Centre was built in the 1970s to address the serious problems associated with long‐term poverty. The 20 years of achievements by the Parks Community Centre and community organisations have taken just 18 months to be destroyed by the Liberal state and federal governments.

How many people are feeling relaxed and comfortable, as promised by this Prime Minister in the lead‐up to the last election? If there are any, I can tell this House that there is no‐one living in and around the Parks area who is feeling relaxed or comfortable. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Woodward, Commander Edward Arthur, DSO (Double Bar), KSJ, FINucE, RN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne, Chris, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to record the passing of a very loyal local Liberal in my electorate, Commander Edward Arthur Woodward DSO (Double Bar), KSJ, FINucE, RN, and to pass on my condolences to his wife, Barbara. Commander Woodward, who was an extraordinarily strong supporter of the Liberal Party over a very lengthy time, passed away in my electorate last Tuesday.

SPEECH.PARA: Teddy and Barbara have been particularly kind to me over the years and I regard them both with great affection. They have been stalwarts of the local Liberal party branch in Leabrook, the state electorate committee and the regional convention over a long period. Commander Woodward was a fine, upstand ing man. He was decent, honest, wise and witty. He was devoted to his wife, Barbara, and to the Liberal Party and the community. He will be sadly missed by many, not least of which by my wife, Carolyn; my mother, Margaret; his very close friend in the Liberal Party, Jan Boyd‐Turner; and, indeed, all the Liberals in my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for a few seconds to note that today is the national day of Italy and to pass on my congratulations to all those Italian‐Australians who have made such a great contribution to this nation. There was, of course, an Italian on the First Fleet and since then Italians have made a great contribution in areas such as Leichhardt in my electorate, Five Dock, Ashfield, and Carlton in Melbourne. It was my pleasure to represent the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) at the COASIT Ball.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for member's statements has concluded.

—The Attorney-General is absent from question time this week. He is attending the Second World Congress on Family Law and the Rights of Children and Youth. He will be meeting United States and European officials on law, security and human rights issues. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will answer questions on his behalf. The Deputy Prime Minister is absent from question time this week. He is attending a ministerial meeting of OECD, chairing the annual ministerial meeting of the Cairns Group and also participating the other meeting within Europe and the United States. The Minister for Foreign Affairs will answer questions on his behalf.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Health. My question refers to yesterday's announcement by HCF to increase its premiums by 12 per cent, its second increase since last August, further reducing the value of the government's tax rebate. When asked why a thousand people a day left private health insurance during the March quarter, does the minister recall saying:

QUESTION.PARA: What you are seeing happen here is a fallout from all the arguing and disagreement between these galahs in the private health sector.

Why will the minister not accept that spending $1.7 billion on another 3,000 public hospital beds right across Australia would have helped more patients than giving it—to use his words—to the galahs in the private health sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two points about what the honourable member says. The first is the drop‐out from private health insurance and the second is the method of redressing it. I will take the second one first. We could have just put extra money into public hospitals. That is what you tried to do with the last Medicare agreement in 1993 and it has been spectacularly unsuccessful, because at the moment we have no mechanism to put extra money in without seeing that the states just take the money out.
—That is why you are taking it out!
—The member for Dobell!

—That was the net effect of what you did in the last Medicare agreement. I could have put $400 million or $500 million a year into public hospitals and the net effect would have been zero as it was because the states would have just pulled the money out. I think that would have been stupid.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point about that is that it is treating the symptom not the cause. Whether it is Peter Beattie in Queensland or Bob Carr in New South Wales, people understand that, unless you have can put a floor under the drop‐out from private health insurance, then you will not be doing anything to treat the cause. You might be happy to treat the symptom; it would give you some temporary relief. But in the end what we are doing is treating the root cause.

The second thing the honourable member raises is the drop‐out from private health in the March quarter which was 0.7 per cent. While that is a disappointing figure, I should compare it to the March quarter in 1995 which was also 0.7 per cent and also the March quarter in 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but we didn't blow $1.7 billion then. It is $1.7 billion.
—Order! The member for Dobell has asked the question.

—In fact, what this shows is first of all the hypocrisy of the opposition, and secondly the lack of knowledge of the opposition. If you have a look at what has happened in the year to March 1997—and I have gone back to 1992—it is in fact the lowest drop‐out from private health insurance in the last 12 months since we were elected of the last six years, and that is only because I went back six years. The fact is that in the year to March 1997 it was 1.4, in the year to March 1996 it was 1.7, in the year to March 1995 it was 2.0, in 1994 it was 2.2, in 1993 it was 1.6 and in 1992 it was 2.7.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that we have done better than you in the last 12 months of government than you were able to do at any particular time in your previous six years and probably a lot further.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $1.7 billion and 1,000 people are leaving a day.
—I warn the member for Dobell.

—The fact is that the incentives do not start from another month and most reasonable Australian will be happy to give us a go, unlike you. We are trying to do something to redress the problems that we had from the decisions that you made progressively over a decade which Access Economics reckons put the price of premiums 39 per cent higher than they would need to be otherwise. People will never forget the words of Graham Richardson which were basically that the Labor Party is a bit biased against private health insurance. You have no credibility and you have no right to even talk about this issue that you neglected and made worse for a decade.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House of progress on legislation to give effect to the government's 10‐point plan concerning native title?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the House that the legislation is in the course of being drafted. I expect to have the first draft of the legislation to have a look at about the middle of this month. I also take the opportunity of saying to the parliament and to the Australian people that the government's 10‐point plan to deal both with the deficiencies of the Native Title Act and also with the impractical decision of the High Court of Australia in the Wik case, has been arrived at after very, very careful consideration and very, very considerable examination by the government parties.

ANSWER.PARA: The plan that we are putting forward is not in any way an ambit claim. It is a settled, firm position. We are not willing to negotiate away the basic principles of that plan. We are of course ready to discuss detail at the margin, but it would be wrong of me and misleading of me and creating false expectations if I were to allow the view to get around that in some way the 10‐point plan can be the subject of significant compromise. It cannot, because it is a received, settled position. It endeavours to address the fact that in the view of the government the High Court's decision in Wik pushed the pendulum too far in one direction and that the proper role of the parliament so to bring the pendulum back to the middle.

The 10‐point plan respects the place of native title in the common law of Australia, but it is also designed to give to the pastoral and mining industries of Australia the certainty to which they are clearly entitled and which is clearly in the national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through bucket loads of extinguishment, is it?
—I should also say to the interjecting Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the plan does not involve, in the words of the member for Banks:

ANSWER.PARA: A land grab of monumental proportions. It is finishing off the job that Captain Phillip did. It is a disgrace and the plan will not withstand scrutiny.

That is the contribution. We should know where the member for Banks stands on this matter. The member for Banks said that he agreed completely with the remarks that were made by the Chairman of the reconciliation council. He said that Wik was about sharing the country. Certainly, we are in favour of a title system in this country which gives equal rights to all Australians, irrespective of their racial background. The 10‐point plan is designed to do exactly that. The 10‐point plan respects native title. It also respects the need to deliver that certainty and that consistency.

I also note that the shadow Attorney‐General said that he is going to have to consider some fairly substantial changes to it at this stage whether he likes it or not. I would say to the Leader of the Opposition, with whom I discussed this matter shortly before question time, and as I indicated to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition: I am perfectly happy to meet the opposition but that meeting should take place against the background of everybody in this parliament understanding that the 10‐point plan is a fair balance between the claims and the rights of Aboriginal people and the rest of the Australian community.

The discussion that will take place should not encourage anybody on the opposition side to imagine that the views expressed by the member for Banks are going to be paid much regard by the members of the government. Perhaps I should not be too troubled about the views of the member for Banks because, in the discussion I had with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on Thursday night, when I taxed him about the rather contrary views of the member for Banks, he said, `Don't worry about Melham.'

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to reports that the government has decided to break its agreement with Australia's minerals and resources industries by imposing a cap on diesel fuel rebate. Does the Prime Minister agree that diesel fuel rebate is critical for those industries being internationally competitive? Does the Prime Minister agree with the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies—AMEC—that imposing a cap on diesel fuel rebate would amount to, `deliberately raising taxes on business inputs'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Perth for that question. I take the opportunity to inform the honourable gentleman that the government expects, on behalf of the Australian taxpayer, to spend about $813 million in the coming financial year on the diesel fuel rebate scheme for miners. I also remind the honourable gentleman that, faced with a deficit of $10½ billion—which, I think to the great credit of the government, will be converted into a surplus of $1.6 billion by the completion of its first three years in government—we had to take a number of difficult decisions in last year's budget. I think we have substantially insulated important productive sectors of the Australian economy from the need to take expenditure cuts.

ANSWER.PARA: It always interests me when I hear members of the opposition talking about the budget and saying that every single measure we take involves some kind of, however marginal, pairing back of something is absolutely wrong. They are constantly calling for more expenditure and yet, at the end of it all, they say, `Oh, yes, we favour balancing the budget as well.' The reality is that you cannot simultaneously serve those three masters.

I would say to the mining industry of Australia: do not be misled by scare comments from spokesmen for the opposition. Do not be misled by some of the articles appearing in the press this morning. The mining industry has been treated very fairly indeed and it will continue to be treated very fairly. I have no doubt at all, in the discussions that will take place between the government and the mining industry, that the proposals put forward by the government will be seen by the mining industry as fair and reasonable and utterly consonant with our responsibilities to the generality of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the acting Attorney‐General. Is the acting Attorney‐General aware of media reports relating to the Kruger case in the High Court of Australia, which was heard by the full court in February 1996? Can the acting Attorney‐General advise the House of the key issues that were involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of some media reports in relation to the Kruger case and I can inform the House a little about the nature of it. The Kruger case began in 1995. It is a High Court case where a number of plaintiffs have claimed that the Commonwealth is legally liable for past practices of removal of Aboriginal children from their families and that the Commonwealth is liable for compensation. The Kruger case and the Bray case were both heard by the full court of the High Court in February 1996.

ANSWER.PARA: The former government finalised its submission in relation to that matter in November 1995. At issue we saw the same questions that have been raised in the report Bringing them home—that is, the report of the national inquiry into the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their parents and their families. Those issues are that the practices of past territory and state governments in removing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families were unconstitutional, were illegal, were a genocide and a cultural genocide, and were a restriction on freedom of association; and that compensation should be paid to those people who were subject to these practices.

Quite clearly the issues were the same. Since the government tabled that report last week, the Labor opposition have claimed that the government should immediately admit liability and pay compensation for those past practices of various governments. But, if we look at the former government's response to the Kruger and Bray cases, we see that the issues were exactly the same.

What we see is that, in 1995, the Keating Labor government formally adopted a position where it denied any liability and denied calls for compensation. It is important to look at the report because, page by page, chapter by chapter, it takes up each of those issues. In chapter 1 it says this:

The Commonwealth pleads that . . . the Ordinance was in any event valid in that it was enacted for the purpose of the protection and preservation of persons of the Aboriginal race and was capable of being reasonably considered to be (or alternatively was) appropriate and adapted to the achievement of that purpose.
It went on:
The Commonwealth denies that it is liable in damages for a breach of the Constitution and pleads that the claims are statute barred or otherwise time barred.
In Chapter 9, it went on and said this:

In the event that the Commonwealth is found to have been in breach of any constitutional rights, guarantees, immunities, freedoms or provisions of the Constitution as alleged Plaintiffs, the Commonwealth denies that any such breach gives rise to a personal right of action for damages in the Plaintiffs independent of any common law action.
A further quote, if you look at it, can be found in relation to the genocide question. I found that one particularly pointed. In paragraphs 7 and 8, it says:

It is clear from the definition of the term genocide in the Genocide Convention, that before genocide will be committed, one or other of the acts listed in the article must have been carried out with the intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group as such. It is not sufficient to show that a law authorises certain acts in order for it to authorise genocide. It is necessary to show that the intent of the law, or acts authorised under the law, was the destruction of a racial group as such. The effect or likely effect of the act is not determinative, nor is its objective purpose. What must be shown is criminal intent.

It is interesting that, when questioned upon these matters, what we hear from members of the opposition now trying to defend their role in relation to this comes from people like the Deputy Leader of the Opposition this morning, where he said:
How the issue went off and was actually argued in the courts by lawyers and all the particular issues, I am not quite sure. But certainly, that issue, to my knowledge was not before ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not before lawyers!

—What he is suggesting is that lawyers go off—and the honourable member is a lawyer—and argue these matters without instructions from their clients, that they are on a frolic of their own. I have never heard anything so absurd.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Banks has been touting around the gallery today some terms of reference which were intended to try to show that the former government was concerned about the compensation issue. It is clear, when you look at the way in which this issue was addressed—and the timing of it—that there are two factors involved.

The first is that there was a reference to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on 11 May, which dealt with the issues of compulsory separation and the adequacy in relation to our laws—and a requirement to examine the laws and practices in respect of placement of Aboriginal children—but which did not address the issues of compensation. Later, as an afterthought, when the litigation was commenced, what we saw was the addition of a terms of reference. Let us focus. It did not talk about providing compensation. It said to the commission:
. . . examine the principles relevant to determining the justification for compensation for persons.
No compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on. Read it all.
—The member for Hotham.
—Keep reading.
—I do not mind reading it. I will put it fully:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . examine the principles relevant to determining the justification for compensation for persons or communities affected by such separations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, compensation—the `c' word!
—Yes, the word was there, but it did not provide for compensation.

ANSWER.PARA: What you had was a reference of 2 August and then the submission in November of the same year in which they argued totally against it—on every issue at a later point in time. In the terms the shadow attorney‐general used in describing the case, there was very much a holding operation in relation to both matters so far as the former government were concerned—to get them off the agenda before any election when they would be responsible in relation to these matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister and follows from the incomplete answer of the acting Attorney‐General. Why, Prime Minister, when you released the submissions in the Kruger and Bray cases yesterday, did you fail to draw attention to paragraph 1.6 in the submissions, which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: The means of dealing with the present human and social consequences of the implementation of those past policies which may now be perceived to have been wrong or even seriously misguided must now be found in the political and administrative processes rather than the curial process. The Attorney‐General of the Commonwealth has recently requested the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to inquire into and report on matters which include tracing the past laws, practices and policies which resulted in the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders from their families by compulsion, duress and undue influence and the effects of those past laws and policies, examining the principles relevant to determining the justification for compensation for persons affected by such separations.

Prime Minister, bearing in mind that that paragraph precisely goes to the point of the circumstances of compensation, even where you agree that there is no legal requirement upon you to do so, why did you deliberately leave that out yesterday from your presentation to the media on this matter? And now, as we are in a situation where we have the product of that very lengthy period of analysis, why do you still believe that extra legal compensation is inappropriate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Filibustering at question time cannot relieve you of the charge of utter inconsistency. The Leader of the Opposition has been caught out. The Leader of the Opposition has been saying one thing over here—`I am all in favour of doing this'—yet, when he was in government, less than two years ago, the Leader of the Opposition was adopting the same arguments that we were attacked last week by the opposition for adopting. The Leader of the Opposition speaks with two voices. The Leader of the Opposition conveniently has two faces. The Leader of the Opposition is both hypocritical and inconsistent on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: If it is good enough in government to authorise your lawyers, can I say to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Gareth Evans QC, the idea that the lawyers for the Commonwealth would go off on a frolic of their own, that they would make up the Commonwealth's submission and that on the way into the High Court they would decide whether or not to reject the doctrine of intergenerational guilt, that they would decide whether or not there would be a submission in favour of compensation—they would decide whether or not at the time these laws were implemented the people who implemented them believed, however wrong the belief may have been, they were for the benefit of the people towards whom they were being directed—absolutely defies belief.

I would be very interested to know whether the Leader of the Opposition responds to the letter he received today from the Acting Attorney-General asking that there be made available for perusal by the government relevant cabinet memoranda and other advice received by the former government. We will find out whether ministers' minds were directed to this or not.

There was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition dissembling on television yesterday when he said, `I do not particularly remember that coming before the cabinet. The lawyers went off and did it all on their own.' Do you mean to say that the lawyers decided whether or not compensation was going to be paid?

What is happening is that the Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues wound themselves up last week, and they threw away any attempt at a bipartisan response to this report. They shamefully politicised the whole process. They tried to wrap themselves in a cloak of moral unction, which is their wont on so many of these issues. But now the Australian people have been told that the very stance that the Leader of the Opposition criticised us for taking is exactly the same stance that the Labor government had taken in office.

The Labor government took exactly the same stance as this government has taken. The Labor government has disputed compensation. I do not remember the Labor government talking at the time about any question of a national apology. I do not remember the Labor government saying the things as late as February of 1996. I do not remember the Labor government saying any of these things.

The truth is that the Leader of the Opposition is a man for both seasons: if you are in government, you have one attitude; if you are in opposition, you have an opportunistically different attitude. He has been caught out on this. His own document, his own government's submission to the High Court, has demonstrated that he has double standards and monumental hypocrisy on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have a supplementary question. Why, Prime Minister, did you fail to admit that paragraph 1.6 of those submissions clearly shows that the previous Labor government—
—Order! The question is out of order. Resume your seat.
—was willing to consider the payment of extra legal compensation and had specifically—
—Order! Resume your seat. The Leader of the Opposition! The question is out of order.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer received the report of Professor Alan Fels into the reaction of the four major banks to the recent cut in official interest rates? Can the Treasurer advise the House of the results of this inquiry by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As the House will know, the Reserve Bank cut official interest rates on Friday, 23 May—last week.
—You used it.
—Order! The member for Calwell.
—My request at the beginning of the week to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission—
—You know what you have done!
—Order! I warn the member for Calwell.

—I requested the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to investigate the way in which each of the major banks passed on a 0.35 per cent reduction in their lead housing standard variable mortgage rate. The commission sought information from the four major banks about the timing of the decision to reduce rates, the basis for the decision not to pass on the 4.5 per cent cut, the terms and conditions for the reduction and the involvement of senior executives in any discussions about their decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: Each of the banks has now replied. In essence, the banks have stated to the commission that the decision by each to reduce its rate by 0.35 per cent was made independently. That was made after an assessment of the effect the reduction in the rate would have on the cost of funds. The ANZ also indicated it took into account competitor activity when considering the reduction. The National Australia Bank decided to reduce its business rate by 0.5 per cent on 23 May, to be effected from 30 June. Of course, the most significant event of last week was the decision by the ANZ Bank, which reconsidered the issue, on 27 May to cut its mortgage rates by 0.56 per cent, a move I welcomed last week because it made the ANZ Bank the most competitive of the major banks in the home mortgage market.

The ACCC will continue to be, and be requested to be by the government, a vigilant regulator and enforcer of the Trade Practices Act. The banking sector should have no doubt at all that, as far as this government is concerned, it wants to see the most competitive financial sector in Australia that is possible. There are a number of recommendations contained in the Wallis report which are aimed at injecting and infusing greater competition into the financial sector such as opening up the payment system and creating regulators which will allow deposit taking institutions to grow and compete.

The government will be responding to the Wallis report in due course, but I wish to underline again that, as far as this government is concerned, we believe that interest rate reductions are for the benefit of borrowers and not for the benefit of banks. The best way to pass on to borrowers the full advantage of lower interest rates is to ensure that there is heightened competition in the sector, the kind of competition that will ensure that those benefits are delivered to consumers and delivered expeditiously.

That is the other element in relation to this. It is not just the quantum of the amount of the interest rate reduction which is to be passed on but the timeliness with which it is to be passed on. I would again say to consumers that the best way to get the best deal out of a financial institution is to shop around. Make sure that competition works for you and that those banks or other financial institutions that offer the most competitive outcome are seen to achieve the kind of custom which rewards efficiency and competitiveness in the financial sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister, and it concerns the ongoing aged care debacle and the government's decision to grant a $5 per day capital subsidy for concessional residents in nursing homes. Has the Prime Minister seen reports of comments by the Catholic Church describing that decision as `a cruel joke' and by the Uniting Church as `an act of derision'? In light of that condemnation, will the Prime Minister instruct the Minister for Family Services to withdraw the government's discriminatory and ill‐prepared Aged Care Bill?

—Can I say in response to the honourable member for Jagajaga I will analyse the statements to which she has referred and see whether they are worthy of the status that she has given them. I thank her for the opportunity of informing the parliament that I believe the aged care reforms that have been brought forward by my colleague are first‐class reforms.
—Not according to the churches.
—Order! The member for Jagajaga!

—They have the full support of the government. They will do something that the Labor government stubbornly refused to do—that is, inject more capital into the aged care sector. When the Labor Party was in office, it starved the aged care sector of money.
—You are going to starve the disadvantaged.
—You had a miserable proposal of $3 a patient in the concessional area. We are offering $5. You were offering $3 and it had a cap of $10 million.
—That is not what the churches are paying. You are ignorning the churches.
—Order! I warn the member for Jagajaga!

—It is pretty easy for people to see which proposal was the meaner. It is pretty easy for people to see which government has tried to do something about it. This is yet another example of the Labor Party saying and doing one thing in government and saying and doing the complete opposite now that they are in opposition. Just as the Leader of the Opposition was prepared with his hand on his heart to oppose compensation in the Kruger case yet now beggars to support it in an unqualified fashion, so it was that when Labor was in office it was prepared to introduce for the hostel sector, with very strong support and the understanding of the then opposition, a funding proposal. We are imposing that exact same proposal in relation to the aged care sector and the opposition is running around saying it is a dreadful, outrageous proposal.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Jagajaga's specialty in Australian politics is scaring people and spreading misinformation amongst elderly, vulnerable people. You really should be ashamed of yourself, some of the things that you are saying. You are deliberately stirring up fear. You are deliberately creating an atmosphere of instability for grubby partisan, political purposes. You should be ashamed of some of the things you are saying to the old people of Australia. Instead of supporting a decent measure, which is modelled on one of your measures, you are going about it in a grubby partisan, political way. You ought to be ashamed of yourself.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Privatisation: New South Wales Electricity Industry

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. The minister would be aware of the New South Wales government's proposal to privatise the states' electricity industry and the state ALP's endorsement of this initiative. What is the federal government's reaction to this initiative? How does it sit with this government's privatisation policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen some reports in recent times.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The question is out of order. It concerns the policies of the New South Wales government and not the policies of the federal government.
—The question is in order. There is no point of order.
—It also concerns the question of the ALP and not the question of the government's policies. So it is out of order on two counts.
—The question is in order.

—As I was saying, I have seen some reports about the decision of the New South Wales government to privatise electricity generation in that state. I note that the premier of New South Wales had something to say about that at the weekend to a country council meeting of the ALP. This is despite the fact that before the last election the ALP in New South Wales swore on a stack of ALP policy platform documents that they would never sell the power generation industry in that state.
—Like the Commonwealth Bank.

—But that is the sort of performance you expect from Labor these days. It is exactly the same sort of performance that we see consistently here in Canberra from federal Labor. We all know that federal Labor indicated on numerous occasions that they would never sell the Commonwealth Bank and never sell Qantas. Of course, as soon as the left wing turned their back, very quickly the dominant right wing snuck it through and away they went selling off Qantas and the CBA.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very obvious in recent times that the only thing Labor federally stands for these days is inconsistency. They oppose every step we take, something the New South Wales Labor government has now woken up to. Every time, we examine a government enterprise and determine what is the core government business, we examine government businesses and say, `What is the best use of scarce public capital?' We look at the most effective and efficient way to deliver services to the Australian people. It seems that the premier of New South Wales and the ALP in that state have recognised that those are the questions that should be asked.

Bob Carr at the weekend, when he spoke to these people out there in Bathurst—the member for Banks was there; I presume that, as the premier spread his vitriol, the member for Banks was one of those booing in the audience—said, `It's not a debate about dogma.' Well, we agree. It is not a debate about dogma. He went on to say, `It's about where government funds can be spent most effectively.' We agree with that, too. Clearly, the federal level of the ALP is totally out of touch.

This Leader of the Opposition is clearly leading new old Labor. They have gone back to the 1980s, before they snuck through their privatisation in the early 1990s. I understand from the paper this morning that the opposition leader is involved in a crisis of management. Whether they wanted to jump over the member for Melbourne last week or not, I don't know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he?

—I do not know. And where is the member for Werriwa? Obviously those bringing intellectual debate into the ALP these days are not allowed into the parliament. Whether he wanted to jump all over them or not, I don't know. What did we see last week?
—Minister, you are digressing too far from the question.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. What we saw last week on the question of privatisation, unlike the premier of New South Wales and the ALP in New South Wales, was federal Labor opposing AN—despite what the workers wanted, despite what was good for the industry, despite what gave a future to rail in South Australia and Tasmania. Here we see this party in Canberra, which previously supported privatisation, do a backflip again, just as they did a backflip—we have seen this in this House this afternoon—on the question of compensation, on the question of cultural genocide, in terms of what was the position of the government previously in that particular case. We see them going backwards on the question of AN.

ANSWER.PARA: Every government in the world these days recognises that there are scarce public resources. They ask the questions as we ask them. Countries like Poland are privatising. All countries are doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Poland?
—Well, Poland is capable of doing it but not federal Labor. The only country in the world that is now aligned with Labor on the question of privatisation is North Korea.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his remarks yesterday about the Kruger case in which he failed to mention that the previous government's submission had indicated its willingness to consider extralegal compensation. Is the Prime Minister saying that if you cannot deal with the issue legally you do not deal with it at all?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I find these contorted attempts by the Leader of the Opposition to explain away his consistency quite extraordinary. If I were the Leader of the Opposition, I would get off this. As he has persisted, let me correct something the Leader of the Opposition said.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not had the opportunity of perusing the covering document, but when you asked me your first question about this document you asked why I did not draw attention to paragraph 1.6.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Well, I did. The covering note has the title `June 1997: Memo' and the heading is `Labor government position on the removal of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children'. It talks about the cases, then in bold type says `the Labor government vigorously defended the claims' and then lists the issues. Then it attaches the whole document, which had been distributed.

ANSWER.PARA: It says, `The following are references from the Labor government's submission', and then it lists them. The very first one states, `General position, chapter 1 at pages 2 to 4. See paragraphs 1.3, 1.5 and 1.6'. Apart from providing a garrulous glossary of terms, in the time available what more can we do? We put the whole document out and we bring your attention to paragraph 1.6. And this is meant to be your knockout point?

I can just imagine the conversation when they knew this document was coming out. The Leader of the Opposition would have said, `Let's seek refuge in 1.6,' and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would have said, `Let's pretend we knew nothing about it. That'll be safer.' I can just imagine that that would have been the attitude.

This is a very simple case of consistency. If you are to have any credibility on these things, you have to be consistent. You cannot scale the heights of moral unction, as the Leader of the Opposition did last week, you cannot shamefully politicise a delicate issue, as the Leader of the Opposition did last week, and you cannot allow your frontbenchers to run around making inflammatory remarks about the tolerance credentials of members of the government parties and then when it comes to the crunch be found out as having argued in government the self-same position we have taken.

We now have the tabling of this document and the knowledge that, even after they had done a cut and paste job on the terms of reference, which they did in August 1995, in November 1995 they were going into the High Court through their lawyers under the instructions of the cabinet, under the instructions of the then Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch. It was not a lawyer's frolic, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would love us to believe. You cannot run that horse, Gareth. That will fall at the first hurdle, and every person in this House knows that.

BREAK.PARA: You were in there in November 1995 saying, `No compensation.' You were arguing against the proposition of intergenerational responsibility. You were justifying these practices on the grounds that they were sanctioned by law and that they were designed at the time to assist the people whom they affected. That is the very argument that I have used. That is the very argument which is relevant to so much of what has gone on in relation to this issue over the past few days.

I want to take the opportunity to say in relation to the government's response to the report that the government will respond very speedily to this report. I have read all of the recommendations and I have read very substantial sections of the report. Let me say, without in any way pre-empting the response, that there are many things contained in the recommendations in that report that I believe all members of this parliament will want to implement and will want to implement very speedily.

I have already expressed, as many others have, my deep sorrow about injustices suffered by Aboriginal Australians under the policies and practices of earlier generations. I know that these feelings of sorrow, regret and, indeed, sadness are shared by most Australians. My government does not support a formal national apology. It believes that to do so is to indicate in some way that present generations of Australians are responsible and can be held accountable for the errors, wrongs and misdeeds of earlier generations.

Apologising for something clearly implies some direct personal responsibility. An unwillingness to deliver a formal apology in no way connotes insensitivity or lack of sympathy. Rather, it is a statement of the obvious. Present generations of Australians are not responsible for the errors of earlier generations, particularly when the act involved was sanctioned by law and believed at the time to be for the benefit of the people affected. Indeed—and this is relevant to the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition—that was the basis of the Keating government's submission in November 1995.

That was the very basis, the cornerstone, the essence of the submission of the Keating government in November 1995; a submission that the Leader of the Opposition was perfectly happy, along with his deputy, to embrace when they were in government. Now for cheap, opportunistic political purposes in opposition they are taking a difference stance. They argued then that the practices which were the subject of that case had been for the protection and preservation of the persons of the Aboriginal race and must be considered by the standards and perceptions of that time, not by reference to contemporary standards.

They were not my words; they were the words of Beazley, Keating and Evans in November 1995, and no amount of verbal gyration and gymnastics by the Leader of the Opposition or the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who pretends that he was not at the crucial cabinet meeting, can alter the fact that you have been utterly inconsistent, utterly hypocritical and 100 per cent caught out for your duplicity on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Could the minister advise the House about the ongoing concern and uncertainty of Australian National rail workers because of the Labor Party's continuing threats to block the sale of Australian National?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question. He has been keeping in touch with workers at AN over their future. Last week I drew to the attention of the House that the Labor Party in opposition had decided to oppose the sale of AN and to try to block it through its passage in the parliament. In the process last week I drew to the attention of the House the views of workers at AN's workshop at Port Augusta. I read from a letter that was written by those AN workers. I will requote that letter:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . we wish to advise you of the support of the majority of employees within the Port Augusta Workshops of the action being taken by the Government to sell the business activities of Australian National.

Last week it was quite clear that AN workers are opposed to the Labor Party's decision to block the sale of AN and indeed support this government's decision to put AN up for sale to give it a new future, to give it a new capital injection and to give it new management and direction.
I am also advised that since then the member for Adelaide has received some 18 letters from AN workers at Islington workshops in Adelaide. One of those letters states:

It is my belief that AN should be sold because we, the employees, are sick and tired of being in limbo. Labor started the demise of AN with the introduction of the National Rail Corporation and are now extending the agony by blocking the sale of AN in the Senate. I believe it is our only hope for some sort of future in the industry.

Here you have workers from both Port Augusta and Islington workshops—one might say the bulk of workers of AN—who strongly stand for the government's policy of selling AN and who are strongly opposed to the Labor Party's policy of trying to block the sale of AN.

What this shows us is just how out of touch and how arrogant this Labor opposition has become since they lost government some 15 months ago. This is the same Labor Party which in government privatised the Commonwealth Bank, Australian Airlines and Qantas Airlines—indeed their brothers in New South Wales now want to privatise the electricity business of New South Wales.

The same people in government who were willing to privatise whatever they could get their hands on now in opposition have done a complete and utter backflip and have opposed the privatisation of an organisation such as AN; an organisation made up of a work force who actually want this privatisation to go through.

I am also in receipt of letters that have been written to the Leader of the Opposition and the Labor spokesman on transport, the member for Melbourne, written by AN workers on Friday of last week. The letters to the Leader of the Opposition and the spokesman on transport, the member for Melbourne, who is not here today, say that the work force is concerned—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is writing another policy.

—He is writing another policy; indeed, he is no doubt plotting the downfall of the Leader of the Opposition. The letter says, `The work force is concerned about your persistence in blocking the sale of Australian National. We are now requesting that you also visit Port Augusta as a matter of urgency.' What you have here is a clear demonstration of will of those people who work for AN, whose futures depend on the future of AN and the rail industry of Australia, totally opposed to the Labor Party, now in opposition. What you have here is a clear demonstration of a Labor Party in government doing one thing and a Labor Party in opposition being totally opportunistic and doing precisely the opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: The workers at AN know when they are being given hypocrisy and when they are being misled. The people of Australia realise that as well. I urge the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Melbourne to go down to South Australia, speak to the people at the coalface and find out how opposed they are to your views in opposition and how they support our views in government of trying to give rail a real future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Will he confirm that appointments of Australian directors to bodies like the Asian Development Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the EBRD, have traditionally been made on the basis of advice from a Treasury selection committee following public advertisement? How can the Treasurer justify aborting that process in the case of former Senator Jim Short, whom he personally appointed—I repeat, whom he personally appointed—as executive director of the EBRD without any Treasury advice or recommendation and without Senator Short being an applicant for the position when advertised applications closed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the question.
—What about the economy?
—He does not ask questions about the economy any more. He takes an extreme interest in international appointments, does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—He loves them.
—He particularly takes extreme interest in those positions which are tax free.

ANSWER.PARA: I knew that there would be a question about this because Senator Nick Sherry issued a press release on the issue a short time ago. As I have previously illustrated to the House, Senator Sherry calls the shots on key issues in this portfolio. It was Senator Sherry who called the shots on the superannuation surcharge. When you voted for it here, Senator Sherry voted against it in the Senate. This is just another illustration of an opposition that talks with a forked tongue.

Let me make clear, as I did, how this appointment was made. The government called for expressions of interest. I decided who was the best candidate, and the best candidate was Senator Short. Senator Short's recommendation was signed off by the Australian cabinet. What a shocking thing to do! Fancy the Australian cabinet making a decision. What is more, we can even remember the decisions we make. You cannot remember whether if you were there, can you? We can remember who was there. The whole Australian cabinet was there and the whole Australian cabinet signed off on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very good decision.

—Yes, it was a very good decision and he was unquestionably the most qualified person for the position. Who was in the Australian cabinet when Neal Blewett went to London as High Commissioner? Who was in the Australian cabinet when Kerry Sibraa went off to Zimbabwe? There is ominous silence, Mr Speaker. Perhaps you were not present at that one either, deputy leader. The deputy leader would have you believe that the cabinet had nothing to do with the High Court submission. The lawyers are on their way to the High Court and a funny thing happened—they decided to deny compensation. Gee, we hadn't thought of that before, had we? You would presumably not leave that decision to the Australian cabinet? Of course you would not. Of course you decided in the cabinet what the position was. Of course the cabinet decides on the position of the High Commissioner. Of course the cabinet decides on the recommendations to the EBRD.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said before, the Treasurer takes responsibility for the Treasurer's decisions and, what is more, he makes them. The Treasury does not make decisions on senior appointments in this area. I make them. I looked at all of the applications. I considered Senator Short, and I am afraid to say that Senator Short was the best qualified. Why would you be surprised? Why would you think that somebody who had been a bureaucrat in the Treasury department would be more qualified than somebody who had been the Assistant Treasurer? Do you consider someone to be unfit for office while they are running the department?

He was the Assistant Treasurer, he had been a Treasury official and he had worked internationally. He was the best qualified person. What is more, we have a great deal of confidence in him. We neither intend to hand our responsibility over to the public servants in this area or in others, because that is what we get elected for. We get elected to make decisions and, what is more, we will go on making them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of any proposals that could lead to the closure of schools throughout Australia, in particular, in my electorate of Paterson? What is the Commonwealth government's response to these proposals? What measures has the Commonwealth government undertaken to expand educational opportunities for all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Paterson for his question. I know how committed he is to educational opportunities for young people in his electorate. A very sharp contrast has now opened up between the government and the Labor Party on the future of schools in Australia and, in particular, on educational choice.

ANSWER.PARA: The Labor Party's policies have always been, as we know, to restrict educational choice. We now have those policies very clearly set out for the new Labor Party by the absent member for Werriwa in an address he gave recently to the Public Policy Centre at Melbourne University. I see the member is absent today, Mr Speaker.
It is obvious that the young braves are getting restless, as Glenn Milne pointed out this morning. They are becoming increasingly frustrated. As Glenn Milne tells us:
Not to put too fine a point on it, Crean and Evans's egos are seen to be dominating who gets to ask what questions of the Government.
It may be that the member for Werriwa is not here because he has not been able to ask a question recently. The member for Werriwa, in his speech `School education in the new economy'‐
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise in the chamber.

—The member for Werriwa has stated the Labor Party's new policies on school choice, and I think it is important that all members in the House hear the words that the member for Werriwa has used. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The ALP maintains a minimum enrolment benchmark of 50 students. This represents not only an effective economy of scale in school administration, but also a useful threshold of popular support and commitment to the representative features of neighbourhood schooling.

What this means is that schools with less than 50 pupils could be forced to close by the Labor Party removing Commonwealth funding. It raises the question about whether there is in fact already a hit list of these schools.

We have done some investigation of this and I wonder whether the member for Werriwa told, for example, the member for Dobell that two schools in his electorate, Wyong Creek and Dooralong primary schools, might be closed because of this policy. I wonder whether he hold the member for Hunter that his policy, if applied, would mean the closure of Broke, Congewai, Jerry Plains, Laguna, Martindale, Milbrodale, Millfield, Moonan Flat, Mount Parry, Rouchel, Sandy Hollow, Walhallow, Willow Tree, Wollombi, Belltrees and Kirkton primary schools. These 16 schools in the member for Hunter's electorate could be closed under the policy enunciated by the member for Werriwa.

Let me say I think it is obviously a good thing when members of the opposition are thinking up policies and putting forward new ideas. We learn from Glenn Milne's article this morning that there is a view in the ALP caucus that the former ministers of the Keating government have now been caught out and are old-fashioned and locked into an old paradigm, and certain people are determined to break out of this. As a member of the caucus said:
Their life experience—
he is referring to the member for Holt, and the member for Hotham perhaps—
a decade of running the country—means they're washed out of new ideas.
He said:
The old orthodoxy is ready to be replaced.
The Leader of the Opposition might well wonder where they are today. There is obviously something going on out there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: if the Minister for Finance was digressing before and you called him to attention, surely the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training must be digressing now. I would ask you to bring him back to the point of his answer.
—I thank the honourable member for Hotham. I am sure the minister took cognisance of the comments I made earlier today, and I ask him not to digress.

—Indeed, Mr Speaker. I was referring to the attitude of the member for Werriwa to new ideas and the desperate need for them on the other side of the House. Of course, if this is the quality of the new ideas that are coming out of the Labor Party, it is obviously going to have serious problems as we go through the various electorates around the country still occupied by Labor members and list the schools that would be subject to closure under the policy of the member for Werriwa.

ANSWER.PARA: I challenge the Leader of the Opposition to come out and tell the Australian people now that he will have nothing to do with this nonsensical policy which has been put forward by the member for Werriwa. It is no good protecting him by refusing to allow him to ask me questions. Obviously, he does not like that. Come out and make it absolutely clear that the Labor Party's education policy has nothing to do with the nonsense being peddled by the member for Werriwa.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. With regard to Australian Audit report No. 21 1995-96, called The Meat Research Corporation Management of Fututech : in view of the overwhelming evidence of mismanagement, cronyism, collusion and possible fraud in committing the Commonwealth and levy payers' funds to a commercial contract that was known to be unachievable and which subsequently resulted in a substantial payout of MRC funds to Kilcoy Pastoral Company and BHP Engineering, will the government now, some 12 months after the tabling of the report, initiate a full parliamentary inquiry into the issues raised by the levy payers and the ANAO. If this government is committed to supporting the rural sector as the Prime Minister has stated, will the government take action to examine fully the loss of some $40 million from an industry presently in crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. To the best of my knowledge, there was no criminal intent and it has to be said that from time to time research results in the expenditure of very considerable amounts of money and fairly poor results or disappointing results arising therefrom.

ANSWER.PARA: I will undertake to examine again, in consultation with a couple of my colleagues who have been involved more recently in looking at this matter, the issues that the honourable member has raised and get back to him in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Minister, you would obviously share my concern about the ongoing tragedy of youth suicide in Australia.
—Move quickly to the question.

—The minister would be aware that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs today tabled its summary report on a seminar, entitled Aspects of yout h suicide . Would the minister outline to the House recent government initiatives which seek to help young Australians at such crisis points in their young lives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Fisher for his question. I would also like to commend him and his committee for the tremendous work they have done in highlighting what is an immense problem in the community and for the tabling of the report today which arises from the seminar on youth suicide.

ANSWER.PARA: Along with many Australians and, I believe, many in this House, I am deeply saddened and distressed by the very high rate of suicide amongst our young people in Australia today. It is a rate that is the fifth highest in comparable industrialised countries today and there has sadly been a trend of increasing rates of youth suicide in Australia from 1984 to 1992. This is particularly marked for young men, and particularly for young men in rural communities. The deaths of young men from suicide have increased in the 15 to 24 age group from 258 in 1985 to 350 in 1995. It is indeed a tragedy.

We must continue to ask questions as to why this is happening in our country today and explore the best way we can help our young people and support the families and communities whose lives are touched by this tragedy. We are committed to addressing the issue because of the tragic consequences in people's lives. It is not a single issue problem; a series of complex questions that needs to be asked in relation to this.

BREAK.PARA: The federal government, since taking office, has already taken a leadership role in addressing and trying to prevent the problem of youth suicide in our community. We have allocated $31 million in total to prevention programs, and this goes to very practical support programs such as the kids help line and the Lifeline programs. We know that many young people, when they are contemplating suicide, telephone those agencies as their first point of contact because they can remain anonymous in so doing. I was pleased to launch the new Lifeline youth line service, which is available to young people wherever they are in Australia for the cost of a local calling.

In addition to improving funding for the help lines and the lifelines, we have also enhanced youth counselling services in recognition of the particular problem in rural Australia. We have also put into place support programs that will guide and assist parents to recognise the symptoms in their young people and to support and help them with their grief after someone in their family has committed suicide. We have placed a great deal of emphasis on putting in place protocols to help our health professionals, including our medical profession and indeed hospitals, so that they understand more about the problem in the community, the symptoms and how they can assist. In addition to that, we are working with the media to develop a media code.

We have continued to place some emphasis on research, particularly research into childhood mental health, with a focus on identifying and addressing long-term causal factors which lead to adolescent suicide and attempted suicide. I believe that the money we have allocated to support these initiatives and that particularly target young people at risk of suicide will go some of the way towards addressing the problem. As I said, the causes of youth suicide are complex and it is a problem that we need to work together on as a whole community with government if we are to reduce the rate of suicide in our community.

I urge young people all over Australia, if they are feeling lonely and they are feeling distressed, to please pick up the phone and access the services that are available. That service through Lifeline, the youth line, is available to all young people, no matter where they are in the country, for the cost of a local call. We hope that they take advantage of that. Mr Speaker, I would like today to encourage all of us in this place to work with our communities, to be vigilant and to be supportive of the work out there so that we might help to reduce the rate of suicide in our country today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, are you aware of statements made by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, in the parliament last Friday, in the debate about the employment services bill, in which she said, `It is against the state law to charge an employee for employment placement services'? Prime Minister, isn't it the case that in the minister's home state the law says that a job seeker can be charged a deposit and that deposit can be applied towards a fee? Has the minister misled parliament and contravened your ministerial code of conduct?
—Mr Speaker, I have no information in my possession which suggests that she has. But I will analyse the honourable member's question. If I have anything to add, I will.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neville, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. As the minister would be aware, in contrast to the policy of aggressive centralisation pursued by the previous government, the key feature of the coalition's industrial relations policy has been the pursuit of harmonisation between the federal and state jurisdictions.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will move quickly to his question.
—Indeed I am, Mr Speaker. Can the minister inform the House of the outcome of last Friday's Labour Ministers Council meeting held in Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He is quite right to point to, as he did in his prefatory remarks, the lack of cooperation and the division that used to rack these Labour Ministers Council meetings under the previous administration. I suppose the high point of that was when the former Labor government ratified the unfair dismissal convention and used that as a means of overriding the state schemes.

ANSWER.PARA: In contrast, the ministers responsible for industrial relations, otherwise known as the labour ministers, did attend the meeting on Friday, including the relevant minister from New South Wales. It was well attended. The meeting was marked by a particularly cooperative attitude to some of the very important issues that we are approaching. There are a number of those. Firstly, we have agreed to really push on with this concept of harmonising the systems, and that is basically to make the systems easier for people to operate. By making them easier to operate, you can lower the cost for business and that gives business the wherewithal to improve its productivity to ultimately give more people jobs. So lowering the costs of the system is very important.

We also agreed to take steps towards a national approach in respect of industrial relations practices in the building and construction industry. This is also especially important because, as most honourable members would be aware, we do have some practices in the building industry which are in breach of good standards. For example, too often still on building sites today we see instances of compulsory unionism. That is in breach of freedom of association provisions in federal law and in various state laws and we now have a means by which we can deal with that on a cooperative basis nationally. The industrial relations elements of a national building construction code will be incorporated in a code at the construction council ministers meeting in August.

We also came to a common view about certain aspects of workers compensation. For example, we are looking at and encouraging the idea of mutual recognition which, for big national companies operating in more than one jurisdiction, holds out the prospect of simplifying the system, ultimately thereby lowering costs and also paving the way to more jobs through higher efficiency.

Lastly, we had a general and agreed view in respect of the conduct of wages policy and in this instance the ministers were speaking on behalf of their respective governments as important employers in the labour market.

Compared with the days of division and lack of cooperation, I am very pleased to be able to report to the House that we had a very constructive meeting and we are working on a lot of practical benefits for the business community which, ultimately, will provide benefits to small business, big business and, most importantly, to employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to reports that the government plans to cut automotive tariffs to below 15 per cent in response to the Productivity Commission report received last week. Prime Minister, will you rule out reducing the tariff to five per cent by 2005?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Productivity Commission report will receive very early and prompt consideration by the government. Obviously, as a decision is likely to be announced fairly soon—I do not mean today—let me say to the honourable gentleman that it would plainly be foolish of me to start ruling particular responses in or out.
—Where's the consistency?

—Is Simon Crean consistent on tariffs? Ah, yes! According to the words of the absent member, the absent friend from Melbourne, Simon wants to make a trip down memory lane arm in arm with the member for Oxley.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I asked a very specific question of the Prime Minister. It was not a question asking him to dissertate on the honourable member for Hotham's view on tariffs. It specifically asked: will you rule out reducing the tariff to five per cent by the year 2005?
—I thank the honourable member for Corio. I am sure the Prime Minister is addressing that question.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the member now takes a point of order on the Prime Minister. His question asked the government to announce policy on a sensitive issue, which is contrary to the standing orders.
—I thank the member for O'Connor. I am well aware what the question was. I call upon the Prime Minister to answer it.

—The government, in reaching the decision on this very important matter, will take into account all of the factors that I have previously acknowledged are important: the maintenance of a viable motor manufacturing industry in Australia; the importance of this country reaping the benefit of trade liberalisation which is occurring within the Asia‐Pacific region; and also, of course, the employment consequences. As the honourable gentleman knows—and as those who strive for consistency and a sensible policy outcome in this area will know—trying to harmonise those three goals and producing an outcome that promotes them is tremendously important. You will not win any marks, you will not save any jobs and you will not win any export markets in this area by engaging in the cheap populism which is being engaged in on this issue by a number of members on the other side and by a number of those who sit independently on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: We will make, I believe, a balanced decision. It will be a decision which is very much in the national interest and will reflect a continuity of policy. We will not be engaging in the flip‐floppery of the member for Hotham. It really has to take the cake for a gauche interjection—Simon Crean on consistency in the middle of a question on tariffs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Given that 43 per cent of the total work force are women and 57.5 per cent of those women work full‐time, would the minister advise how the government is assisting families like those in my electorate of McEwen, where 40 per cent of the work force are women, to blend work and family responsibilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for McEwen for her question because the truth of the matter is that one of the really important things we have had to deal with in industrial relations reform is trying to modernise the system to make it relevant to people who are in the system today. I think it is a fair generalisation to say that the trouble with the system which we inherited is that, basically, it was a system run by blokes for blokes.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the reasons for the casualisation of the work force, particularly as it impacted on women, was that people were essentially offering only casual work to women because of the unfair dismissal system. Another one of the reasons why we have seen an explosion in casual employment is that the opportunities for regular part-time work were in effect barred in so many awards. That is why we legislated to remove those bars—so that people have a real choice as to whether or not they have regular part-time work or casual work.

We are seeing some positive developments. We actually put in as an objective of this legislation that it assist families to better match their work and family responsibilities. If you look at the legislation, in addition to the part-time provisions I have just referred to, we have also made the agreement making processes much easier. The reason that is important in a practical way, particularly for women, is that it gives them a chance to actually have an agreement that suits their own circumstances, trying to pick up and match their time requirements, particularly in terms of dealing with children. So we have got the objects in the act and we have got a series of changes in the act, all of which are aimed to modernise the system to make it easier for people to balance work and family responsibilities.

We have gone one step further. We have a series of practical measures in addition to the legislation aimed at reinforcing the point. So, for example, we have these work and family awards, which I was recently associated with.
