The Australian Financial Review did a very good job of giving people case studies so that people in our businesses could see how others are doing it and how it can be very good for both the business and for the people in their employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you talking to the advisers' box?
—We cannot hear you.

—I am pleased that you are listening and learning for a change. We are also going to have a range of brochures and information. We have maintained funding for the working women centres, which also are part of the apparatus to provide protections for women at work, in addition to the anti‐discrimination provisions of the legislation and the maintenance of key conditions in allowable matters. So it is a very important issue; we are dealing with it on a broad range of fronts. I thank the member for her interest.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. It follows very logically from that one. I refer the Prime Minister to the case of Davis v. Portseal Pty Ltd, a decision of the Full Court of the Industrial Relations Court. The employee in question was sacked for failing to implement an instruction to dismiss another employee simply because she was pregnant. The court found that the employee had been unfairly dismissed. Why won't you abandon your proposal to deny future employees in this situation protection against unfair dismissal?

—As I have said in answer to other questions that were put to me last week, I will avail myself of the opportunity of examining in full the details of particular cases. I have been in this place long enough not to rely on explanations of cases put by members at question time. I remind the honourable member that none of the proposals in relation to the unfair dismissal law that are being put forward by me or by the Minister for Industrial Relations in any way takes out of the act prohibitions against certain unlawful terminations. For example, section 170CK prohibits dismissal for a number of reasons which are outlined in the section.

BREAK.PARA: Honourable members opposite should understand the distinction between an unlawful termination and an unfair dismissal. I think the work force understands that difference and, most importantly, the men and women in small business understand that difference, because it is they who are complaining that, even though the act now is a lot better than it was, it is still a long way short of the sort of act that would be desirable in order to make it more attractive. For example, even Mr Bastion of the small business association, who does not always praise the coalition when he makes a press statement—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or us. Too right!

—`Too right,' says the member for Cunningham. In other words, you think he is a pretty reliable witness on this, don't you? Do you know what he had to say about our unfair dismissal regulation? He said that it was the jewel in the crown. So the bloke who you think is all right on this subject thinks that what you are trying to knock off is the jewel in the crown of our proposals.

BREAK.PARA: Let me continue. The Workplace Relations Act retains, despite any changes that might be made in the unfair dismissal law, a widespread number of prohibitions on such things as temporary absence from work because of illness or injury, union membership or non‐membership, seeking office or acting as a representative employee, filing of a complaint of participation, alleged violation of laws in recourse to competent administrative authorities, race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibility, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin.

The reality is that there will remain in the legislation—even if the unfair dismissal exemption is extended—a widespread number of prohibitions on unlawful termination. Once again, like the member for Jagajaga, the member for Canberra is running around trying to scare people. He equally ought to be ashamed of himself.
Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—The Prime Minister said in question time today that I said to him at one point in our private conversation last week, `Don't worry about Melham.' That misrepresents both the content and the flavour of that private conversation, as the Prime Minister well knows. What I said to him, as I recall it, was along the following lines: `I know Daryl's been upsetting you lately. But don't worry about him, worry about the issues. Worry about trying to find a way through this that gives us some legal certainty, that meets everyone's real concerns and that avoids sending us down a path of a race based election.'
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is to show clearly where he has been misrepresented.

—Mr Speaker, what the Prime Minister said in question time today gives me no confidence whatsoever that it will be possible to have serious and constructive discussions between the government and the opposition, let alone confidential ones.
—We are not here to debate the issue. Resume your seat.
—That should be a matter of disappointment, not only to me and the opposition but to all the relevant interest groups and the wider Australian community.

—My question is to you, Mr Speaker. Under standing order 150, I would ask that you write to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development on questions 1229 and 1240 standing in my name addressed to them that have been on the Notice Paper since 4 February.
—I thank the honourable for Prospect. I will write to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development on your behalf this afternoon.
—Mr Speaker, last week you tabled documentations on members' travel allowance claims over the last few years. Could you bring back to the House the cost of preparing that documentation?
—I thank the honourable for Watson. I will take the question on notice and report back to the House a little later this week.

—Mr Speaker, given the enormous power inherent in your august position, will you use your authority for the third time and ask the Prime Minister to answer the question I asked without notice in March? On three occasions you have said you would.
—I have. I will take the matter up with the Prime Minister's office again. I thank the honourable for Kalgoorlie.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Gash, Joanna, MP; Griffin, Alan, MP; Howard, John, MP; Taylor, Bill, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Gash(from five citizens), Mr Griffin(from 18 citizens), Mr Howard(from 314 citizens)and Mr Taylor(from 20 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Latham, Mark, MP; McClelland, Robert, MP; Morris, Peter, MP; Price, Roger, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Sydney calls to the attention of the house that the proposal to allow nursing homes to charge an entry free or bond discriminates against the most vulnerable frail and sick members of our community.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House forthwith abandon such proposals to permit the introduction of nursing home entry fees and to immediately restore full funding for capital assistance to nursing homes.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Latham(from 28 citizens)Mr McClelland(from 2,555 citizens)Mr Peter Morris(from 44 citizens)and Mr Price(from 476 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Pastoral Leases
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This petition by owners of freehold and leasehold land in all states of Australia requests the House to ensure that legislation is passed ensuring that:‐

The granting of pastoral lease, or equivalent, and the granting of freeholding rights to leasehold land will automatically extinguish Native Title to any such land in all States and Territories of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Laws
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in the parliament:

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Lilley draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that the repeal of Section 120(1)(c) of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 will increase pressure on the Golden Circle Fruit and Vegetable Cannery at Northgate Queensland to re‐locate off‐shore and will expose the industry to multinational predatory tactics.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to reconsider the decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales hereby expresses their dismay at the proposal to charge entry fees for people needing nursing home care. Furthermore, the petitioners are extremely concerned that the charging of entry fees will force people to sell their house in order to gain a bed in a nursing home.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives act to ensure that nursing home care is available to all who need it and further that the family home is exempted from any asset test relating to payment for such care.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home and Community Care Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House that:

1. Funding cuts to the Home and Community Care Program, which covers services such as Meals on Wheels, Community Transport, Home Maintenance Programs and home help services, will severely disadvantage elderly and disabled people;
2. these funding cuts will result in poorer quality of life for these disadvantaged people;
3. and is in breach of an election promise by the Coalition Government that the poor and needy would not be adversely affected by a Coalition Government.

Your petitioners therefore request the House that these funding cuts be immediately reversed and assurances given to the Home and Community Care Program providers that their future funding is guaranteed.

PETITION.TITLE: Ausmusic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Tasmania draws to the attention of the House that:
the Federal Coalition Government has completely withdrawn funding from Australia's contemporary music organisation—Ausmusic;
has ignored the findings of a 1994 Coopers and Lybrand report, which recommended Ausmusic be federally funded for a period of five years, in order that it become commercially viable;

and has placed in jeopardy the future of Ausmusic programs, including the annual Australian Music Day, Australian Music Education Week and industry courses which are offered at more than 1,200 schools, youth training centres, technical and further education colleges and universities.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to reverse the decision made by the Minister for Communications, the Hon Richard Alston, and reinstate full funding to Ausmusic as it provides valuable employment and export opportunities for young Australians.

PETITION.TITLE: Mobile Phone Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
For the safety of many rural Victorians, the Commonwealth Government hasten the introduction of better mobile phone services to Western Victoria.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House instruct the Minister to see that the safety of rural Victorians is no longer compromised by poor communications, and immediately install a better mobile phone service.
And your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament

The petition of certain citizens of Campbelltown and Liverpool draw the attention of the House to the fact that our suburbs and quality of life will be severely depleted by the construction of Holsworthy International Airport. Your petitioners therefore ask the House to immediately abandon any plan to construct an airport at Holsworthy.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House need for reforms in the Child Support Scheme. Your petitioners therefore ask the House to introduce and implement the following reforms:

1. That child support payments be calculated on the non‐custodial parent's (payer) net basic rate of pay, exclusive of all allowances, overtime and loading. Not on gross income as it is at present and the lowering of percentages.
2. Lowering of `the cut off points' as an incentive to continue in the workplace.
3. Child Support payments be calculated from the net income on a weekly, fortnightly or monthly basis.
4. The non‐custodial parent receives a reduction in the child support payment while he or she has the children for periods of time e.g. holidays.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: Belmont
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of certain electors of the Division of Shortland draws to the attention of the House that residents of the East Lake Macquarie area would suffer serious difficulty and inconvenience if the Belmont Medicare office is closed.
Your petitioners request the House to require the government to ensure that Belmont Medicare office remains open.

PETITION.TITLE: Cooked Chicken Meat
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House their concern at the proposal to import cooked chicken meat into Australia, particularly the risk of disease to the poultry industry and native bird population, and the economic impact this will have on the domestic industry. Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take such action as will ensure that there be no importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Racism
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain members of the Australian community affirms our commitment to a culturally diverse Australian society which is unified by a common desire to see all Australians, regardless of their race, ethnicity, religion, sex, age or ability treated with respect and dignity. We recognise the contribution that all Australians have made to the cultural, social and economic development of Australia and reject the views expressed by Pauline Hanson as divisive and not based on fact.

In recognition of the need to debate these issues honestly and publicly, we request the House to call upon the Federal Government to mount a high profile anti‐racism campaign (for which funds were provided in the 1996‐97 budget) and fulfil its obligations to build and maintain a harmonious and united Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecommunications Tower
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain residents of Roleystone in the Perth region of Western Australia draw to the attention of the House that the undersigned citizens are vehemently opposed to a further erosion of their democratic rights by the use of the Telecommunications Act 1991 and the Telecommunications National Code 1996 by the Vodafone company with the erection of a telecommunications tower in residential areas.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House takes notice of these concerns and takes all action possible to protect the rights of citizens who might be adversely affected by the erection of any proposed telecommunication tower.

PETITION.TITLE: Car Tariffs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The following employees of Cutler Brands Pty Ltd wish to express their concern over the proposed tariff reductions.

Over forty percent (40%) of our business is derived from the automotive industry and the requirements of the automotive industry are a major driver for continuous improvement and adoption of best practice.

Although major productivity improvements have been achieved under the current tariff policy, they are becoming harder and harder to find and further reductions in tariff will place intolerable burdens on our business and possibly lead to major contraction in business and employment.
Your petitioners therefore request that tariffs be frozen at current levels.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House that the decision to conduct an Environmental Impact Study (EIS) of Holsworthy as a possible site for Sydney's second airport is the cause of great distress and concern to the many residents that live in the surrounding suburbs.
Your petitioners pray that the House firmly oppose the construction of an airport at Holsworthy.

PETITION.TITLE: Circus Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that under the Quarantine (Animals) Regulations of the Quarantine Act 1908, approval is given for the importation of free ranging exotic animals such as lions, tigers, bears, elephants and non‐human primates to be used for entertainment purposes in circuses and mobile displays. The issue of circuses using animals is very complex and includes: Transportation of animals, where the animals are kept in tiny cages, often travelling in extremes of temperature over long periods; stressful training techniques, often based on fear, deprivation and brutality and often inhumane living conditions, which do not allow any display of instinctual behaviours. We also believe that inappropriate messages are put forward by forcing wild animals to perform circus tricks. It is certainly not consistent with the focus on environmental awareness for people, especially children to learn that it is acceptable to exploit wild animals for human entertainment. We therefore humbly ask that the House prohibit the importation of all animals including those listed under CITES (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species) for use in both international and Australian circuses. We ask this based upon the inhumane conditions that the animals are kept in, the conditions under which the animals are transported, the often cruel training procedures, and the inappropriate messages conveyed to children by forcing wild animals to perform circus tricks.

BREAK.PARA: Petitions received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House recognises:
(1) the grave extent of the heroin trade in south west Sydney and the shocking availability of the drug for purchase, especially on the streets of Cabramatta and Fairfield;
(2) the disastrous social problems currently being caused by the heroin trade in south west Sydney;
(3) that many of the dealers and addicts involved in the heroin trade in south west Sydney are teenagers, with some users as young as 11 and 12, and are having their lives ruined as a result;
(4) that the reckless discarding of used syringes in an improper manner is causing great distress and threatening the health of many families and small business people in south west Sydney; and

(5) that the trade and use of heroin in south western Sydney is moving rapidly from bad to worse and that government, at all levels, must look for better and more effective ways of combating what has become one of Australia's most serious social problems.

In October 1995 the ecstasy induced death of Sydney teenager, Anna Wood, drew an outpouring of public grief the likes of which is rarely seen in our society. Anna Wood was just 15. She was not by any definition of the term a drug addict, nor was she a veteran in the use of hard drugs. Barely a kilometre outside the boundary of my electorate in the suburb of Cabramatta, children as young as 11 and 12 are daily sitting in the frigid stairwells of car parks and the putrid stalls of public toilet blocks sticking used, dirty needles into their arms and injecting themselves with $30 hits of heroin.

These children, unlike Anna Wood, are addicts. The track marks in their arms indicate habitual heroin use. But where is the communal outcry that surrounded Anna Wood's tragic death? People are aware that Cabramatta is the centre of a thriving drug culture, but they are inured to the depth and the wretchedness of the tragedy that is being played out in these streets every day of the week. Meanwhile, the kids there just keep shooting up.

Quite obviously society, governments at all levels and of all political persuasions, parents and families have failed these children. At the same time it is quite obvious that, as far as drug availability is concerned, our war against drugs has been an equally disappointing fail ure. Heroin is more widely available now for the young people living in the electorates of Prospect, Fowler, Blaxland and Werriwa, just to name a few, than it has ever been.

It is well known that lying at the root of heroin abuse in south‐western Sydney in particular is the region's endemic unemployment problem. It is unemployment which leads to the family breakdown and social dislocation which pushes people towards seeking solace in drugs. It is unemployment which leads to the boredom and apathy among our young people which fosters their interest in experimenting with heroin.

Reducing unemployment would be a terrific start in combating south‐west Sydney's heroin plague, but what else can be done? It depends on whom you ask, and I think there lies our problem. As long as we remain so hopelessly divided in regard to reaching a solution on heroin, then improving our current circumstances will remain outside our grasp.

Today I want to again alert the national parliament, especially our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the members of his government, to the grave extent of the heroin trade in south‐western Sydney and, in particular, my area of Fairfield and Cabramatta. I do so with the hope that by raising my voice I will encourage a rethink from all levels of government and from both sides of politics about more effective ways of combating what has become an enormously devastating social problem in my area.

We have a cancer growing in south‐western Sydney. It is a cancer which is devouring the young and the innocent so rapidly and is causing such untold hardship and distress for hundreds of families that I believe it should be labelled a national emergency. It is definitely a disaster which is crying out for a solution from the highest level.

The people most often highlighted as driving Cabramatta's drug trade are those said to come from outside the area: young people making the trip into our community by rail on the now infamous `Cabramatta express'. But these people do not, by any means, provide the trade's driving force. About 50 per cent of the clients who use the needle syringe exchange program at Cabramatta Community Centre and the Outreach bus actually live in the Fairfield local government area. This is increasing as more local young people are caught up in the cycle of heroin abuse.

Dr Lisa Maher from the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre—NDARC—is a person whose experience I have drawn on and mentioned in this House before. As part of her research activities, in May last year Dr Maher interviewed 120 kids about their heroin use. Seventy-five per cent of these young people lived in south‐western Sydney, 33 per cent in Cabramatta itself. Outsiders they are not. Dr Maher has made another terrifying find about the heroin users in the area. She says:
The youngest I know of are 11 and 12. They're definitely the youngest addicts I've ever seen. But what really concerns me is the number of them. There must be several hundred.

These kids live in my electorate and in the electorates of other speakers in today's debate: the member for Fowler (Mr Grace), the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the member for Blaxland (Mr Hatton). Indeed, a recent survey of one of our local high schools revealed that 11 per cent of 13‐year‐old students had tried heroin. What a damning statistic to be recorded in our national parliament.

The spin-off effects of such a deep-seated heroin problem in our area is clear. We have a crime rate in south-western Sydney which is growing faster than we can allocate resources to fight it. The improper disposal of used syringes throughout my community is causing parents to tear their hair out in fear and frustration as their children pick their way to school across areas littered with hundreds of bloody syringes. Again I ask: what is to be done?

The first step towards nearing a solution is admitting to ourselves that our previous policies aimed at combating the heroin trade have quite obviously failed. Such an admission hurts but the fact is that, as long as there exists a demand for heroin in our community, it will be supplied.
The Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority concluded as far back as 1988:

BREAK.PARA: All the evidence shows, however, not only that our law enforcement agencies have not succeeded in preventing the supply of illicit drugs to Australian markets, but that it is unrealistic to expect them to do so.

It has been estimated that in New South Wales alone there are currently 61,000 people who regularly inject heroin. Death rates due to illicit drugs are increasing. It is also estimated that only 17 per cent of the heroin illegally entering this country of ours is seized. The cost to our economy of illicit drugs has been stated to be of the order of 0.5 per cent of the GDP.

But an admission of past failure does not mean we cannot make an improvement, perhaps a vast improvement, in the future. What is obvious is that we need new ideas. Is the most effective way of combating the heroin trade prescribing the drug to addicts? Or is it throwing even greater money and resources at the problem and escalating our war on drugs?

Time is against me dissecting the legalisation question in any great depth, but I would say that whatever new directions we take in relation to the trade of heroin and other illicit drugs we should decide upon them at a national level. That is why I call on the Prime Minister here today to convene a national drug summit featuring federal, state and territory health ministers, attorneys-general, police, judicial authorities, experts in the field of drug and heroin dependency and representatives from local government, social welfare and religious groups in order to discuss new approaches to illegal drugs and, in particular, to obtain a national solution to the heroin problem. It is only by taking a national approach on this issue that we can hope to bridge the divisions which exist on the different approaches open to us in combating illegal drugs.

If we can organise summits of premiers, chief ministers and police ministers to discuss national gun laws in the wake of the 35 people who lost their lives so tragically at Port Arthur then surely we can do the same, only on a larger scale, in order to develop new approaches for illegal drugs and for the heroin which is killing hundreds of people around this country each year. Of course, new directions are currently being sought by various state and territory governments and health authorities in relation to heroin and I acknowledge that. I congratulate the South West Sydney Area Health Service for establishing a needle disposal hotline which will enable residents to call a toll-free number and have health department staff pick up improperly disposed needles within 48 hours of them being reported.

At the same time, I suggest state public health authorities pick up the recent suggestion of the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) in this House regarding the provision of syringes, which are manufactured by the Victorian company Uni-Ject Australia, as part of their needle exchange programs. These particular syringes allow the needle point to be sucked back inside the syringe casing after use, thereby drastically reducing any chance of a needle stick injury. These are small but valuable steps towards alleviating the burdens of heroin abuse on our communities. But there are big steps yet to be taken and that is why I believe a national drug summit is essential.

In conclusion, I would like to say again to our Prime Minister and to the government: it is not an overdramatisation to label the situation that we face in south‐western Sydney as a national emergency. A national emergency requires a national solution. The old ways of fighting the heroin trade and heroin abuse have largely failed. Let us convene a national drug summit and let us take some new approaches towards combating heroin and other illegal drugs. To the Prime Minister and government and all members of this House I say that the young people and the families in my area are looking to you all for the leadership required to help remove the cancer which lies at our community's heart. Please do not let them down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this motion, because it is of serious interest and consequence to our society. It is not so much what we are doing about the drugs themselves as the actual harm that they are doing to individuals, to the community and to government resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The use of drugs affects the users, in terms of hepatitis C—and the numerous other forms of hepatitis that are being discovered every day—HIV, overdose, loss of employment, loss of self‐esteem, the breakdown of families, social isolation, dropping out of school and, ultimately, the stress and possible suicides that result from low self‐esteem from drug use. Then there is the harm to our community: the needles on the streets—already mentioned by the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio)—drug related crime, children dropping out of families, the pressure on the parents, siblings and children of users, the assaults that are drug related, the break and enters and the acquisitive crimes. The costs to the community and the harm done to the community are enormous.

Then there is government expenditure on policing, court action, legal aid, incarceration, Customs, the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, ambulance services, social welfare services, absenteeism from places of employment, health and public campaigns on HIV and hep C. The cost of this problem—which is acute in Cabramatta and Fairfield—is enormous. Perhaps the community needs to be innovative in its approach to this problem.

It is difficult for government to be labelled as doing nothing. We have done an enormous amount. The drug program coordination unit was established. With that came a number of education programs in New South Wales. Drug action teams were formed. Premier amongst those is the Fairfield drug action team. They are trying a number of strategies for the local area. They are looking at the local problem, the local suppliers and the local community—what works in that community. They are having a number of successes in that area. They have put in television surveillance in the area. They are still having minor problems in responding to incidents that are detected, but they are on the way down the path to something that may combat the problem.

There has been the Model Criminal Code. Again, that is a recent innovation. It was announced on Friday, and it is open for submissions until 31 August this year. We are trying to coordinate all the major drug offences nationally and come up with a national criminal code on this issue. It is important to target the suppliers of the drugs. It is a commercial activity, and each user relies on further users to supply his or her habit. Therefore, you have a recruitment program running. Our young people are targeted because the business relies on new users, so it is the very commercial aspect of this organised crime which needs to be combated. Often it seems bigger penalties for the user simply end at greater costs in prison and social welfare systems. We are moving in the right direction with the Model Criminal Code.

We also have the Health Insurance Commission. Over the next 3½ years $5.25 million will be spent to establish a number of specialist staff to address the issue of doctor shopping and, especially in the Cabramatta‐Fairfield areas, that has been targeted and statistics are being gathered. People who are seen to be visiting more than 15 doctors a year are being encouraged to change their behaviour. There is prosecution of people who are illegally using prescription drugs or abusing the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Furthermore, professional bodies are being encouraged to take action against any of the professional traders in the area who are abusing the system.

In March 1996, we also had a conference in Hobart on the reduction of drug related harm. There was a group from this Australian parliament interested in drug law reform, and a number of interesting recommendations came out of that. We are looking at success rates in the Netherlands and Switzerland, at what is happening in the Bronx, New York and around the world. We are monitoring what is happening in other parts of the world, and looking at possible avenues down which government in Australia can go.

On top of that, we are also looking at a further detox unit for Fairfield hospital. It is important that those sorts of measures are supported by the community. Quite frequently, when methadone clinics are inserted into a community, it is done in such a way that the drug related harm is even more extensive. You have a drop off in business and small businesses in an area, you have higher exposure to discarded syringes and a number of other social spin‐offs from that. We have to look at the way we are providing alternative support systems for drug users.

It is easy to throw the book at people and throw more money at a problem, but it is important—before we legislate for further money and a national summit to discuss the problem yet again—to get out into the small parts of the community and find out what is at issue. If unemployment is causing the drug problem, then perhaps work for the dole will be successful in those areas. Perhaps it is worth trialling a pilot program in that area. If it is drug use that is causing the unemployment, then we are back at the state we are in now of combating drug misuse problems.

The drug action teams are going a long way to dealing with the problem. They are involving the local social work teams, the local methadone suppliers, the local police, the local councillors. You are getting an organised, humane community response to the problem.

This is an enormous problem facing society. By and large, government can put legislation in place and provide finance. I would stop short of saying any previous attempts by government have failed. It is a recognised problem. This is not a problem that appeared in Fairfield and Cabramatta on 2 March 1996; it has been there since 1980.

It is hard to say whether $30 a cap or $390 a gram for the current street value of heroin indicates that there is a growth market. When I was working in probation and parole in 1986, that was about the street value of heroin at that time. It is probably keeping up with CPI. It also gives an indication as to supply and potential demand.

Again, we need to look at education and family support, at keeping the drug user within a family system, within a social system and within employment, and putting a lot of measures in place to support them through the lifetime of their habit. Most habits have a lifetime of about 10 years. If the drug addict survives—does not overdose or kill them selves—generally they seek to leave the habit themselves.

Drug addiction is not like work. You cannot take Saturdays and Sundays off. You cannot take a sickie. It does not matter if you have the flu. You must score. It is a full-time, seven‐days‐a‐week, 366‐days‐a‐year addiction. Generally, most people come to the conclusion over time that they will voluntarily remove themselves from that addiction or will take enormous strides to do so.

The important thing is that, when they reach that point in their personal life where they want to make that decision, they have the support networks in place to help them make it. It is probably a matter of carrying the addicts, doing further research, further refining programs already in place and making a very sympathetic and well‐funded contribution to this problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Ted, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes allowed for me to speak, I first would like to support the remarks of my colleague the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) calling for a national conference. While some of the remarks made by the previous speaker, the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), were no doubt of value, some of the things that she said were being done at present have been a complete failure.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to rush ahead and tell you of an hour I spent in my electorate of Fowler, which Cabramatta is part of, on Saturday. Assume that I am a new member and you have never heard me speak before. You heard the previous member refer to the price of a cap. I have with me a cap, which has probably never been seen in parliament before. Anybody who is interested in seeing one may come to my office. It has been fumigated so it is quite safe. Caps are sold on the market now for between $30 and $70.

The stupid thing about these caps and the law—I know my speech will get a bit convoluted because I have only five minutes to get about 80 hours of talk in—is that a person can carry 47 of these caps, which roughly contains 2.8 grams of heroin, and cannot be convicted of trading. That is how ridiculous our laws are. Just mark what I am saying to you: unless a person is caught in the act of exchanging money, they cannot be gaoled for trading in heroin, and they can carry just under three grams. That is how stupid it is.

On Saturday, in the company of two very prominent businessmen who demanded of me that I not name them here—that will tell you how serious it is—we visited an area in one block of flats. In the stairwell of two blocks of flats we counted 180 caps. I will not tell you how many needles we counted which obviously had been used within that morning, because you would not believe me.

On 17 May, which is only a fortnight ago, a collection of these businessmen and community leaders met in Cabramatta in secret because they were afraid to have their names divulged. They met as a result of the New South Wales Premier's statement, which was quoted by the member for Prospect, about heroin trading, particularly in Cabramatta, being a national disgrace.

In Cabramatta alone, 97 deaths have occurred since 1993, which is not a very great number of years ago. On one patrol, I had the very distasteful job of pulling out one of those drug addicts from under a stairwell. I go down there regularly. I want you to listen to what I am telling you as if you have never heard me speak about this before. The walk that I went on last Saturday was no more than 100 yards across two streets. That is the disgraceful situation that exists there.

It is all very well to say that we need money, but we need money for undercover police. It is no good dressing police up and putting them out on the street. It is completely useless. All these characters see them and they behave like normal human beings; cops go around the corner and they are back in business again. We need undercover police.

It is no good saying that we cannot afford them—we could afford 350 police to protect the `Oxleymoron' last Friday night. But we cannot send another 50 police under cover to Cabramatta. Our priorities are wrong. The law has to be wrong if you can carry these items with you and not be convicted as a dealer.

I respectfully take exception to the remarks of the member for Lindsay about 2 March. We are not blaming the present government at all. Forget about that. We are asking you to do something now. If I have to say that nobody else has done it, I will say it. We want your Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to immediately convene a national conference. That is all. All you can do is win. You cannot lose. We need it, and we need it urgently. I am here to plead on behalf of the business people and the community of Cabramatta. You mentioned the cost to the community. You are quite right, ambulances are tired of taking those people to hospital when they are needed elsewhere. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I find a great deal with which I can concur in the motion of the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). Certainly, the problems now being experienced in Cabramatta represent something that never before has been seen in a local Australian community. It is arguably one of our most spectacular failures in social, health and criminal law policy in the country. I think it is something approaching a national emergency. It probably would benefit from the direction of some national resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Prospect and, likewise, the member for Fowler (Mr Ted Grace) have talked about some of the local impacts, as did my colleague the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly). In south‐west Sydney, there were 44 deaths by heroin overdose in 1995, which was an increase of 120 per cent on the figure for 1992, which gives you some feeling for the escalation of the problem. Some 59 per cent of those fatalities took place in Cabramatta. Of those, 71 per cent occurred in public places, including 92 per cent of those who died in Cabramatta. Currently, there are about 35 cases a week of ambulance officers reviving and, hopefully, resuscitating those suffering from drug overdoses. So the drug overdose rate has increased by about 180 per cent since 1983.

To give you some idea of the grim realities, 50 per cent died in the street, nine per cent died in a public toilet and seven per cent died at a railway station. It is a situation that is accelerating at a grave rate and one in which, I think it is fair to say, our responses to date, whatever their logic, whatever their mix, are clearly not working or not working satisfactorily.

I note the member's motion calls for `more effective ways of combating what has become one of Australia's most serious social problems'. That, of course, is the great challenge. I personally have some reservations about the logic and practice of some aspects of harm minimisation, but I note, to be fair to my colleagues in the Labor Party both here and at the state level, harm minimisation is not an electorally popular course of action and it involves some political risk. There are many of my colleagues on this side of the House who would support it, such as the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), who is more expert than I and former head of the Australian Medical Association.

My concerns are largely mirrored by the Mayor of Fairfield, who has raised some deep concerns about the impact, for example, of needle distribution services. I note that one of the local child-care centres, the Fisher Street child‐care centre, has had to be shut down because needles have just been left around the place, out in playgrounds, and have exposed children to serious risk. I accept that that is part of the logic of a much more intensive needle distribution service on the basis that drug users can inject on site and dispose of needles without actually leaving the premises.

But I have to say that I still retain this, some might say, reactionary reflex which is reluctant to see governments give some form of sanction to a form of behaviour which has lethal consequences. So while I do not come to this motion in a sort of tub thumping, rhetorical way, I do, nonetheless, express this concern: I am reluctant to see governments give a sanction to what is a lethal habit.

The member for Lindsay mentioned what was happening in New York. There 1,200 officers have been dedicated to a key area. The member for Prospect talked about the focus on users and needing to move away to suppliers in the major drug rings. That is what they have done under Mayor Giuliani in New York. They have had a 20 per cent reduction in narcotics related offences. In my view, we need to continue a war on drugs. We ought not just give up, we ought not just accept that it is impossible and that it is here to stay, but we ought, as the member for Lindsay said, to seek to mobilise the whole community in an educational campaign.

I salute the efforts of Father Chris Riley from Youth Off the Streets, who is now running a basketball clinic in the heart of Cabramatta, and he is running a TAFE program to encourage literacy and numeracy skills. We have to take a whole of life approach to this. I believe that important steps are being taken in that direction. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) in relation to this motion on heroin trade. This is not a new problem. This is not a problem that has arisen on its own or sui generis in Cabramatta and in Fairfield. The problem of the use and abuse of heroin within Australia and the south‐west and western suburbs of Sydney is a very old one. This drug is devastating. It does not just go back to 1980. It was there in the 1970s. It was there in the 1960s.

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen person after person kill themselves through overdosing on heroin or electrocuting themselves after a period of five, 10 or more years using and abusing heroin and other substances. In the 1970s in my suburb of Bankstown, heroin use was in plague proportions. I have seen people that I went to school with die as a result of using heroin. I have seen people that I went to school with and know well go to gaol for 14 years as a result of being caught doing armed hold ups and robberies, and I have seen them spend those years in gaol, some to die there and others to come out and be rehabilitated. I have seen a state government attempt to grapple with the problems of heroin abuse.

I was directly involved a number of years ago in getting a tripling of funding for the methadone program in New South Wales at a time when a number of people thought that methadone use was almost as bad as the use of heroin, but it has proven over time to be one valid and sensible recourse to get people off heroin and its misuse and to bring them back into the community so that they do not all have to go to gaol, they do not all have to continue to destroy their very families and destroy their friends and acquaintances by bringing them into the circle of use. One individual basically needs 10 to 12 of their friends to support their habit. I have seen clusters of individuals destroy their lives and destroy the lives of their families.

Currently, the situation in Cabramatta, Fairfield and Bankstown in my electorate has become worse because of the increasingly ready availability of much purer heroin. We read in recent reports that the drug cartels in South America, having filled themselves up to capacity with the production of cocaine, have now moved to grow opium in Latin America and that opium is being sold in the United States. As a result of that, the South‐East Asian marketeers of opium and refined heroin are being locked out of the United States market, by and large, and are flooding Australia with relatively cheap product, product that is more powerful than what was available previously.

I do not think this is an easy problem to solve. It never has been and it never will be. It does not just go to the legislative constraints on people; it goes to the very question of people's behaviour and intent. I have seen generation after generation of young people in Bankstown falling into the use of illicit drugs, imperilling their lives and the lives, safety and health of their entire families and, in fact, destroying them utterly.

The member for Prospect is quite right—particularly in relation to the misuse of heroin in the last few years and its now much greater availability, greater strength and greater attraction for even larger numbers of school children in the south-west of Sydney—it is important now that we not just leave this matter to the states, that we not just leave it to the national drug offensive that we ran for a number of years but that we do call for a national summit to try to solve this problem on a national basis and look at overseas experience, as we have in the past, to drive towards a better, stronger and more sensible solution to a social problem that has ripped apart the fabric of this society for generations now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) for raising this important social issue in this House. The problem of the supply of heroin, particularly in the Cabramatta area, has much to do with a code of silence instilled through fear upon the respectable Cabramatta community by gangs of young males whose only fear is deportation.

SPEECH.PARA: Detection of large-scale suppliers is extremely difficult. Rather than give in to the criminal element and encourage other Cabramattas elsewhere, we must use every means at our disposal to develop more sophisticated techniques of detection. Why not introduce more police into the area and continually harass and arrest street dealers? We should move dealers away from the usual points of sale and make it more difficult for users to find their sellers. This worked in Sweden, and the cost factor must be far less than the suggested alternative of shooting up houses.

Along with the suggestion of establishing shooting up houses, an extension of the needle exchange program has also been suggested. However, 80 per cent of the users come from other areas and such initiatives must cause addicts to remain in, not depart, the area.

That used syringes are being discarded recklessly illustrates that addicts are not exchanging them. Further, a serious hepatitis C virus infection problem amongst intravenous drug users alone, about 6,000 new chronic infections per year, illustrates that addicts are still sharing needles, despite the needle exchange. It is recommended that intravenous drug users be encouraged not to use needles. The needle exchange program does the opposite.

Internationally, many countries are turning to rapid opioid detoxification as an answer to addiction. A pure opioid antagonist, such as naloxone or naltrexone, is administered while the addict is anaesthetised, thus avoiding painful withdrawal. The patient is then maintained on naltrexone which, together with psychotherapy, has yielded lengthy abstinence rates—for example, 80 per cent for six months and 67 per cent for nine months. It provides rapid, effective and painless detoxification which addicts do not have to fear.

In the United States, general anaesthesia can be carried out in a doctor's office or outpatient clinic. In the United States, the cost is about $2,500 per patient. Further post‐operative maintenance with naltrexone is much cheaper than methadone and is in tablet form. It is not a drug of abuse.

Rapid opioid detoxification is much cheaper than the estimated ongoing annual cost of $10,000 per addict per annum to supply legal heroin. The proposal to supply legal heroin to addicts in the ACT is not necessary and is itself fraught with danger. It has never been successful internationally. There are those addicts who wish to maintain their lifestyle and who will use as much as they can get. Legal supply must supplement illegal supply.

It has been suggested that we have 59,000 to 110,000 heroin addicts. If this program has any merit, we must look at maintaining a large proportion of that number. Of this we must add a continuing increasing population of addicts moving through from casual use. The cost factor will be prohibitive, as it was in Britain once the number of addicts exceeded 1,000.

We could well look to successful international programs such as in Sweden, where cannabis is regarded as a recruitment drug and massive education of its harms has resulted in reducing the population of heavy drug users. Rehabilitation programs can include rapid opioid detoxification. Addicts could be coerced into it through court direction or it could be provided as an alternative to serving out a sentence or as a condition of parole. The Cabramatta area, being the draw card it is because of the purity of heroin, could be targeted.

Harm reduction was introduced as our national policy at the national drug summit in 1985. It is a policy that promotes toleration of use by using responsible needle exchange and legal heroin programs. This has been shown to be a failure. It is highly promoted by the international legalisation movement and it is said by international drug experts to be one of the major reasons for permissive use. It is time we discarded it as a failure and in its stead devise a policy that gives a message of hope to the community and a loud warning that our governments will not tolerate drug use.

The fact is that since the adoption of harm reduction our problems have worsened; hence, the increased use of drugs. It is time that we shed them and adopted sensible and cost effective programs that will reduce use and help addicts shed their addiction, not maintain it, and assist, not hamper, our law enforcement policies to make effective their deterrent. It is time that we got fair dinkum in fighting drugs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) for bringing this motion before the House. She is bringing parliamentary attention to one of the leading public issues in her electorate—indeed, a leading issue throughout the Sydney metropolitan area. This is not an issue, however, that can be judged through racial stereotypes. The problem of drug trafficking affects all parts of our community. The victims and criminals alike, sadly enough, cross all forms of social and economic diversity.

SPEECH.PARA: In the community debate there is, naturally enough, a call for ever tougher laws and tougher penalties. Australians perceive few more heinous crimes than trafficking in heavy drugs, especially peddling them to our youth. Fair minded, decent citizens—parents who fear for the wellbeing of their children—want law enforcement which matches the scale of law violation. They want social penalties which match the scale of the crime against society.

This is an important debate and these are important points to make, but so too is our responsibility as parliamentarians to address the causes of crime. Without young Australians feeling the need to turn to drugs, there can be no drug trafficking. The social cancer of heroin trade, outlined by the member for Prospect, tells us that something has gone terribly wrong in our society. It tells us that our cohesiveness and strength as a society have eroded much too far.

The evidence of the recent New South Wales royal commission tells us that our social trust is diminished to the point where some of those employed to police our laws are more the law breakers than law enforcers. The sound, honest police now working in Cabramatta and Fairfield carry an even greater weight of public responsibility and social trust. Governments must find new ways to rebuild our basic sense of community and social connectedness. There is no more effective way for dealing with the causes of crime than this approach. So too we need to offer better pathways of trust and security for young Australians.

It is often said that this is an era of uncertainty and insecurity; a time when uncertainty abounds. The public debate about insecurity is too frequently directed away from young Australians and towards those of other generations. Yet now more than ever young Australians face the remorseless challenge of insecurity, the uncertainty of not knowing where changes to the education system are headed, the uncertainty of not knowing whether they will be able to find a job at the end of their time at school or training. We need to work on these things as parliamentarians to address the core causes of insecurity for our youth and to try to rebuild social trust and connectedness.

I think it is a good thing for our parliament to be exploring new penalties and new approaches to the problem of heavy drugs in our society. I understand in the United States there is a special penalty that applies under their laws for those who are caught trafficking heavy drugs in and around schools. I am advised that under the Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which Australia is party, there could be a head of responsibility for the federal parliament to enact such laws—that is, to send a very clear message to drug traffickers that there is no more heinous and unacceptable crime in our society than the trafficking of drugs in and around schools.

These are legitimate matters for our parliament to debate. The member for Prospect is to be commended for bringing them to our attention. As I hear from the speeches of the members for Hughes (Ms Vale), Blaxland (Mr Hatton) and Fowler (Mr Grace), this is an issue that spreads right throughout the south‐ west of Sydney. Our constituents want us to address these concerns in the national parliament, to explore means by which we address the causes of crime through new forms of social capital and trust and to explore the things we can do as parliamentarians to find an even more acute expression of the penalties that are needed to deter crime.

Whether it is acting on the Convention on the Rights of Children, whether it is following the precedent in the United States for enacting special laws on drug trafficking in and around schools or whether it is the call—as many members have made—for state and territory governments to enact even stronger penalties in this area, I believe we do good service to the parliament, as the member for Prospect does good service to her electorate, by raising this particular matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) for bringing this matter to the attention of the House. In support of the motion that is being debated this afternoon, I want to particularly support part 5; that is, `that governments at all levels must look for better and more effective ways of combating what has become one of Australia's most serious social problems'. I know that the focus is on the south‐western suburbs of Sydney in this debate, but it is a national problem and it is one that extends into regional Australia as well. In my electorate, it is also a very serious problem. The trading and use of heroin is not just confined to south‐western Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to highlight a very sad story of one of my constituents, Mrs Margaret McKay of Port Macquarie, who fought a long-running battle to save her son, David, who was addicted to heroin. It was a battle that she lost on 3 March this year when David died at the age of just 29 from a cocktail of legally prescribed drugs. While David's battle was lost, the war continues for Margaret and many others like her to try to find better alternatives for the rehabilitation of heroin users.

David McKay was born in Gundagai on 12 July 1967. At age six, David and his family moved to Port Macquarie, where he grew up and went to school. His mother, Margaret, describes her son as a young man who was loved by all who knew him and who had an incredible sense of humour and a keen, sharp wit. David could write fabulous poetry and was a talented musician. On leaving school, he went to St Joseph's Vocational College and secured a job with a local business. David started smoking marijuana when he was 12, and from there he was on a downward spiral to drug abuse and misuse.

David was on the methadone program three times. Each time his mother, Margaret, tried to get him off it. She describes the methadone program as a joke. This is a lady who has had first-hand experience over a number of years with all these programs to try to rehabilitate her son, and what she did achieve she did pretty well single‐handedly. She describes the methadone program as a joke, a commodity for addicts in what she says is a legal drug trade.

The first time David started on the methadone program, he was prescribed 40 millilitres per day. By the third and final time, he was up to 150 millilitres of methadone per day—this is a prescribed drug—plus up to 90 pills per day of various other prescription drugs such as Rohypnol, Rivotrel and Serepax. It was this lethal combination of drugs, not the heroin, that Margaret believes really killed her son and many other addicts.

She is highly critical of the ease with which her son was able to obtain prescriptions for a host of different drugs, sometimes with just a simple phone call to a doctor. At one stage she even wrote to every doctor in the town begging them not to write David any more prescriptions. She lobbied the AMA and State Health to stop the so-called legal trade of prescription drugs, which simply replaces a dependency on heroin with a dependency on other synthetic and potentially more lethal cocktails of prescribed drugs.

So what is the solution? There are differing views on tackling the heroin crisis. Margaret McKay has advocated the trial of a heroin program because she believes that the current system does not work—in fact, it makes things worse for drug addicts. Others, such as retired chemist and anti‐drug use campaigner John Malouf, points to the failures of such heroin trials overseas. Mr Malouf stated in an article in the Daily Telegraph on 23 May this year:
If heroin is legalised . . . it will only clarify the status of one drug and do nothing to prevent illegal dealing in amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine and whatever designer drugs are around the corner.
It will also turn governments into drug pushers.

I agree that the current system failed David McKay and continues to fail many others like him. I agree that more needs to be done and that alternative solutions need to be found. I agree that methadone and other drugs are just bandaid solutions. But I do stop short of endorsing heroin trials or legalising so-called `shooting galleries', as has been recommended in some reports that have been published recently.

I do believe that we can reach a middle ground. Heroin could and should only be used under controlled rehabilitation conditions—only in circumstances where an addict's dependency can be managed and brought down without recourse to other more harmful but legal drugs. The aim should be to get the addicts to kick the habit, but not by using harsher alternatives to heroin, such as methadone and other prescription drugs, as David McKay's 17‐year struggle with drugs would indicate. There must be a better way than what we have in this country at the moment. We must as a nation look at resolving this problem and reviewing the practices that are currently in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee be appointed to inquire into and report on the circumstances of the sinking of HMAS Sydney off the Western Australian coast on 19 November 1941, with particular reference to:
(a) the extent to which all available archival material has been fully investigated and whether any archival material has been misplaced or destroyed;
(b) all relevant archival material from allied and former enemy forces;
(c) any scientific procedures now available, such as DNA testing, to identify human remains found on Christmas Island and claimed by many to be from HMAS Sydney ;
(d) the extent to which the Commonwealth Government should participate in a search for HMAS Sydney ; and
(e) measures which should be taken to protect and honour as war graves at sea the final resting places of HMAS Sydney and KSN Kormoran ;
(2) That the committee consist of 12 members, 7 members to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips and 5 members to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member;
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the Speaker;
(4) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman;

(5) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting
(6) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine;

(7) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting;
(8) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee;

(9) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the public proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum;
(10) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records;
(11) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to move from place to place;
(12) That a subcommittee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any sittings or adjournment of the House;
(13) That the committee have leave to report from time to time; and
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.

I seek to establish a select committee to inquire into the sinking of the HMAS Sydney on 19 November 1941. I am a late arrival to this issue. My interest in it was sparked in November 1994 when the first Western Australian 1945-95 Australia Remembers commemorative service was conducted. That was in waters between Fremantle and Rottnest and it commemorated well the Sydney . It seemed, however, to be regrettable to me at the time that nationally we were unable to find any geographically more correct location.

I subsequently became a trustee of the Perth based HMAS Sydney foundation trust, established to encourage community support in a national effort to search for the Sydney. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) and the late Senator Panizza have all lent their office and support to this same endeavour.

The sinking of the Sydney was Australia's greatest naval tragedy, with the loss of 645 men. There has never been a truly national effort to publicly appreciate the reasons for the loss, to seek to find the Sydney and to properly commemorate and protect the final resting place of the Sydney and her crew.

On its own admission, the Australian Archives document search lacks two vital pieces of evidence—the naval inquiry report of 1946 and relevant ships logs and signals logs. The Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) has today, as previously, indicated that he will place no obstacle in the way of this search. Time, of course, is of the essence. Our time today will not see the adoption of a select committee. I will not be precipitous in the conduct that I take in this House, but I propose to pursue this motion to its natural conclusion. Later today I will table a notice of motion to that effect.

This is national unfinished business. This House can lead a national effort to seek to finalise it—to commemorate, to protect and honour the Sydney and her 645 crew. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that all my colleag ues would agree that the need to resolve co nflict with war is anathema to modern civilisation within the First World and, for that matter, in any of the world's cultures. How ever, just over 50 years ago Australia was embroiled in a world war—a conflict which de cimated many countries and many cultures and destroyed many societies. The Second World War placed enormous anguish within many Australian families. Over 60,000 Aus tralians never returned home.

SPEECH.PARA: In the majority of these tragic casualties t he families knew how and where their love d one was lost to them. Although not happy with the news, I am sure most families were able to grieve more easily because of the ce rtainty of the information they had received about their lost family member. This was n ot so for the families of service personnel st ationed on the HMAS Sydney. These families remain unsure as to the fate of their loved o ne, due to the many theories of how the Sydney was sunk with all personnel on board—personnel totalling some 645, repres enting all major cities and towns in Australia.

The sinking of the Sydney off the coast of Western Australia is clouded in uncertainty as to who was responsible. Was it the German raider Kormoran? Was it a Japanese submarine engaging in an act of war prior to the Pearl Harbour bombing?

The fact remains that there is mystery su rrounding the sinking of the Sydney. I wholeheartedly support the motion of the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) and seconded by the member for Moore (Mr Filing), both of whom have a very real interest in determining answers for the mystery.

The Minister for Defence, Ian McLachlan, and I met on this matter and he advised me to say that he will put no obstacles in the way of an open inquiry into the matter. No doubt, by implication, this was support for an inquiry. Mr McCarthy of the Western Australian Maritime Museum says:
The issue of the Sydney should first and foremost be the telling of the story to the satisfaction of the bereaved or to those left in doubt about the sinking.
I agree, and fully support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in support of this motion, I want to remind members that just 50 years ago Australia suffered its worst naval tragedy ever. Just off our western coast one of our most famous and powerful warships to that time was sunk with the loss of the entire war complement of 645 men and boys. No-one survived. We still have not resolved this loss to the satisfaction of their relatives nor of the Australian community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: The information that is available all points to a series of errors. The Kormoran's survivors testified that Sydney's captain came too close to the German raider and that Sydney's gunnery staff was apparently unprepared to be able to fire the first shots. This is compounded by controversy over the search for survivors and the fact that over 300 Germans survived but no-one from Sydney. The government and Navy appeared to have been less than candid in the release of information, which is confirmed by that information available after the 30-year secrecy conditions lapsed.

This is an issue that is not going to go aw ay. The fact that we were not able to achiev e a satisfactory result then has served to increase demands for a full inquiry rather th an to reduce them. Because there has never been any compulsion to provide a full satisf actory answer to the people of Australia, th e government and the Department of Defen ce, particularly the Navy office, have not been forced to be accountable for what has happened at sea or afterwards.

BREAK.PARA: There has been speculation that a full inquiry did take place in what must have been absolute secrecy. Archival notes of a war cabinet meeting refer to an inquiry. Details, however, have never been publicised and may even have been destroyed since. I am convinced that the people of Australia deserve a chance to find out why this tragedy occurred and why the relevant authorities are being forthright in finding out what has happened and making it public. I wish to commend the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) for his dedication to the task in pursuing the creation of a select committee of inquiry.

The Australian Archives acknowledge there may be information that has not yet been found that pertains to the sinking of the Sydney. The Archives' paper holding is the equivalent of 500 shelf kilometres. The cha nce of finding material wrongly or obscurely filed without a concerted effort is very small. There were 200 shelf metres of documents related to just naval signal relevant messages. Not all of the relevant material is held by the Archives. Some is still held by departments but without document or file details cited to the Archives.

The Archives has given examples of official documents which were removed from or ne ver placed in the official record. These even include interrogation reports from the crew of the Kormoran and logs from HMAS Harman, thought to have been the only establishment monitoring ship to shore communications at the time. Did Sydney send any distress message?

What we need is a wide ranging opportunity to establish an inquiry which can get the relevant information together to deal with the mystery surrounding the loss of HMAS Sydney and its crew. It needs to be able to establish not only what happened in that battle at sea but what happened since Sydney was last seen steaming off to the south south-east, down at the bow and burning.

Clearly, the Commonwealth has a duty to those who were lost and to their surviving relatives, but it is not that simple. We must find what documentary evidence may exist and gain access to it. Most of these records will be official Commonwealth records, and clearly there is a leadership and coordination role that must be played. If we cannot discover exactly what happened to the Sydney through the examination of records, we must find the remains of the ship.
