Only Commonwealth support and involvement will allow the volunteer and commercial organisations who are willing to continue to search for HMAS Sydney to be effective.

I, too, commend this motion. I congratulate the member for Perth on his initiative as well, and also would like to thank the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) for his comments and support for what is, in my view, probably one of the greatest calls for an inquiry in this place for some time, given its historical significance and given that the HMAS Sydney bears the name of the city which will be hosting the Olympics in two or three years time.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an o rder of the day for the next sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for the one million plus real unemployed in this country. I grieve al so for a government which on budget night, in acknowledgment of this national tragedy, could mention unemployment or employment but once. It is a national shame that reflects very poorly on the government. For a government to treat this evil, chronic and endemic unemployment problem in this nation with j ust one mention is mind numbing to the ext reme. Prior to the budget, 70 per cent of A ustralians considered the government's first task was to seriously tackle unemployment and implement strategies other than just eco nomic levers to create jobs, and the government's response to that call from the Australian electorate was just one sentence —just one mention of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: There are creative and indeed commonsense solutions to break the back of unemployme nt. Some are known, and I will mention a c ouple of them later in this speech. But some are, as yet, unknown—the legacy of an inad equate commitment in this country to solve unemployment. Why has this commitment t o solve the unemployment problem gone mi ssing? Why is there an apparent lack of will , a lack of urgency, a lack of real empathy t o the unemployed by government, by bureaucracy, by academia, by business, by industry, by unions, by welfare and by the media?

After spending the last nine years on the House of Representatives standing committe e and Labor caucus committees on employ ment, education and training, I have had the opportunity to hear first‐hand the views of many Australians on the vexed problem of unemployment. One theme that haunts me and is often repeated comes from people who h ave leadership power and influence in this c ountry. It is quite obvious that most of today's leaders have been largely untouched by unemployment. They completed their education, chose their occupation and progressed through their chosen fields. They grew up when unemployment was one or t wo per cent. Among these people, personal experience, whether in families or extended families, of unemployment would be minimal. Perhaps that explains in one way at least th e lack of urgency so necessary in tackling t he unemployment problem.

The current situation is in stark contrast t o the leaders who influenced Australia in th e postwar period, who experienced the Depression and a world war. Postwar reconstruction in the free democratic world included a social contract with the workers that today all over the world governments are running away from at a thousand kilometres an hour. Many people on the government side point to the apparent low unemployment rates in countries like the United States. But if you add to tha t base figure of six or seven per cent unemployment, four per cent in prison, up to per manently four per cent in crime and up to f our per cent on the streets or who have just given up, that is not perhaps an unemployment rate that we should emulate.

And let us not be too precious in this cou ntry either. I am yet to be convinced that the real unemployment rate is at the current official rate of 8.75 per cent. It is more like 13 per cent plus if you take into account those who have given up and those who are seriously underemployed. Yet when ideas are put up in this country to create jobs, even in a very modest way, the idea is often given the run‐around by those who advise government. And major political parties wonder why an increasing sum of people in this country are seriously looking at what are mad and very dangerous alternatives.

Take the modest example put up by the Australia‐New Zealand Solar Energy Society. The study demonstrated that an increase in the use of solar energy for hot water, for example, from the current six per cent of Queensland households to 25 per cent would create 1,500 new and direct jobs. If you apply that across Australia, you would get 15,000 new real jobs. But why hasn't that idea seen the light of day? It would use Australian sourced raw materials in glass, plastic, insulation, copper piping and so on. It would apply to industries working below capacity and to disappearing occupations like pipe fitters.

Why do we allow a situation in Australian shipping where we carry only 7½ per cent of our trading products and in international containerisation only 3½ per cent? Why do we export billions of dollars and thousands of jobs in freight and insurance costs? Why isn't Darwin a major port in Australia? Why isn' t it linked by a north‐south rail land bridge to the rest of Australia? Why do we have ineffectual urban transport policies in so many of our cities? And why have we in Australia failed to get the right balance and attitude to investment and subsidy to roads and rail? Why don't we, out of limited government investment, maximise rather than minimise the number of jobs that may result?

A German study I came across demonstrated that, if you spend a billion deutschmarks—about a billion Australian dollars—on road construction, you get considerably fewer jobs than if you spend the same amount on heavy or light rail: about 14,000 jobs for roads, 22,000 for heavy rail and about 23,000 for light rail. Australia spends about $6 billion on roads each year. But, in so doing, we fail to acknowledge the huge associated cost. There is at least $6 billion in road deaths and trauma and perhaps up to $10 billion in compensation payments. That is one hell of a subsidy for such a negative return.

Let us compare the reaction, though, to public transport or a railway line that `loses' a few million dollars. If we mention `subsidy for road transport' in this country, no-one blinks, no-one turns a hair. If we mention `subsidy for rail', some in this country in powerful positions become positively feral. It is not very honest, it is not employment sensitive and it is not in the best interests of Australians or our infrastructure.

The developed world has created a chronic and endemic unemployment problem that, if not addressed, will lead to civil disorder in many countries. Current economic orthodoxies and past economic orthodoxies appear incapable of solving the problem. Economic growth alone, although important, will not solve the problem of unemployment. The fundamental role of a nation's economy is to provide job opportunities to all those who want them.

Patricia Hewitt, the Deputy Director of the Institute of Public Policy Research in London and the author of a widely commentated paper at the European job summit in October 1993, argued that a reduction in working time cannot solve the problem of unemployment on its own but, she said:

No analysis of unemployment and employment will be adequate unless it takes account of the rapid changes in the structure of working time and working lifetimes; and no employment debate will be complete if it omits working time reorganisations.

We have not really had that debate in this country. In the Australian context, John Moorhouse, from the University of South A ustralia, has pointed out that, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 20 million hours of overtime are worked in Australia. Since 1978, a time when unemployment started to grow, overtime for males has increased by 70 per cent and that for females has increased by over 100 per cent. Simplistically, 20 million hours are equivalent to 500,000, 40-hour-a-week jobs. It is under stood that not all of those hours are paid overtime. Nevertheless, serious consideration would lead to the release of between 100,000 and 200,000 jobs. Even if it were just a minimal 50,000, it would be worth the effort.

The debate on the reduction of hours is vigorously criticised by some academics and financial writers. However, they take little or no account of the social costs of unemployment with increased crime and suicide—nor do they mention an inefficient economy with high unemployment, occupational health and safety problems, lost productivity caused by boredom and fatigue, increased compensation claims and redundancies. Repetitive strain injuries and post‐traumatic stress syndrome seem to be the diseases of the 1980s and 1990s. Why?

The criticisms of some economists are that proposals to reduce working hours suffer from a `lump of output fallacy'—that is, the total amount of work to be done is fixed and, therefore, the only way to employ more people is to share the work more frequently, but that is in and out of employment. But surely the `lump of output fallacy' is itself fallacious because of the productivity gains throughout the 20th century. Between 1881 and 1981 the lifetime hours worked by British men fell by nearly half—from 154,000 hours over 56 years to 88,000 hours over 48 years. That downward trend over a century is being reversed, dooming at least 10 per cent and probably 20 per cent of our community to intermittent employment, if any, for all their lives.

Reducing working hours schemes will not on their own solve the unemployment problem. However, they must be analysed and given serious consideration in the debate to tackle unemployment. The three examples I have mentioned will create jobs and reduce unemployment. They are, of course, only part of the answer, but they are a beginning. But there can be no beginning with a significant change in policy development by all politic al parties unless the attitude to the unemployed from this nation's leaders changes dr amatically, and that requires leadership. It r equires government and the Prime Minister to lead first. Unfortunately, in the budget the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Ho ward) ducked the unemployment problem a nd left the unemployed on their own. That i s to this nation's shame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan, Kathryn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that the Howard government holds two-thirds of the total seats in the House of Representatives, my turns at speaking in the grievance debate are far‐between. Therefore, the selection of a topic for this brief and fleeting opportunity usually requires a difficult choice to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: On this occasion, the choice has been made for me by two events that occurred last week: firstly, the release of the March quarter `visitor arrival figures' and the coincidental publication of three independently‐conducted surveys of international tourism, and, secondly, the release of the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families—the Bringing them home report.

Members may well wonder how these two apparently poles‐apart topics may relate to the one subject and some may think that, as a member representing a Gold Coast electorate, I should concentrate on the former and leave the latter to the time when it will be specifically under consideration by the House of Representatives. In fact, both are dimensions of an issue which I feel conscience‐bound to address now, namely, the expression of racism in Australia and the hurt it is causing our country—both internally and externally.

Whilst the March quarter visitor arrival figures show a welcome overall increase, an analysis of 1997 tourism statistics—as distinct from visitor arrivals, which includes non-tourist visitors—shows an ominous underlying problem. It is being referred to in the tourism industry (and press reports) as the `Pauline Hanson effect'.

A comparison of the March 1996 quarter figures with the March 1997 quarter figures shows a drop in international tourist arrivals from four of our significant sources of Asian tourists. Thailand's figures declined by 900 tourists; Singapore by 2,300, Japan by 10,500 and Taiwan by 14,900. Malaysia appears to continue to show an increase, but a comparison of the rate of increase of tourists from that country shows a decline from nine per cent growth in January and February to five per cent by the end of the three months of the March quarter. Nobody in the tourism industry believes that this is just a `temporary' blip in the figures.

The experts point to the fact that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) made her maiden speech in the House of Representatives in September 1996, and to the many reports in Asian newspapers which followed it. These newspapers continue to report her constant claims that on the subject of Asians in Australia she speaks for the `vast majority' of Australians. The fact—a word the member for Oxley dislikes unless she is applying it to her quite idiosyncratic `facts'—is that, given the normal lead time of several months for people booking overseas holidays, 1997 figures are beginning to demonstrate the real effect of her wild assertions and her attempts to play on what she apparently perceives as widespread anti-Asian sentiment in Australia.

The effect in my electorate has been a drop in international tourism growth rates and the cancellation of bookings by international tour-group clients. Australian tourism industry executives have been stating for some time that these cancellations are frequently accompanied by statements from tourism marketers in our major Asian sources of visitors, that their clients do not want to visit a country in which they believe they are not welcome because of their race.

I remind the House of the words the member for Oxley chose to state her position when she made her maiden speech—words which have resonated in Asia, and which have also been widely reported in North America, to my personal knowledge. On 10 September 1996, she told us—and the world:

I and most Australians want our immigration policy radically reviewed and that of multiculturalism abolished. I believe we are in danger of being swamped by Asians. Between 1984 and 1995, 40 per cent of all migrants coming into this country were of Asian origin. They have their own culture and religion, form ghettos and do not assimilate . . . A truly multicultural country can never be strong or united.
She then quoted the 50‐year‐old words of Arthur Calwell:

Japan, India, Burma, Ceylon and every new African nation are fiercely anti-white and anti one another. Do we want or need any of these people here? I am one red-blooded Australian who says no and who speaks for 90 per cent of Australians.
She added:
I have no hesitation in echoing the words of Arthur Calwell.
In adopting that posture, she appears to claim to speak for 90 per cent of Australians!

Pause for a moment and apply a bit of logic to her statement. If 40 per cent of our migrants are Asian, then 60 per cent—the majority—are not. Of our current population, a little under 5 per cent are Asian. That is, the 95 per cent non-Asian population is being boosted annually by 60 per cent—a majority—of migrant arrivals. Far from being `swamped by Asians', her own figures indicate the gap between Asians and non-Asians would actually be widening.

In fact—that word again!—even if every new migrant to Australia were Asian, it would still take 200 years before they became 50 per cent of our population. The member for Oxley usually brushes these facts aside by saying others are telling `lies'. Her own facts, on this occasion, bring her argument undone. I note that she was reported at the weekend as being opposed only to—and the quote in the paper was—`massive immigration and that was on environmental grounds'.

I have here a copy of her speech in Ipswich on 11 April this year, made at the event in which she launched her One Nation Party, and which I shall seek leave to table at the conclusion of my speech. In that speech she said that one of the five `immediate goals' of the party would be:
To stop all immigration except that related to investment that will
lead to employment, and for this to continue until Australia's unemployment is solved.

Not in her entire speech—and certainly not in her statement of goals—is there a single mention of the environment in any context whatsoever. Her speech reeks of anti-Asian sentiment. It can be no coincidence that in making points on her perceived negatives about Australia today, she refers disparagingly to Asian countries. For example, on the decline of jobs in manufacturing industry, she says:
The jobs are going to countries like Indonesia, where the pay is 39 cents an hour.
On the consequences of decline in rural Australia:
Will the Government then import even basic crops—perhaps rice, to get us more used to it?
On multiculturalism:
And yet there are so many people in Australia who do not think of themselves as Australians. They have simply transplanted the problems of their way of life to our country.
We must remove the divisiveness of . . . multicultural affairs. Government policies have given us different classifications for Australians.
We now have Aboriginal Australians, and Indonesian Australians and other ethnic minorities.
What of your dream for Australia?
Do you want it to be like another place?
Indonesia perhaps? Cambodia or Vietnam?
How about Iran or Iraq or Lebanon?
Do you want race riots, religious fanaticism, gang and drug wars?
We won't achieve it—
that is, the `dream for Australia'—
by allowing heinous crimes previously unknown to us such as home invasions and the extortion of shopkeepers to be imported along with so many cultures so alien to the Australian way of life.
In the conclusion to this manifesto which includes many wild assertions about foreign investment, she says—in a clear reference to the Japanese:
We must remember the sacrifice of so many Australians who fought to save our country from outsiders who would have taken it.
We must not allow our country to be taken from within.

Given her recent apparent disavowal of this manifesto's immigration `goal'—to the press, at least—just what is the One Nation Party's immigration policy now? Who knows? And if we think we know what it is today—a fashionable (in some quarters) concern for the environment—who is to say what it will be next month, or next year?

Trying to pin down the views of the member for Oxley is as frustrating as trying to catch a grasshopper. Just when you think you can get a grip on it and dispose of it appropriately, it shifts—takes off at a tangent—out of your immediate reach. You pursue it to its new position and when it realises it is in trouble again, it shifts once more. And so on.

Some may think this a trivial comparison, but I remind them that large species of grasshoppers are known as locusts. We may have spent a lot of time over past months explaining to Asian members of parliament, to investors and other business people from our Asian trading partners, and to the world's press that the views of one independent member of parliament are not the nation's views—that she is, like the grasshopper in the garden, fairly insignificant in the scheme of things. Unfortunately her rallies, reported to the world, appear more to portend the ominous dark cloud of an approaching swarm of locusts—a dark hint of nascent racism in Australia.

What is the link between this and the report on the `stolen children'—the Bringing them Home report? Last weekend, I heard on radio the words of the member for Oxley about this report. After saying the stories in it were terrible, she immediately denied the report's statistics to justify the practice! She used words to the effect, `Well, a number of those children would now otherwise be dead'. It is a case of don't worry her with the comparative mortality and health figures in the report—the facts, again—because to do so would undo all her anti `Aboriginal Australian' rhetoric.

Make no mistake, the world is watching how we handle this report. It will measure us against the image the member for Oxley has so successfully given Australia of being a racist country. If, as a nation, we appear to react to this report as she has, they will do so with some justification.

BREAK.PARA: I seek leave to table a document headed `Speech, Pauline Hanson, Launch of One N ation, 11.4.1997'.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I gri eve this afternoon for the many residents in the beautiful suburbs of Chelsea Heights, Aspendale Gardens, Mordialloc and Parkdale whose otherwise peaceful lives are continually disrupted by the excessive traffic volumes t hat are forced to use these pleasant outer south‐east suburban Melbourne suburbs as major traffic thoroughfares between Wells Road and Boundary Road through to the Ne pean Highway. In summary, the quality of life enjoyed by the several thousand residents li ving in the aforementioned areas is greatly diminished by the failure of the Victorian st ate government to fund the construction of a section of freeway of approximately 10 kilometres in length known as the Dingley Bypass.

SPEECH.PARA: The Dingley Bypass has been planned for a number of years to link the Mornington Peninsula Freeway at Chelsea Heights ultimately with South Road, Moorabbin at War rigal Road via Wells Road and Boundary Road. The proposal was developed by the t hen state Labor government in 1992 and was fully supported by the then five surrounding municipal councils which comprised the are a. In fact, the councils were prepared to forgo all other roadworks to get this project funded, such was the importance they placed on it f rom a local perspective.

The overall cost of the project in 1992 do llars was estimated to be $23 million over e ight years, which is approximately $3.5 mill ion per year. Half of this funding was at tha t time to have been provided from the coun cils' arterial road allocation fund. Therefore , costs directly to the Victorian government would have been perhaps as little as only $ 2 million per annum.

The residents of Chelsea Heights living in the vicinity of the intersection of Thames Promenade and Wells Road know that the Mornington Peninsula Freeway traffic exits that freeway at this particular point to avoid one set of traffic lights at the terminus of t he freeway one kilometre further north at Springvale Road. Chelsea Heights residents living around Fifth, Sixth and Eighth Avenues and those in Amaroo Drive and Enterprize Avenue areas know that it is extremely difficult and equally dangerous to try to acc ess Wells Road or even Thames Promenade given the excessive volumes of traffic on t hese roads during peak periods.

A local resident, Mr Ian Baldock, has put a detailed submission to the City of Kingst on and has organised meetings of residents t o highlight the inadequacies of the Wells Road/Enterprize Avenue intersections used i ncreasingly by local families, most of whom are young and who now have children approaching kindergarten and pre‐school age.

Some two kilometres further north, the re sidents of the 1,600 homes comprising what should equally be a peaceful suburb, that o f Aspendale Gardens, are plagued by the excessive volumes of high speed traffic usin g Wells Road, which north of its intersectio n and terminus at Springvale Road becomes a divided four‐lane road. The Mornington Peninsula Freeway terminates abruptly at Springvale Road, causing traffic to exit ont o Wells Road right through the middle of A spendale Gardens, often travelling at excessi ve speeds and not only meriting the construction of the Dingley Bypass some two or three kilometres further east but also necessitating locals to mount a campaign for the construction of a pedestrian crossing which is indee d supervised to ensure that local school chil dren who use that crossing are not involved in a serious accident with an oncoming speeding car. If the freeway were extended between the terminus at Springvale Road on to South Road, it would then access the Ne pean Highway at South Road and do this th rough a light industrial area and not through residential streets, as it does today.

A few hundred metres further north, Wells Road, Aspendale Gardens becomes Boundary Road, Mordialloc. The ultimate destination of much of this traffic is the Nepean Highway, where it proceeds on to inner Melbourne and areas further north. There are some three roads in this area that traffic uses to access the Nepean Highway. The first of these is Governor Road. Mr Mark Heath, Secretary of the Governor Road Safety Committee, noted two years ago that there had been a massive increase in the volume of traffic using Governor Road, much of which was heavy vehicles, and that much of that traffic, of both heavy and smaller vehicle nature, attained unlawfully high speeds. Mr Heath and his neighbours in this area are legitimately concerned for not only their safety but also of course the safety of their children.

The roundabout at the intersection of Boundary and Governor Roads is also extremely dangerous. Aspendale Gardens resident Mrs Maria Fabbiano contacted me recently about having been run off the road by a truck while she was attempting to negotiate this roundabout. Were the state government to construct the required section of freeway to be known as the Dingley Bypass between Springvale and South Roads, then trucks of the kind that ran Mrs Fabbiano off this Boundary Road roundabout would not even have cause to be on it in the first instance. Nor would they use White Street in Mordialloc, the second major access road between Boundary Road and the Nepean Highway.

Young Maria Coutsis is a White Street resident who has recently written a passionate letter to me detailing her personal experiences in witnessing accidents in White Street—a narrow two‐lane road carrying excessive traffic and a significant number of heavy vehicles. I urge the state government to hear the pleas of concerned residents like Maria Coutsis and to construct this 10‐kilometre stretch of freeway and so get traffic off streets like White Street. Similar pleas emanate from residents living on either side of and along lower Dandenong Road, the third major route through to the Nepean Highway from Boundary Road.

The Mornington Peninsula Freeway—a ro ad into which much of the north bound traffic from the Mornington Peninsula itself and indeed from Melbourne's south-east growth corridor ultimately funnels—simply comes to an end at Springvale Road. All of the traffic on it simply filters through residential streets to get to the nearest major road travelling in the same direction, that being the Nepean Highway.

The Victorian government has indicated that the construction of this short stretch of freeway known as the Dingley Bypass—which is only 10 kilometres long and which, in my view and the view of all local residents, would ameliorate the problems of Ian Baldock, Maria Coutsis, Maria Fabbiano and many thousands of their neighbours—is not in its 10-year funding program. I have urged in writing in times past and I implore again in this place this afternoon for the Victorian government—in the interests of those people who deserve to live in safe, clean and peaceful neighbourhoods—to reconsider its decision not to fund the construction of this freeway within the foreseeable 10-year period. I urge the government to act as a matter of urgency to ensure that residents of this beautiful bayside neighbourhood can have their place of living returned to one where peace, clean air, solitude and safety prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I grieve for the forgotten band of Australians who are among us in the community, the group of Australians numbering almost 18 per cent of the total population. Today I grieve for the disabled Australians, in particular intellectually disabled Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Picture this if you will. A room full of people, people who are not your average ordinary Australians; rather people with very special and certainly very defined needs. One woman seems cheerful enough. She wears a shirt made of flour sack material because it is the only thing she has not yet managed to tear off. A teenager sits in a wheelchair, his body twisted, muscles atrophied. He operates his wheelchair using a lever. Despite his outward appearance, his eyes show a certain comprehension of all that is going on around him. A young woman who talks in screeches and looks no bigger than a two-year‐old walks by assisted by two staff. I was told she was 20 years of age. Outside in the garden lying on mattresses are several people who are letting their twisted limbs succumb to gentle physiotherapy.

Of course, as all of us here are aware, this scene is not a dream. It is in fact reality. This scene was what greeted me when I visited an organisation called Valued Independent People—or VIP House—in the suburb of Girrawheen, which is in the heart of my electorate.

This facility plays an important part in the care and long-term welfare of the intellectually disabled residents of Cowan. In Cowan there are two schools that cater for students who have special needs within the disabled community—Burbridge and Gladys Newton, which I have had the pleasure to visit from time to time.

Burbridge earlier this year had a multisensory environment room installed as a way of promoting levels of concentration, interest and excitement in the children. A research team from the University of Western Australia is also studying the students' reaction to the multisensory environment and recording their progress.

Still, it was a sobering sight to be at VIP House and witness the daily living demands of people who have disabilities and the people who care for them. VIP House aims to provide a flexible home and neighbourhood, daytime occupation, community access and a participation service to people with a disability according to their needs. Occasional respite is also provided. The service is directed to people with high support needs, as an alternative to employment, and is restricted to persons residing in the northern metropolitan corridor of Perth.

VIP House is now providing recreational services to school leavers who are living at home or in hostels under the post‐school options funding. It receives basic funding from the Disability Services Commission and clients pay a minimal fee for service, plus a token transport fee. A board oversees the operation and staff are responsible for the day-to-day running of the operation. Despite what must be limited funding, the staff have transformed this house into a multipurpose caring centre for people with all kinds of disabilities.

BREAK.PARA: I will be honest with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and admit it was a challenging sight to come face to face with many of the clients who use the facility, but I was struck by the unswerving enthusiasm of the management, the board, the carers—who prefer to be known as facilitators—and the parents, some of whom I met during my visit. The unstinting love and care offered to the clients and children in what must be at times highly demanding and emotionally exhausting work never ceased to amaze me. It can be quite jarring, especially as a parent who has three healthy children, to observe the daily hardships many of these parents face.

My visit raised some important issues—issues that really never should confront this service area of our community, issues which governments should never debate; rather they should just tick off funding approvals. It seems to me that our priorities when it comes to care for the disabled have hit the wall. They have hit the wall of apathy.

We have lost the focus that our country should always have towards our less advantaged, towards those who remain the forgotten within our community. I think it is most important for those of us who do not have relatives with disabilities to appreciate how hard the daily task can be for those who do. People with disabilities and their families may suffer hardships, but in most cases all action is undertaken with such an enormous degree of selflessness. They have accepted that their lot in life is somewhat different to the average Australian.

For instance, I met a couple who immigrated to Australia from Portugal about 10 years ago. They adopted a blind, severely intellectually disabled teenager who was 15—and they had him for about three years—who had been abandoned by his natural parents at birth. What humane values these people must have applied. They truly are great Australian heroes in my view.

I would suggest that we need to reassess our priorities with funding in this very imp ortant area. The staff, board and parents at VIP House conveyed to me other issues that were of concern to them—specifically in th e area of the disability services sector. In th e issue of health, there is the question of responsibility: who is responsible for whom?

In Western Australia, the disability services area has worked long and hard to change th e public's perceptions of people with disabilities. We no longer have the Spastic Welfare Society and the Slow Learning Children's Group. We now have the Cerebral Palsy Association and Activ Foundation. These na me changes have had an important impact o n public perception. The emphasis is not on disabled people but on people with a disability. They are putting people first.

However, a concern raised by some parents I spoke to was the issue of sterilisation for intellectually disabled females. They would like to have the right to give consent for their daughters to have a hysterectomy. Before all the civil rights people start jumping up and down, let us just think about this for a moment. An intellectually disabled woman who is confined to a wheelchair or the young person I met who is in calipers would not be able to adequately care for themselves even if they were more mobile. During menstruation, I am told, hygiene problems can occur, especially when they cannot adequately care for themselves. Yet parents, certainly in Western Australia, have no right to determine the welfare of their daughter in this regard. I spoke to a father who has two daughters who are intellectually disabled and he is very passionate on this issue. This particular issue does seem to be of great concern to parents who feel it would simply be one less thing to be concerned about.

Another issue raised with me is the one of carers and the need for respite care. It is my clear view that the unheralded in the community are those who work as carers. More work needs to be done in this policy area. In particular, it is considered there is not enough quality respite care within our community, and I wholeheartedly agree with that. The latest budget addresses carers with a welcome increase both in financial assistance and also funding over four years for the national respite for carers program. However, more needs to be done.

Another inequity within the disability field is the one of home and community care—or HACC, as it is commonly called—with its funding emphasis on service for the aged. It would be very useful if this were extended to include people with disabilities. The fact is that 18 per cent of the population are disabled. If we transfer that figure to the amount of people who are required to care for them and the agencies that provide services for them, it translates into a fairly sizeable proportion of our population.
The West Australian refers to the disability group as `the forgotten band'. We recently heard from a parent, Mr Bob Primose, who wrote to the West Australian about his son. He said that:
The provision of services has not kept pace with the rising level of community needs.
He goes on to refer to his son, Gregory, who had died 30 months previously:
Although we miss him greatly, his passing released us from the stress of worrying what the future held—what would happen to him when we were no longer there to monitor his well‐being.

It is not so much a case of increasing spending; rather a case of getting our priorities right. We need to think very carefully about where we spend taxpayers' funds. This group of people find life hard and this needs to be recognised. We do not need to make their lives even harder by cutting funds to services provided to them.

The federal government's efficiency dividend will ensure that administrative operations are accountable for the amount of funding the states and territories receive. It remains an imperative to ensure carers receive adequate respite, especially elderly carers. I met a woman who is 72 years of age and she has bathed her 38‐year‐old daughter every day for the last 38 years. You can imagine what a task that would be. Her greatest concern is what will happen if she dies. Who will look after her daughter?

I grieve today for this particular part of our community. I think it is very important that we address it in a financial sense and also in a policy sense. We need to consider our intellectually disabled people in particular withi n our community with greater funding emphasis. We should not have them lining up i n front of governments, both state and feder al, asking for funds when we should automatically provide for these people and their carers. I ask that both state and federal governments throughout the country consider in creasing their time with policy formulation i n this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start grieving I would like to commend the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans). I think his was a very good and thoughtful speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to grieve on Sir Ronald Wilson's report, Bringing them home. I have absolutely no doubt that there were terrible injustices done and that children were taken from loving parents. I have no doubt that this was done with malice on occasions, but more often it was done with the interests of the children in mind. The children we are talking about were half‐caste or even less Aboriginal. It may have been a racist view, but it was deemed that, because these children were at least half‐white, they should have a chance. With the clear vision afforded by hindsight this was extreme folly.

However, judgment should be made by the standards of time. What must also be considered is that Judge Wilson predominantly interviewed those cases presented to him by the Aboriginal Legal Service. There were many cases elsewhere where people did not respond because they knew it was the fact of being made wards of the states that saved their lives.

Besides being very selective, Sir Ronald's report is fatally flawed in other ways. He says that it is not an intellectual report; it is from the heart. This means, of course, it is not bound by fact. Indeed, the evidence he has collected is beyond confirmation. Sir Ronald said in an interview in the West Australian on 30 May that:
. . . I didn't stop, as a judge would have stopped, to ask where's the corroboration. How could you doubt the authenticity of a story when tears are running down the faces of the storytellers?

Had Sir Ronald witnessed the tears shed in this parliament by posturing politicians, he would perhaps have been a little more cautious. As it is, he has offered a licence to every con man in the land.

Just such an example is on page 7 of the West Australian on 29 May. There is a picture of Patrick Dodson giving his closing speech at the reconciliation convention. Mr Dodson is giving a eulogy about Robert Riley who, it is claimed, committed suicide last year after a long struggle to come to grips with the enforced removal from his family. Let it be understood that Robert Riley was not forcibly removed from his family. His mother asked Sister Kate to take him because she was in a relationship with a man who could not stand Robert and whose bashings would probably have killed Robert. It may be true that Robert Riley was traumatised at being rejected by his mother, but it had nothing at all to do with whitey. I would be very surprised if Patrick Dodson did not know that and Ronald Wilson should have known it because he was on the board of Sister Kate's at the time. While it may be a good tear‐jerker and a guilt reinforcing performance, it just was not true. Such is the level of evidence regularly used by the doyens of the guilt industry.

Ron Caston and Robert Manne are good examples: both pillars of the Jewish community who like to flagellate us with guilt. Yet they are strangely silent on land rights or compensation for thousands of dispossessed Palestinians. It is always easy in an issue to trot out the highly emotional example, as the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) did in his predictably sanctimonious contribution.

I remember the words of Isabella Lynott, who is now 95 years old. She, along with her sister, were the first children taken to Beagle Bay, a catholic mission, in 1909. Isabella's father was white and when he died her mother implored the local police officer to take her children as they would otherwise surely die. Isabella remembers Beagle Bay very warmly. She said:
The nuns were very good to us. They gave us clean clothes, taught us to read and write and to play musical instruments. They taught us how to sew and to dance.
She had only gratitude for her deliverance.

Another hero of mine is Pearl Hamaguchi, a woman who, being an Aboriginal‐Asian, endured a far harder life than white half‐caste children. Being half‐Asian, she was not considered worth saving, although she was institutionalised for a short time later. Pearl remembers all that she endured, but she does not dwell on it. She has made a name for herself. Both she, her husband and her family are highly respected members of the community. Her comment to me recently was that she had always thought that, we, the Gudea, were a bit silly but, with Mabo, native title and Ronald Wilson, she now thinks we are far more stupid than even she had imagined. Pearl Hamaguchi is an inspiration to me and a great role model for the whole of society.

I know many stories that tell of triumph over adversity. After all, I represent more Aboriginal people than any other politician. Unlike the members who spoke on the MPI or the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), I and my staff are involved daily with the problems of a large constituency and we get a good insight into the real problems and disadvantages that Aboriginal people suffer.

It is all very well looking back through the misty eyes of political correctness. Given the guilt‐ridden apology of our Governor‐General, he—on his fat salary paid out of the public purse—can see our unspeakable shame and, because he can see it, is somehow aloof from it. The Governor‐General has no private capacity. While it is true that he was appointed by Keating to further the craven cause of republicanism, until that great day comes he would do well to remember that he is a representative of the Crown.

By the standards of the time, the decision to remove children was considered a compassionate move. Of course there was some abuse of the system, but there was considerably more sensitivity and compassion than present day critics would concede or even understand. I have spoken to police officers who have told me that, where children were being looked after, they did not enforce their removal. Many of the children were taken for their own protection.

BREAK.PARA: What Sir Ronald should have done is to have compared the plight of those who were not afforded the protection of the state. I suspect that if an apology is owed or compensation due it is to those people, but for the most part they are dead.

There were cases where Aboriginal custodial fathers would encourage their young, lighter coloured girls into prostitution. I wonder what the ranks of the politically correct would have had the government of the day do under those circumstances. In many other cases, half‐caste children were simply not wanted by the tribe, regardless of how the mother felt.

The real tragedy and shame is that, because of all this emotional nonsense, there are many Aboriginal children today who should be made wards of the state, and the authorities know that their failure to do so will inevitably lead to their death. I recall phoning a doctor in a large Aboriginal town last Boxing Day. She confided to me how angry she was, patching up neglected children, putting them into hospital, knowing that in six weeks they would go home and, inevitably, be readmitted a few months later—defenceless children on an inevitable downward plane. They are entitled to the protection of the state but are denied it because of our political correctness.

In conclusion, I want to set the record straight about the referendum in 1967. I believe I have always been politically aware. The truth is that I and the overwhelming majority of the Australian population thought we were voting to give Aboriginals equality. We were not. We were voting to give the Commonwealth special powers, which have, by and large, been abused.

I note that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talked in his contribution of the benefits that flowed from the referendum. He listed in his speech what he saw as the priorities. Interestingly enough, in those priorities he quoted me exactly, except he missed out one of them. If you miss out one, the wheels fall off the lot. The Prime Minister failed to mention the need for employment.

He mentioned many bureaucratic services. From experience, I can tell the House that these vaunted initiatives were part of the problem. Education and health, despite large amounts of money thrown at them, are going backwards. I spend a disproportionate amount of my time trying to protect Aboriginals from ATSIC itself. I want to take Aboriginals forward with us into the future. I want for them the material benefits I want for my children and for all Australians.

I note that Sir Ronald, Mick Dodson et al want a board set up to administer compensation. Of course they do. They see it as just another carriage on the gravy train they are so used to riding. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) wants the government to spend $1 billion on compensation when the government has earmarked that money for the benefit of all Australians. If there is to be any compensation at all, it should come from savings made by the abolition of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
This report is so guilt driven and so predictable that it deserves scant consideration. Truly, Sir Ronald Wilson is a fool. Given the craven nature of our media, the fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—There is nothing unparliamentary about that. The fact that he has the face and the demeanour of a fool will not protect us. What we need, 30 years on, is another referendum, so that the people of Australia can offer a direction that is not forthcoming from the government—and even less so from the ALP.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to spend my grievance debate speech discussing this report. I come at it from probably completely the opposite end of the spectrum to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). If we have anything in common, it is our sincerity, even though we have a different way of approaching it.

SPEECH.PARA: Bringing them home, the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children From Their Families, is a report that ought to be read by every member of the parliament. The nation stum bled last week, both in terms of the premature public release of the report and the way in which its subsequent tabling in the parliament was handled here by both sides of parliament. Attempts at point scoring, not only in this place but also by sections of the media, diminished not only the pain which is the almost 700 pages of this report but also us in this parliament, and the ease with which we retreat into the all too familiar ideological posturing and personal invective that characterises much of the debate.

Those wanting to rediscover in themselves their own humanity need read only a few pages of the testimonies. I found myself in tears on more than one occasion, as I was struck not only by what these people had endured but by their courage in being able to tell it. Like so many things done in the past, it was done in some cases with the best of intentions. Governments, churches and non‐government organisations believed that seemingly impoverished children would have a better life in a white, superior, modern culture. There was also a belief that those who were half‐caste were in some way set free from the rest of society, and their only hope was to be incorporated into the dominant culture. For others, though, the intent was to subsume Aboriginal culture into that of the dominant Anglo‐Saxon one.

That many Aboriginal children forcibly removed, or coerced under duress, did not even have the chance to say goodbye and, in some cases, endured years of maltreatment and abuse should be a source of national shame. The report and its wrenching stories will evoke in each of us different emotions. Many, including the member for Kalgoorlie, have spoken of guilt and the assignment of it to our generation and to those who will come after us. To do so is wrong. But those who do not feel a sense of shame, which is quite a different emotion from guilt, whilst celebrating the extraordinary achievements of the 220 years since European settlement, risk building a future which alienates a significant section of society.

The entire process of the inquiry has been of therapeutic value to many of those who testified to it. In a number of cases, it was the first time in which, with palpable anguish and thin pain, the stories had been told. I would like to read a couple of those stories. One, which was not related directly to the inquiry but which was reported in the book by Stuart Ritoul of 1993 called The Wailing, reads:

In 1902 the chief protector of Aborigines in Western Australia, Henry Charles Princep, said he believed that it was the government's duty to place children of mixed dissent in missions to be trained to become useful workers and humble labourers. He complained in his annual report that the natural affections of the mothers stood much in his way.
A father who wrote a letter to the department in 1903 said:

I am afraid that my wife will commit suicide if the boy is not back soon for she is good for nothing—only cry day and night. I have as much love for my dear wife and children as you have for yours. So if you have any feeling at all please send the boy back as quick as you can. It did not take long for him to go but it takes a long time for him to come back.
Evidence No. 821, on page 6 of the report, reads:

I was at the post office with my Mum and Auntie [and cousin]. They put us in the police ute and said they were taking us to Broome. They put the mums in there as well. But when we'd gone [about ten miles] they stopped, and threw the mothers out of the car. We jumped on our mothers' backs, crying, trying not to be left behind. But the policemen pulled us off and threw us back in the car. They pushed the mothers away and drove off, while our mothers were chasing the car, running and crying after us. We were screaming in the back of that car. When we got to Broome they put me and my cousin in the Broome lock‐up. We were only ten years old. We were in the lock‐up for two days waiting for the boat to Perth.
Whatever the motive, as a nation we need to understand our past if there is to be any hope at all of embracing a confident future.

When I addressed a meeting about Aboriginal health a couple of months ago in the New South Wales parliament, a very conservative young Liberal approached me and said, `I thought all this Aboriginal affairs stuff was a load of nonsense until I was listening to the ABC's PM program last week and I heard a little bit of a woman telling her story.' He said, `I had to pull over to the side of the road, and I cried uncontrollably for 10 minutes.'

Radical though it may be, I respectfully suggest to the House that an Aboriginal man and an Aboriginal woman be invited to a joint sitting of this parliament to tell their stories of unimaginable pain and anguish that too few Australians have heard and even fewer understand. The reason I suggest that is that, like that young member of the Liberal Party who told me that he thought this was all a load of nonsense until he actually heard it, I think there are many people in this place who actually have to hear these stories told, not through the prism of some of the activists in the reconciliation movement but by the very people who lived this pain. The symbolism would be powerful, and it might just play a catalytic role in healing wounds deeper than the current national psyche can allow to easily heal.

I do not support compensation. I ask myself, `What good would it do? How can a cheque compensate you for losing your inner-self?' Also, I suggest it would light a fire under the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) that we have not yet seen and would further divide an already divided country—divided in sections at least.

I have also found over the years in dealing with those who are seeking litigation against doctors for medical misadventure that what they wanted much more than any financial compensation was for the doctor to understand their grief, to understand what they had been through and to apologise for what he or she had done. Let us not be blind to injustice nor deaf to despair. This report demands a measured, thoughtful and detailed response, not the kind of precipitant response that the opposition has sought of the government over the last week. It should rise above the behaviour which all too often typifies our day-to-day political debates in this place.

One of my colleagues said to me that he felt that over the last week and the last few months reconciliation had faltered. In fact, I think reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians has a much greater chance of success. Up until recently I had felt that it was nothing more than badges, glossy posters and a whole lot of platitudes which meant very little to the everyday Australian. What has happened with the release of this report—hopefully, they will be able to repeat their testimonies in this place—is a forcing of the everyday Australian to ask themselves the question which ought to start here and cascade throughout the rest of the country, that is, `How would I feel if this were done to me?'

It is not a question of our generation or subsequent ones carrying guilt. Rather, it is about carrying an understanding of what was done, why it was done and its consequences on those people and their families, if not on the rest of the nation. Financial compensation will do nothing to address that. I would suggest to you that it would make it worse.

What we need overall is a deficit reduction strategy on existential Aboriginal despair, intolerance, prejudice and living standards that no Australians should condone. I commend to the House and to the parliament the suggestion that we do something extraordinary for a group of people who suffered extraordinary injustice and that we ask a couple of them to repeat their stories.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr ADAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues that I would like to bring to the House's attention today in this grievance debate. The first is an exciting new initiative happening in Tasmania. Previously, Tasmania's clean green image has been to do with air and water and, supposedly, its farming. However, just like the rest of Australia, Tasmanian farms use chemicals and have lots of chemical inputs in their production.

SPEECH.PARA: A new company, Green Life Tasmania, will see this `clean green' image restored to the state. The company is in the process of trialling a totally organic rain farm and dairy in the state's far north-west corner, where the world's purest rainwater is proven to drench the soil. Green Life Tasmania intends to collect the water and milk and market them worldwide. They are involved in teaching how to use natural resources to bring life back into the soils.

BREAK.PARA: The bottom line of making things green and clean is to go totally organic, otherwise you have no credence whatsoever. The Liberal government in Tasmania has made `clean green' their policy over the last few weeks, with a total lack of direction. They cannot possibly label products `clean green' when they have been saturated to the heavens with chemicals.

Green Life Tasmania will use the organic fertiliser Vitec and use previously unfarmed soils for its farms. It will be the first truly chemically free, large scale clean green farm, teaching the government to practice what it preaches. This was brought to my attention by Sari Schmidt, a Mount Carmel student from Hobart, who is in the parliament today. I thank her for giving me the opportunity to make those comments.

I would also like to raise another matter, a very serious issue, and draw it to the House's attention—that is, the plight that Tasmania finds itself in. I believe it is because of the withdrawal of considerable amounts of federal funds, the fact that the marketplace has failed in Tasmania and the fact that the current Tasmanian Liberal government does not have a clue about how to stimulate any growth in our economy.

One of the headlines in the Hobart Mercury newspaper on Tuesday, 27 May was that Tasmanians are in peril. The state's population forecast is to drop 11 per cent in the next 50 years. We currently have a population of fewer than half a million, and this means a decline in the number of people in Tasmania by 55,000. Those who remain will have an average age far greater than the national average. This is of particular concern to me in Lyons because the loss of population is most likely to affect the people in the smaller towns. They are the ones who are desperately seeking work. Young people are leaving in droves for interstate because there is nothing happening in our economy.

All the state government has come up with is a scheme to try to attract people to come and live in the state. When a number of people have approached the government to see what it has to offer, the reply has been a lovely glossy brochure with all sorts of pretty pictures and a prize of an odd piece of land should their names be pulled out of a hat at some point in the future. The government added to this some technological dream the Premier had of providing a technological centre based on something happening in New Brunswick in Canada. The idea is basically okay, but it is not the saviour for the state of Tasmania.

Contrast this with what South Australia is offering, which is an all expenses paid removal plus some subsidised accommodation until people settle themselves in; and, if people were serious about changing states for just lifestyle, it would be more of a conducive offer. I think Jim Bacon, the new opposition leader in Tasmania, hit the nail on the head when he recently responded to this government's flights of fantasy by saying that piecemeal population drives and a focus on one emerging industry would not halt the population decline.

Bells, whistles and pretty pictures do not provide jobs, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker. The government has come up with some incentives. The federal government has given Tasmania away and our federal government members are just letting it. They are not saying anything to stop what this federal government is doing to Tasmania. The state government is no better. All they can do is blame Pauline Hanson. This argument is going to wear thin. She is not responsible for the economic ills of Tasmania; she is merely another symptom of the discontent and disillusionment of the Tasmanian people.

Money has to be invested in industry plans, in infrastructure and in regional development if the Tasmanian economy is to survive. We need a proper transport system, which includes rail. The present minister is selling the whole caboodle of it without really understanding or fitting it into any sort of planning situation for the Tasmanian transport system. We need to have a transport system which includes rail, sea and air. We need the freight equalisation scheme to remain, which is under challenge by this government, which is gradually being pulled away. We need a second ship to transport goods and tourists. We need to stop mucking around with the councils, with our local municipalities, and help them organise themselves with an economic base.

Tasmania has a lot to offer, but it cannot compete with the rest of Australia without the same sorts of initiatives that other states enjoy. The state government really has to analyse the true nature of the problems in Tasmania. We thought we had a bit of an opportunity for this to occur with the Nixon report. Mr Peter Nixon, who was a long-term member of this House and served in coalition governments, is doing a report or updating our previous economic statement, the Callaghan report.

The Premier's direction statement came out without reference, as far as we know, to the Nixon report. So we are left with a few tired politicians chasing pipedreams that cannot possibly come to anything, the latest being Tasmania's belated push to have the Antarctic treaty nation secretariat established in Hobart, against the federal government's better judgment. What about some new ideas, folks? How about assisting the industries we already have? There are plenty of ideas there. With a little constructive help and support from such bodies as Tasmanian Development and Resources, some emerging resources could actually take off and make jobs for the state. Incat has done it. Others can too.

Jobs will strengthen the economy and then there will be some incentives for people. Young people need those incentives to remain in Tasmania and we need incentives to attract others also. You know what they say about rats deserting a sinking ship? The state is sinking and the federal government has scuttled the lifeboats. Tasmania does need a rescue mission.

In recent changes to the upper house in Tasmania, we at last have two women in that formerly male bastion. I believe this is the beginning of change in Tasmania. Silvia Smith, once the federal Labor member for Bass, now has another victory under her belt, and I congratulate her on her election to the Tasmanian upper house last weekend. Mike Aird, another ALP member, retained his seat of Derwent, which is part of the federal electorate of Lyons, with an increased majority of the Labor vote. Sue Smith has also been elected to the upper house after a distinguished career in local government.

Tasmania is ripe for change and the Labor Party's new leader, Jim Bacon, will lead a young and energetic party to victory whenever the next state election is held. They will be looking for a future for Tasmania that will seek to help the people who have a vision for the state—help them and their enterprises become the backbone to encourage new things to happen and entice people to settle in our state. We do not need any more tinkering around the edges. We need some decisions to be made to get our state back on track. We can only do that with a future state Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There was arguably no-one more pleased with the passing of the bill for the sale of one-third of Telstra than me. The main reason for my pleasure at this announcement was the making available of $1.25 billion for the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia. The House and the community are now aware that the objects of the trust are: to provide a framework to stimulate a strategic investment in the natural environment; to achieve environmental protection, natural resource management and sustainable agricultural outcomes; and to provide a framework for cooperation between the community and all tiers of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Among the many vital environmental issues to be tackled is that of a national land and water audit. Effective management of any resource requires the recording of its quantity and condition to enable periodic reviews. Despite the seriousness of land and water degradation in Australia, there has not been a comprehensive record kept to allow accurate assessment over a period of time.

The Natural Heritage Trust will provide $37 million for the national land and water audit, with $7.5 million to be expended during 1997-98. These funds will be managed by an independent board to provide the first com prehensive appraisal of the environmental, social and economic costs of land and water degradation to the nation. Under this audit, the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, in my electorate of Riverina, which is the most secure and proven irrigation environment in Australia, will benefit.

Irrigation uses more than 73 per cent of Australia's commanded water resources to grow nearly $6 billion worth of produce. This figure multiplies significantly when activities outside the farm gate, supported by this production, are considered.

The Murrumbidgee irrigation scheme, which has been in existence for more than 80 years, is starting to feel its age and is in need of refurbishment—not only because of the problems developing within the MIA but also for those living downstream of the MIA area. In the light of research and new technology now available, it is in a position to make the adjustments that will enable it to provide sustainable agricultural production into the future.

As with many longstanding irrigation schemes, the major problems to be overcome in the MIA are rising water tables and excessive drainage. One organisation that has been doing something practical about preparing a plan for the future wellbeing of the MIA is the working group of the MIA and district land and water management plan. This plan was first discussed at a public meeting in August 1991 and the responsibility for developing the plan was given to a working group of 10 community members and three New South Wales state government employees under the able chairmanship of Mr John Bonetti. The group was drawn from a wide cross-section of the local community and embraces irrigators comprising both mixed farmers and horticulturalists, dryland farmers and graziers. It includes people who are familiar with both the upstream and downstream nature of the problems of the MIA.

Since 1991, that group has worked tirelessly to resolve the MIA's land and water management problems, and in January this year the draft plan was made available to the community for comments and guidance—to see if there were solutions that had been overlooked and to seek the best way to put these solutions in place. This draft plan brings together only the upstream studies and it is hoped that the downstream studies will be completed soon.

After receiving additional submissions, the final plan should be available before the end of the year. The plan has been prepared on the assumption that the New South Wales government will provide a financial grant to maintain and/or replace the existing water supply and drainage, given the creation of the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Corporation.

Before the implementation of this plan, the New South Wales government wants a rigorous economic evaluation to ensure an acceptable return to the taxpayers of New South Wales. It is proposed that Murrumbidgee Irrigation should implement the plan; however, there is some feeling that the local community would have more confidence in the plan if it were implemented by a representative community group.

Whatever the final plan contains or whoever administers the refurbishment and changes in practices, the working group is to be congratulated on its endeavours. I believe it has done an excellent job to proceed to this point, despite some of the conflicting points of view that it has received from individuals and powerful lobby groups that have a particular interest to guard or promote. As we say in the MIA, there are more headaches in a barrel of water than in a barrel of whiskey.

The committee has almost completed its job and some hard decisions will still have to be made. Then it will be up to both the federal and state governments to assist, as they both have a large financial interest and investment in the region. The plan requests a further 15 years of financial commitment to the project. It is my hope that the federal government, through the Natural Heritage Trust, the Federation Fund or some other funding arrangement, will allocate money to provide a benefit both to the state and to the nation.

With the restructuring of the CSIRO from 1 February, three divisions—that is, Soils, Water and Environmental Mechanics—have merged to become CSIRO Land and Water. A committee led by Mr Arthur Blewett, the Principal Chief Adviser of Corporation Development, was established to make recommendations about the merger. Mr Blewett recommended the formation of a CSIRO National Centre for Irrigation Science in Griffith.

In announcing the recommendation in November 1996, Mr Blewett said that, in creating a new Centre for Irrigation Science in Griffith, the merger committee saw an opportunity to foster the development of an industry based on irrigation technology and know‐how. A report in the Land on 23 January 1997 reads this way:

A top level CSIRO report has recommended the CSIRO's Division of Water Resources' Griffith site become a national irrigation research centre, in partnership with the Charles Sturt University and Victoria's Department of Natural Resources and Environment.
The recommendation was made to the CSIRO executive committee and overturns earlier speculation that a CSIRO reshuffle could mean the downgrading or even closure of the Hanwood site, near Griffith.

Under the recommendations, the facility would become a National Centre for Irrigation Science and would focus on irrigation throughout Australia, broadening its outlook and providing a greater focus on northern irrigation.

However, although the recommendation to have the new centre has been agreed to in principle, it would still need the approval by the yet to be appointed chief executive of CSIRO's new Land and Water Resources Division.

Under the move, the local CSIRO site would get an extra four irrigation scientists, from its current level of four to five, but could lose scientists in river and wetland management areas, who would move to Canberra where the Rivers and Wetlands Division would be headquartered.
According to Arthur Blewett, principal adviser, CSIRO corporate development, the new centre would provide economies of scale, but the Hanwood site's new status would not mean any funding increases.
In other words, this plan of the CSIRO is an opportunity for Griffith to become the key centre in Australia for the development and export of irrigation expertise and technology.

It goes without saying that the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area—as I said before, the most secure and proven of irrigation environments in Australia—is the place that is most central to future research and education for the irrigation sector. It should be pointed out that, in the past, the CSIRO laboratory in Griffith has undertaken research of importance to Australia, and internationally it already has established close working relationships with Israel, China and the United States, amongst others.

The former CSIRO Division of Water Resources, and Charles Sturt University Professor of Irrigation, Professor Wayne Meyer—about the same time as the announce ment about the Centre of Irrigation Science being located in Griffith was made—put forward a paper outlining the aims of a National Centre for Irrigation and Research and Training at Charles Sturt University.

The recommendation of the CSIRO, which embraces the establishment of a chair of irrigation sciences at CSU, provides opportunity for the CSIRO, the peak scientific organisation of Australia located in Griffith and a university located in Wagga Wagga to be central to the practical development of a `green machine' for Australia.

Since Dr Blewett announced the centre at Griffith, the merger of Soils, Water and Environmental Mechanics has taken place, and the new division is to be one of the most powerful within the CSIRO. Unfortunately, however, neither state nor federal government has picked up on Dr Blewett's announcement. No comment has been forthcoming from either the Premier of New South Wales or anyone in the federal government about what is happening in Griffith.

Professor Meyer has stated that Australia has the potential to take over from Israel in the fields of leading irrigation technology for the world, and it is seen as complementary that the New South Wales government has already established its Centre for Irrigation at Hanwood, a short distance from the CSIRO Land and Water Laboratory. This could be an exciting prospect for New South Wales, if not for Australia, as it combines educational research with an opportunity to carry out studies on some of the most technologically advanced horticultural and agricultural blocks in Australia, if not the world.

BREAK.PARA: Given the importance of irrigation to the nation, I am trusting that the announcement made by Dr Arthur Blewett, the Principal Chief Adviser of Corporation Development, about the establishment of a CSIRO National Centre of Irrigated Science in Griffith will soon be confirmed by some action. We are all aware there is a big job to be done and we have little time to waste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the following report entitled Development of No. 6 Squadron facilities at RAAF Base Amberley, Qld .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The report which I have tabled concerns the proposed development of facilities for No. 6 Squadron at RAAF Base Amberley in Queensland. The Department of Defence proposes to construct new facilities adjacent to the existing apron and hangars for the operation, servicing and maintenance of F111 aircraft at RAAF Base Amberley.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal examined by the committee is intended to provide an integrated facility for the various operational elements of No. 6 Squadron, which include an operational reconnaissance and strike capability as well as aircrew conversion and training functions. The proposal will provide office accommodation, mission briefing and training rooms, storage facilities and workshops as well as associated amenities for a unit strength of 180 personnel.
When referred to the committee the estimated out‐turn cost of the proposed work was $10.25 million. The committee has recommended that the works should proceed.

No. 6 Squadron is one of two squadrons equipped with F111 strike and reconnaissance aircraft. The squadron is responsible for F111 aircrew conversion training and the provision of an operational strike and reconnaissance capability.

Until recently, there was some uncertainty about the life of type of F111. This uncertainty, and higher facilities priorities, delayed the provision of modern facilities for the squadron until now. With the benefit of numerous studies into the life of type of the F111, an avionics upgrade and the purchase of additional attrition and rotation aircraft, Defence now believes the aircraft will remain in service for many years. It is estimated that the life of type will expire in 15 to 20 years.

Both the aircraft and squadron personnel represent a substantial equipment and training investment by the taxpayers of Australia. The aircraft themselves are a sophisticated conventional deterrent force. I must say that the Public Works Committee was impressed not only with the briefing at Amberley but with the additional information made available about the capacity of the F111 and the sort of entrepreneurial spirit that had characterised Defence's upgrade of the F111 into a modern fighting aircraft.

BREAK.PARA: Based on extensive inspections of facilities housing squadron activities, the committee concluded that facilities at RAAF Base Amberley occupied by No. 6 Squadron are inadequate due to their dispersed locations, age and condition. There is therefore a need to provide new purpose built facilities for No. 6 Squadron's existing command, administrative, technical and training functions at RAAF Base Amberley.

The proposed facilities will be at two locations. The new No. 6 Squadron facilities will be in hangar annexes and new buildings contiguous to Hangar 373 and the storage of F111 attrition or rotation aircraft will be in two existing Bellman hangars.

The committee concluded that the proposed scope of the works can be justified as being consistent with the functional requirements for squadron facilities. The committee also concluded that design features to be adopted are consistent with functional requirements and recognise the need to comply with relevant standards and codes. The scope of the proposed works capitalises on the adaptive re‐use of existing hangars.

A master plan has been developed for the future development of RAAF Base Amberley with which the proposed works are consistent. Careful phasing of the works will minimise disruption to the continued operation of No. 6 Squadron during construction.

On the basis of evidence received, the committee has therefore recommended that the development of facilities for No. 6 Squadron at RAAF Base Amberley should proceed. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue my speech on the budget. This government has dedicated substantial resources to address Aboriginal health, education and employment issues. We will guarantee funding levels for ATSIC for four years, giving them greater program flexibility and more financial security. In particular, there will be some additional funding going to employment and business development.

SPEECH.PARA: We see economic independence and self-determination as a key to the future wellbeing of indigenous Australians. Their health, education, employment and housing continue to be below the standards of the average Australian. We aim to fix that.

We must stand condemned in the eyes of this and future generations if we do not take practical steps to ensure a decent life experience for all Australians. We must frame policies that are just, and genuinely deliver the outcomes which our indigenous people identify as their priorities.

We need to ensure that this generation understands the history of the conquest of Australia, not so they come to feel guilt about the frontier actions but so they can understand the struggles between blacks, whites and Asians who fought for a share of the resources as they established a new nation. Better understanding of the experiences of the different races should help us to become a more just and equitable society in the future.

The establishment of European settlement across Australia tended to follow a pattern first set around Sydney. Governor Phillip was, at first, friendly to the indigenes, hoping to learn about the country from them.
