Within five months of taking over their fishing and hunting grounds, however, he observed that the natives were starving and attacking the convicts who stole their boats and artefacts. Two years after landing, in February 1790, Governor Phillip estimated that nearly half of those living locally had died of a smallpox type disease. Two‐and‐a‐half years after, in December 1790, he gave orders that any 10 natives be captured and beheaded in response to the spearing of his gamekeeper. He supplied bags and hatchets for that purpose.

In May 1816 a military force was defending settlers while Governor Macquarie made a proclamation of native outlawing, placing £10 sterling on the heads of 10 named warriors to be captured dead or alive. By 1836 the first protectorates were set up to keep the tribal remnants away from the settlements. Native police, in particular, did battle with the surviving Aboriginal nations. Typically unpaid, taken from the gaols where many faced death sentences and starved and beaten if they attempted to escape their white officers, these native police—in particular in Queensland—brought their superior bush skills to play in locating and defeating the enemy. For those who want to know more about the role of the native police, you will find their achievements and conditions described in the 1861 royal commission in the Queensland parliament's Votes and Proceedings.

Captain Cook's failure to treaty with the natives in 1770, despite his official instructions, meant the survivors of the land wars had no rights as refugees or as defeated enemies of the Crown. Tribesmen captured during the campaigns and skirmishes were tried and gaoled or hung by colonial courts as common criminals—as thieves and murderers. They were not extended the rights of prisoners of war—as soldiers captured in battle.

For more than a century the new Australian settlers were taught in schools that the Aboriginal population did not fight to retain their lands; they simply sickened and died away when confronted with the pressures and infections of `civilisation'. I learnt this same message when I went to school. Thus, Aboriginal people were emasculated in the minds of the majority. They were not afforded the respect of those who stand up and appear to fight for their rights.

As the defeated tribal remnants starved and succumbed to disease and despair, the newly emerging Darwinian concepts of 1859 and the 1860s were reinterpreted to rationalise the death rates, sickness and dependency as evidence of innate biological racial inferiority. The so‐called `full bloods' were expected to die out like the extinct dodos. Hence the health, education and employment policies for the survivors of the armed struggles for the land were for years distilled into the annual presentation of a blanket on his or her majesty's birthday—a gift from the colonial government.

Following the era of armed struggle, the survivors of the defeated Aboriginal nations were looked to for cheap or slave labour, especially in areas where few white workers would venture. The following two statements, both in the official records of 1913, present the attitudes to Aboriginal labour that underpinned official remuneration and training policies. Mr W. E. Dalton, accountant and honorary secretary of the Aboriginal Friends Association, stated in evidence in the 1913 South Australian royal commission into Aboriginal issues:

You have to bear in mind that 60 years ago the natives were practically animals crawling about in the bush. The half‐castes are their children and usually also the children of the most depraved class of white men. They have not the heredity that other races have, and you cannot expect them to work on purely industrial lines. If you are going to have a four hour working day I think that the native could work beside the white man. He could not keep working for eight hours.
On the other hand, Professor Baldwin Spencer wrote in his preliminary report on Aboriginals in the Northern Territory, prepared for the Department of External Affairs in 1913:

. . . while it is true that, in some parts the aboriginal gives trouble, it is equally true that at the present day, practically all the cattle stations are dependent on their labour, and in fact could not get on without it, any more than the police constables could. They do work that it would be very difficult to get white men to do and do it not only cheerfully but for a remuneration that in many cases makes all the difference at the present time between working the station at a profit or a loss.

So we have the rationalisation of economic exploitation on the grounds that the worker is incapable of sustained work, despite the realities of Aboriginal participation in the work force at that time and often for no pay.

In 1913, in sworn evidence at the royal commission in South Australia, we see housing conditions described as being inadequate at Point McLeay and better conditions being recommended. But this benevolence was undermined with the question from the honourable J. Jelly, who said:
If the natives are given the conditions you speak of is there any likelihood of their increasing in numbers, so as to become a very great burden on the State?
In reply, he was assured by E. C. Stirling:

That is a legitimate inquiry, but I think that the experience of all the world over is that the black races die out in the presence of the white races. I do not think that what you say is a serious contingency. I think that with all you can do you cannot keep them beyond a certain time.

This same Mr Stirling then expounds on the virtues of separating the Aboriginal children of mixed descent from their parents in order to save them from going `back to the ways of the natives'. The Hon. Mr J. Jelly asked:
What would be a suitable age to remove them?
Mr Stirling replied:
I think when they are about two or three years of age.
The chairman, on hearing this, then asked Mr Stirling:
You would not recommend that they were taken away when they are absolute infants?
Mr Stirling said:

BREAK.PARA: No: because then you would have the burden of them that all children are at such a young age. When they are a couple of years of age they do not require so much attention and they are young enough to be attractive.
He is then asked:
Do you think that their experience of two years with the black mother would seriously interfere with them?
Mr Stirling responds:

No. There would not be time for them to establish habits and customs. I am quite aware that you are depriving the mothers of their children, and the mothers are very fond of their children, but I think it must be the rising generation who have to be considered. They are the people who are going to live on.

Thus we see the royal commission considering the so‐called `rescue' of a generation whose mother's race was thought to be dooming them to extinction. However, it was to be a cheap rescue, which took place only when the babies had advanced out of nappies and on to solid foods, when they were two or so years of age, after their biological mothers had dealt with the inconvenience of their infancy.

Over the next 70 years, Australia's miscegenation policies took thousands of children from Aboriginal mothers. The consequences for generations of Aboriginal people were the loss of physical and emotional wellbeing, the loss of personal and cultural identity, and economic exploitation.
At the royal commission in Western Australia in 1927 into the killing and burning of Aboriginals in East Kimberley, the Reverend Gribble, head of the Forrest River Mission, observed the following:

At present the native is not the asset of the state, he is rather the asset of the individual who, shall I say, possesses him. I need only remind your worship that it costs only 5 shillings to obtain a permit to employ an aboriginal, which in the North carries no wages with it, while on the other hand, it costs 7 shillings and sixpence to register a dog.
One year later, in 1928, J.W. Bleakly, Chief Protector of Aborigines, reported that:

. . . one fact is universally admitted, that the pastoral industry in the territories is absolutely dependent upon the blacks for the labour, domestic and field, necessary to successfully carry on. If they were removed, some of the holdings, especially the smaller ones, would have to be abandoned.
He went on to say:

It is remarkable that, although recognizing their absolute dependence upon the natives, there has been no attempt made by the people on these holdings to elevate or educate them, though this should enhance their value as machinery.
He added that, in particular, the Aboriginal woman:
. . . is one of the greatest pioneers for the territories, for without her it would have been impossible for a white man to have carried on.

These were the same enslaved and often sexually exploited women, denied an education or training, whose babies were taken in order that they be `rescued' from a life of poverty and degradation. If time permitted, I would quote the lack of funding and the cruelty and indifference found in so many of the half‐caste institutions that these babies were committed to, but the just released findings of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families says it all.

In 1964, the Northern Territory's legislative council abolished the concept of protective wardship for the majority of the territory's 18,000 Aboriginals of full descent. This entitled them to drink alcohol and cohabit with whites. However, the question of paying award wages, unemployment and sickness entitlements at the same rate as to others in society, was deferred.

The report Bringing them home, just released and just tabled in parliament, is a substantial and significant report. It documents the tragedy of Australian black‐white relations—how we denied the most basic human rights to individuals over generations: the right to belong to a family, to be safe and loved, and to know whence we came. Our government is yet to give its detailed response to this report. When that happens, I know it will be an appropriate response.

In the 1970s, I spent a number of years researching the evolution of our race policy, and it led me to work for years to overcome prejudice and ignorance about our race relations history. That general misunderstanding continues. It is essential that we as a nation dedicate the right policies and adequate expenditure to overcoming centuries of damage done to Aboriginal people in the process of European settlement and the exploitation of their labour. To get these policies right, we must listen to and learn from Aboriginal people, those people who miraculously survived with their culture, to inform and enrich our great Australian society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —That speech is perhaps the latest example of why some people on this side of the House believe the honourable member for Murray (Mrs Stone) is destined for promotion in the not too distant future. I commend her on the quality and content of her contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I will also pick up on a few of the comments she made. I do not know if she had a chance to see the recent ABC television documentary series called Frontier, which was shown over a three‐week period and contained a lot of background information on the land battles between European settlers and Aboriginal nations over quite an extended period, including the period she mentioned in her contribution. In my own part of the world, a bit to the north of the New South Wales central coast, there were two quite infamous incidents—at Waterloo Creek and near the Myall Lake region—which were well‐recorded at the time. Large numbers of Aborigines, including Aboriginal women and children, lost their lives in terrible circumstances.

I hope that one day all members of this House will understand that this is not a matter of guilt. Both the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the former Prime Minister have said that guilt is not a very productive feeling. It is not just a matter of guilt; it is more an obligation to face up to our past and to try to make sure that we acknowledge the truth, as the honourable member has tonight, and to express the nation's regret. That is the first step before we can move to a more national reconciliation of all these issues. I commend the honourable member for Murray for her contribution.

BREAK.PARA: But my job tonight is to return to some of the issues more directly covered by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in his budget a few weeks ago. First of all, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) described this budget as the budget of the Sheriff of Nottingham. You can understand why, because it does take a Sheriff of Nottingham to design a budget which slugs the elderly and the chronically ill by forcing them to pay more for their essential medicines. The government uses those savings from the elderly and the chronically ill to help fund a new savings rebate which gives $450 to people wealthy enough to have $60,000 in the bank.

It also takes a Sheriff of Nottingham to design a budget which claims it is trying to increase national saving by giving a family of battlers with $3,000 in the bank a savings rebate of only $13 while giving the Treasurer who designed the budget $450 for doing nothing. It takes a Sheriff of Nottingham to design a budget which cuts federal funding for public hospitals while giving families on the BRW rich list $450 for each family mem ber who may receive income from a family trust. Finally, it takes a Sheriff of Nottingham to give us a budget which cannot find an extra dollar for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health while giving the directors of BHP a $450 tax rebate for the capital gain they received when BHP shares rose after those same directors announced the closure of the Newcastle steelworks. A bit later I will return to some of the decisions in this budget that affect health and, in particular, the government's decision to impose a new tax on new drugs and the failure of the government's private health insurance policy.

Whatever we might think about the Sheriff of Nottingham's role in history, at least he could make a decision. Under this government, we have a Prime Minister who cannot make a decision, who stumbles from crisis to crisis, delaying and putting off decisions. Australia is the country that suffers. We have had the Prime Minister fail on employment, unable to make a decision on cross‐media ownership rules, afraid to stand up to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) on immigra tion, unable to stand up to the NFF and the National Party on Wik and unable to say sorry to people affected by the removal of Aboriginal children over many generations.

Let me begin on unemployment. This government predicted in the last budget that there would be sufficient growth in our national economy for us to reduce the level of unemployment in Australia. In the nine months since last year's budget was brought down, the rate of growth of the national economy has been scaled back on two occasions. It keeps getting scaled back because, under this government, the economy is as flat as a pancake.

Figures in today's Financial Review indicate that retail spending, in seasonally adjusted terms, is down dramatically. That is because people are worried about entering into large spending commitments because they are uncertain of their jobs and their economic future. This government has been unable to introduce greater confidence into the Australian economy. It has been unable to reduce the level of unemployment. In fact, after having promised lower unemployment, this government has delivered an increase in unemployment and, in particular, an increase in the number of the long-term unemployed—the people who find it hardest to get back into the work force.

It is because the economy has been as flat as a pancake, because unemployment is up, because retail spending is down and because the long-term unemployed rate is up that everyone who has a job does not know whether or not the government will be able to pull the economy out of this stagnation that it has fallen into. That is why Mr Smug, the Treasurer, keeps getting up here month after month—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the honourable member should refer to the member's electorate or his office.

—Mr Smug, the Treasurer—the man who day after day in MPIs here is described in that way—is the person who announces interest rate cuts as if they are something that he should be proud of. What he does not realise is that the Reserve Bank is forced to lower interest rates because the economy remains flat.
—Do you like high interest rates—24 per cent?

—The honourable minister at the table does not understand that the reason the Treasurer gets to announce these reductions is that the economy is stalled. You have to cut interest rates because unemployment keeps going up. You have to cut interest rates because the rate of economic growth is falling lower and lower.

BREAK.PARA: We all know we need about four per cent growth a year just to keep the current level of unemployment where it is. If the Financial Review is right and we are falling back to only a little bit more than half of that, it guarantees that we will have higher unemployment next year than this year. It guarantees that the economy will remain as flat as a pancake and that we do not get the new jobs we need for young Australians and we do not get the new jobs we need in future years for those middle‐aged Australians who might lose their jobs in Newcastle as a result of recent decisions.

When this government was advised by BHP that they were going to close the steelworks at Newcastle, one of the major employers in the Hunter region, what was the response of the government? The Prime Minister could not pick up the telephone, and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) put the opening of the casino in Melbourne ahead of a public meeting in Newcastle to discuss the crisis.

The Prime Minister, knowing what damage he suffered, rushed on to A Current Affair with Ray Martin to promise the people of Newcastle that he would visit them soon. They were the words he used: `I will visit the people of Newcastle soon.' A month has gone by and the Prime Minister of Australia announces—eight weeks or more after the announced closure of the Newcastle steelworks and after the Prime Minister has been to a cricket test at Lord's in England—that he will find the time to go to Newcastle and explain to those people why he could not pick up the telephone and was not prepared to use the power vested in his office to do more than he did to save the jobs for the people in Newcastle.

It is not just an issue of the need for Australia to have a steel industry; it is also about cars. The Prime Minister keeps saying that it would be unthinkable for Australia not to have a car industry. People like Jeff Kennett and the federal Labor Party are saying, `What we do not want to see is the unthinkable thing happening. What we do not want to see is this government continue to delay making a decision on the future of the automobile industry in Australia.'

It is an industry which, under the car plan developed during the years that John Button was the industry minister, has had to undergo some pretty tough rationalisation. The Button plan tried to increase the throughput for each of the models in Australia. It was also about trying to generate additional exports. The car industry has responded. We have seen a dramatic turnaround in the level of exports of fully built cars. That has been a great achievement of the Australian car industry. We have seen component manufacturers go ahead leaps and bounds, with factories right across Australia not only supplying components to the domestic Australian car manufacturers but also exporting automotive components right around the world.

It is those industries and jobs that are at risk every day that this government puts off making a decision on the future level of tariffs for this industry. It is those jobs and this industry that are at risk because John Howard will not listen to Jeff Kennett on what to do with the car industry. It is those jobs in this industry that are at risk because, for two months now, the government has refused to respond to the Labor Party's call that we freeze tariffs at 15 per cent until the year 2005.

That is the simple proposal that the opposition has put on the table. It is a proposal that we believe tries to guarantee that we keep that industry growing and exporting and employing those tens of thousands of Australians in years to come. That is the employment situation: a government and a Prime Minister unable to make a decision about the car industry; a Prime Minister embarrassed to go to Newcastle; and a Treasurer unable to give us more than two per cent economic growth.

The second area which is a good example of a government unable to make a decision is cross‐media ownership. The former Labor government introduced the cross‐media ownership rules, which basically mean that you cannot own a television station or a radio station and a newspaper in the same capital city. If Kerry Packer owns the Channel 9 stations in the major capital cities, his company cannot own the major newspapers in those cities. That is the case today. If Rupert Murdoch's company, News Ltd, owns most of the newspapers in the capital cities, under the cross-media ownership laws he cannot own television stations or radio stations in the same capital cities.

What could be fairer than that? Nothing. That is why many other countries also have those same prohibitions on common ownership of newspapers, radio stations and television stations in the same capital cities. In the mid-1980s, late 1986 into 1987, the former Labor government introduced those rules. John Howard said he was against those rules. Why, we will never know, but I will bet it had something to do with the fact that his friends at the Herald and Weekly Times and at John Fairfax were against those rules. For whatever reason, by 1991 John Howard was supporting the cross-media ownership rules. In 1991, John Howard put his name on the David Connolly petition that opposed any greater concentration in the media in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The Prime Minister signed the petition—thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Prime Minister of today, then a leading frontbencher in the opposition, John Howard, signed the petition which stated that they were against Kerry Parker buying 15 per cent of John Fairfax and the Tourang consortium. The Prime Minister did that because he said he was opposed to greater concentration in the Australian media. What do we get now? Before the last election we had John Howard saying—
—Order! The honourable member will not persist with using people's names. He will refer to the office that the member holds.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am afraid I am as bad at this as the Prime Minister, who did it several times in question time today. The Prime Minister said in 1995 that his view was that we should abolish the cross-media ownership rules and only rely on the Trade Practices Act. According to the chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, that would mean that there would be nothing to stop Mr Packer and Mr Murdoch buying more.

BREAK.PARA: What the Prime Minister said before the last election was that he would have a full public inquiry into this whole issue before any decisions were made. What happened to that promise? What happened to that promise by the now Prime Minister of Australia that he would have a full public inquiry before there was any decision taken by this government on cross-media ownership? As soon as he is elected, we get limp excuses as to why he would not have a public inquiry. As soon as the election is out the way, that is one of those disposable promises, not a core promise. The future of the media in Australia, the level of media diversity, is not a core promise, it is totally disposable, so there will be no public inquiry.

We have the Prime Minister embarrassingly fronting up on TV and radio programs mouthing Kerry Parker's arguments as to why the cross‐media ownership rules should be abolished. So we get no public inquiry despite the promise. We get the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) saying that they intended to ram the legislation through in this sitting of the parliament. That is what they briefed the backbench committee on. Everyone in this parliament knows that is what they intended to do. Thank God, there was such a public reaction to the Prime Minister's plans that he has been forced to back off. The Prime Minister has been unable to proceed with the plan to ram that legislation through during this sitting of the Australian parliament.

I just hope that those brave members of the Liberal and National parties who have had the courage to speak up continue to speak up and continue to make sure that the Prime Minister is kept to the statements that he made in 1991 when he said he was against any further concentration of the Australian media. It all comes down to a Prime Minister who is willing to dispose of the promises that get in his way.

In the time that is left to me, I wish to highlight one decision in particular that is included in this budget. It is the Prime Minister's decision to impose a new drugs tax—a new drugs tax that is going to affect a third of the spending on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In my opinion, this is economic rationalism gone mad.

This is the view that the government puts to us. The government says, `We're going to pick out six categories of drugs at random and the government subsidy will only be at the cheapest level for all the drugs in each of those six categories.' The categories involve three groups that control high blood pressure, one that controls high cholesterol, another for ulcers and another for depression. As I say, it is a third of all government spending on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and it is going to save more than $600 million. So it is a massive sum of money taken out of the government's scheme to make sure ordinary people can afford their medication.

While all the papers released by the government on budget night said that this involved drugs that were similar, a day or two after the budget the Prime Minister misled the House when he said that this involved only drugs that were of equal clinical value. That is the problem this Prime Minister has, because there are lots of drugs that have been listed since 1993 which, by law and by regulation, have to be different.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), who is at the table, runs the pharmaceutical scheme for veterans. He would understand that all of the drugs that have been listed since 1993 have to be shown to be so different, have to have many fewer side effects, that the cost effectiveness, the difference due to the different nature of the therapeutic action of the drugs, justifies the price difference at which they are listed.

For example, there is a drug called Norvasc, which has been proven by the government's own advisers to have a lower risk of cardiac failure for people who take that drug. Why should a pensioner be forced to take the cheaper drug that is older, that has more side effects, that does not work as well, simply because they are less well off? Why should someone, one of those BHP directors who gets the $450 for their savings as well as the benefit for closing the BHP steelworks, get the best possible drugs while the pensioner who might live in the Newcastle area cannot afford the best drugs that offer the least risk of cardiac failure?

There has even been the example of this in my own electorate. Mr David Schneider, who had a heart transplant some years ago, has written to me on his concerns about this issue. He is on four drugs that are covered by the six groups that the government has targeted under this new drugs tax, and he, quite rightly, is very uncertain as to the increase in his medication cost as a result of this unfair budget. We have had the AMA, not the Labor Party, say that people will be paying up to $30 a month more for their essential medication. I would hate to think how much ordinary Australians are going to have to pay for the right to use their essential medication.

For all of these reasons, we think this government is stumbling from crisis to crisis. We think this is a government that has been unable to show leadership on so many issues, most importantly jobs and employment. We think this is a government that should be doing more to try to ensure we have higher economic growth, generating more jobs—trying to make sure that young people have a better opportunity. It is a government that we think should be doing more to make sure that ordinary Australians do have a diverse media. It is a government that we think is implementing unfair cuts to the subsidies for essential medications for pensioners and ordinary families. It is a government that we think deserves censure. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity that this debate offers to discuss three broad areas which are being debated in the wider community; namely, trade, foreign investment and migration. These three areas are vital to Australia's standard of living and are particularly vital to those constituents who live in my electorate of Parkes, particularly my rural constituents. I appeal to everybody to take a broad view of what is needed on these matters if we are to understand them so that we can survive at our present, and hopefully increasing, standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: We live today in a world of rapid change, a world where there is an instantaneous exchange of information and capital between countries. We live in a world that is highly competitive, where the marketplaces will buy and sell at the best price, wherever it is available—the best deal. We have to get continually smarter and quicker with all of these things if we are not to go backwards. In fact, if we utilise these factors to our advantage we can only go forwards.

We have passed the era where we can live in isolation. We cannot insulate ourselves from the rest of the world if we are to go forwards. As much as some of us would like to hanker for the past, if we do so we will only get left behind. The modern world is not one to be resisted or feared, but one to be embraced and used to our advantage. We need perspective if we are to change, and change for our betterment.

In this regard I would like to look at some figures relating to Asia, particularly trade figures. I have here a table of our exports into Asia, the latest figures available for 1995‐96. The table shows that in that year we exported to 222 different countries and regions around the world a total of $76 billion in exports: $1.4 billion into the African continent, a very small amount; only $6.7 billion into the Americas—both North and South America, including the United States and Canada; $9.9 billion into Europe; $7.7 billion into our region of Oceania; and $49.2 billion—almost $50 billion—into Asia.

In other words, 65 per cent of our export trade went into Asia. That is almost two out of every three export dollars we earn. Our trade into Asia is increasing today by in excess of $5 billion a year. In other words, the extra trade we will do into Asia over the next two years is more than we are selling, after 200 years, into Europe in a whole year. So Asia is absolutely critical to this country's standard of living. It is particularly critical to our rural industries, which are basically export industries.

If you look at our top 12 export destinations, you see that nine of them lie in Asia. At the top of the list is Japan, followed by South Korea. Then comes New Zealand and the United States, which are not in Asia. Our fifth most important export destination is China. So $16.5 billion worth of exports goes into Japan, $6.6 billion into South Korea and $3.8 billion into China. Next on the list of trading partners are: Singapore at over $3.5 billion; Taiwan at $3.5 billion; and Hong Kong, about to go into China, at over $3 billion. Next is the United Kingdom and in 10th position is Indonesia with $2.8 billion, followed by Malaysia with $2.3 billion and Thailand with $1.8 billion. Nine out of the 12 most important trade destinations lie in Asia. Further down the list, at positions 15, 17 and 18, are India, the Philippines and Papua New Guinea.

If you wanted to indulge in a little bit of treason, destruction or detriment to this country, what would you do? If you wanted to hurt the farmers of this country, if you wanted to hurt the businesses in this country, if you wanted to hurt the workers in this country—in other words, if you wanted to harm our standard of living—you would go out and sledge Asia. You would insult them, you would imply that they are backward in some way and you would misrepresent the facts and figures on that region of the world. That is what you would do if you wanted to do harm in that area. I think that to be peddling anti-Asian sentiment from the shores of Australia is madness indeed. That is where our standard of living lies—like it or not. We should be cultivating these people. We should be bending over backwards to do what we can to embrace them and to win extra markets there, as this government is doing.

To imply that these people are somehow backward is a cruel nonsense. In many ways, they are harder working people than we are, particularly those from countries that have embraced a half-decent political system. They show just as much if not more intelligence than we do. They are polite people, they are clean people and they are well‐mannered people. They are honest, they respect their elderly and they have good standards when it comes to family values. Above all else, what I like about them is that they drive the hardest bargain that you could imagine. They are very good business people. I like to deal with hard bargaining people, because you know that they will be there tomorrow and the next day, and they will pay you for the business that you can win from them, if you are good enough to win that business.

Asia is very close to Australia, so we have an advantage over the other countries of the world in freight. That is where our destiny lies. We should not be offending these people with cheap political shots, with ignorant statements, by thoughtlessly insulting them or by scaremongering. As the leader of my party said the other day, such tactics are dumb—very dumb indeed. To say that we are going to be swamped by Asians in this country is a nonsense. They make up 4.8 per cent of our population. On the present increased immigration rates, it will only be a flicker over seven per cent by the middle of next century.

If you compare the immigration rates from that part of the world with last century when the gold rush was on in this country, it is nothing unremarkable at all. I had lunch with some people from Thailand and some people from South Korea a few weeks ago and they informed me that the front pages and other pages over there are full of this scaremongering, insulting nonsense that is coming out of Australia. It is on the verge of harming our trade in this country. That is indeed a great tragedy.

BREAK.PARA: To peddle information that they can invest here but we cannot invest there is also wrong. Those countries, more than us, are crying out for foreign investment, including our investment. They are giving us tax holidays because they realise the value of this investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who's doing it? A former member of the Liberal Party. That's who's doing it. The member for Oxley. Why don't you name her?

—She was expelled from the Liberal Party. If we are going to wind down the level of foreign investment in this country to a level that some would like to see, we will end up with the levels of foreign investment in this country that existed in the Soviet Union or that exist today in Bangladesh. We will have a comparable standard of living to go along with it.

BREAK.PARA: The people who say that should look at our trade with Asia, which I have been lauding and which I say we should be cultivating. We have a trade surplus with those countries. I read recently that we have a $16 billion trade surplus with East Asian countries alone—a surplus in our favour. If you compare that with our trade with the United States of America, for example, we are in deficit to the tune of billions of dollars. Not only are we doing a lot of trade with Asia but the trade is very much in our favour.

Our standard of living in Australia depends not so much on the domestic market but on the export market because we are a trading nation. We export something like 98 per cent of our wool, 80 per cent of our skim milk powder, 80 per cent of our sugar, 78 per cent of our wheat, 74 per cent of our cotton and 72 per cent of our barley. In fact, we are the biggest exporters in the world of sugar and wool. Our wealth stems from our trade, and we must do everything we can to cultivate that.

Those who run around saying that we should be restricting imports, implying that we can export everything out of Australia but have no imports into Australia, are also preaching a dishonest policy. They have no idea of the advantages of pursuing a comparative advantage policy. If we had no imports into this country, ultimately we would have no exports from this country. A simple study of exchange rate movements would tell you that. If you look at it the other way around, if we are going to have high exports from this country—which is surely something all of us want—we ultimately have to have high imports into this country. Otherwise we would have a very adverse exchange rate which would ultimately choke off our exports.

What we should be aiming for is a balance of trade at a high level, healthy foreign investment and sensible immigration levels. I say sensible immigration levels because migrants to this country, particularly the right mix of migrants—that is, migrants who have something to contribute to this country—lead to the creation of jobs here. Even where that does not occur, they eat more food and they wear more clothes. Who does that benefit ultimately? It benefits the domestic market and the farmers of this country.

These people who come to us from faraway lands bring with them contacts in countries from where they came which will benefit our trade. They also bring in capital and expertise. All of this helps us. We have had 5½ million migrants come into Australia since the Second World War. If we could put our hands on those people and take them back to the countries from which they came, it would collapse the standard of living in this country. They have benefited this country enormously.

Other myths that are peddled concern trade barriers. Some say that we should be increasing tariffs. In the last round of tariff reduc tions which we helped negotiate with other world trading partners, we reduced tariff levels in this country on 20 different products. Some people in this chamber might say that was a bad thing, but they are overlooking the fact that other countries whom we trade with reduced tariffs on 1,300 products. We gave concessions in 20 areas, but we won concessions in 1,300 areas. Surely that is ultimately to our benefit as a trading nation.

Look at the dairy industry. It has opened up its markets in recent years by lowering protection levels. It now exports $1,600 million worth of products out of this country. Surely we are not saying that that should be stopped. We could even look at the automotive industry. Earlier today some members in this chamber were calling to raise barriers. We export $1,800 million worth of automotive parts from this country. The wine industry is a great success story. It does not get one cent of government assistance. Yet in 1996 I believe it exported $543 million worth of products out of this country.

Let us not forget that Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and others pay higher tariffs on getting their products into Australia than we pay on getting our products into those very same markets. I think it is time that the truth be told about that.

In conclusion on this particular part of my speech, I would like to appeal to those who peddle the simplistic slogans on foreign investment, trade, trade barriers and migration levels, those who prey on the undercurrents of fear, prejudice and uncertainty out there in the population, those who offer false nostrums and those who stir up and use people who themselves are in financial and other difficulties or who are otherwise vulnerable to think again. In doing so—for political advantage or whatever reason you are doing it—you are not helping those people; you are betraying the very people you are claiming to help.

In a few short ill-considered speeches, you can undo decades of hard grind—won in trade benefits for Australia—and you are the foe rather than the friend of the farmers, workers and business people in my electorate and in the other electorates of Australia. If you like, in an un‐Christian manner, you are hurting the feelings of our migrants who are contributing to this country. I have seen it. You are hurting the feelings of exchange students and you are also hurting the feelings of the original citizens who live in this land.
I appeal not so much for tolerance but for common sense and intelligence and an honest reality and portrayal of the world's situation in this debate that we are having in this country today.

Having made those remarks, in the short time remaining to me, I would like to make some brief comments specifically on the budget. I believe it was a very sound budget. Personally, I would have liked to have seen a somewhat tougher budget. Even so, when we took over last year we reduced the budget deficit from $10.3 billion to about $3.9 billion this year. Next year we will move into a surplus of $1.6 billion, a turnaround in the first term of government of something like $12 billion. This is quite a remarkable effort when you think of it in the context of what has gone on in the past.

Interest rates have come down four times. Housing interest rates at the peak of the last government, which was in for 13 years, got to over 17 per cent. Today they are below seven per cent. I think they were 10½ per cent when we took over last year. Today they are 6.99 per cent. That alone in the period of just over a year is a saving on an average home loan of $292 a month after tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Money in the back pocket.

—In the back pocket, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs says. For the average small business loan, just on the last half of one per cent cut, that is $2,500 a year. We are the first government which is really starting to put the pressure on the banks to pass these interest rates on, which I am also pleased to see. That is the other side of the equation.

BREAK.PARA: This budget was the second budget in a row in which there were no tax increases. I think that is a remarkable feat that has been overlooked. There has been no increase in personal income tax levels. There has been no increase in wholesale sales tax levels, there has been no increase in fringe benefits tax, there has been no increase in capital gains tax and, most importantly for my constituents, this is the first time in which there has been no increase in fuel tax. The last government put it up from 6c a litre to 36c a litre in 13 years. That is remarkable in itself. We are spending $1,900 million a year bringing in our national savings plan, which will encourage constituents to save.

Regional development has been really looked after. Dollars are going into real projects rather than paying for committees and bureaucracies to run around the country. An amount of $21 million has been allocated to the Kidman Way in my electorate, $40 million has gone to the Newell Highway in my electorate this year and money has been put aside for levee banks in Warren and Bourke. Intec Copper, a major project in my electorate, got $6.4 million of R&D funding. Projects like this will really benefit. The deferred pension bonus was a wonderful thing for the elderly in my electorate. Some of them can continue to work on. Overall, it is a very good budget. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only support the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) and his comments on the impact that anti-Asian rhetoric is having on our economic fortunes but, more importantly, on our moral fibre.

SPEECH.PARA: While this budget is certainly not the draconian document that the 1996-97 budget was for regional Australia in particular, it nevertheless targeted several areas in the regions that I would like to detail here tonight. Perhaps the most glaring anti-regional Australia decision was the cuts to the Commonwealth industry placement scheme, which severely impacts on Charles Sturt University in my electorate. The decision to slice this support for tertiary courses run for the police service will impact heavily on CSU, which currently trains 2,000 police at tertiary level. One has only to look at the recent Wood royal commission report in New South Wales and its recommendations that police receive university education to understand the lack of understanding by this government of the needs of law enforcement education in this country.

The university was informed the night before the budget of the decision to slash $10 million from its forward budget. This was a university whose vice‐chancellor had put the best possible slant on the increased HECS charges in last year's budget and those other budgetary changes that had impacted on regional universities.

Charles Sturt University has been a leader in establishing courses for the service sector. At the moment it has 3,000 students enrolled in policing, pre-hospital care, emergency services and Aboriginal mental health. The distance education capacity of Charles Sturt University has enabled large numbers of police and ambulance officers to obtain degree and diploma qualifications while continuing to meet their work commitments, often in remote locations. Charles Sturt University had to travel down here to Canberra after the budget and explain again to the government these capacities, which has made CSU a leader in developing such qualifications among those sectors of the work force that had been left behind academically.

The government would have been well aware of these courses had it been on top of its job. Now, I understand, there have been some adjustments and the government has recognised its obligation to police students in particular at CSU beyond 1999. There are students, though, in the pipeline under the scheme up until 2002. New students may now be funded as overenrolments, but the downside is that the police trainees or their employer will now have to meet the HECS fees. That is perhaps not necessarily a negative, given the HECS fee applies to most university courses, but it could certainly act as a disincentive for people to enter these careers where pay rates are less than adequate.

The university's main complaint in this is the way the whole process was handled and how badly it sits with the government's alleged commitment to regional development. One senior university officer says one must take with a grain of salt any commitment to regional development when the rug is pulled from beneath a regional university in such a fashion.

We must be aware that universities like Charles Sturt, the non-sandstone universities, if you like, are leading the way in addressing the need for those professions with a very important social function such as police, emergency services, ambulance and fire sciences. It was only a few short years back that teaching and nursing were given the opportunity to become part of the full degree tertiary system. And who would question the need for that educational status for those professions? So too should it be with these most recent courses, particularly police, and the government must support where it can this process.

This budget did contain one initiative in the tertiary education sector that I and every rural member should applaud. While only modest in budgetary terms, the increased Austudy for families with two or more tertiary students living away from home by increasing the parental income test dependant deduction to $7,400 is very welcome. Having said that, the government has done nothing to adjust the actual means test and assets test, which are unfairly disqualifying many rural regional families from receiving Austudy benefits.

This area needs urgent reform. I have students giving up school in my electorate because of the impact of the actual means test. That surely cannot be right. The actual means test still specifically targets partnerships, where in the rural industry nearly 80 per cent of farms are run as partnerships. In much the same way as small business and farmers were excluded by the provisions of the capital gains tax rollover relief until I was alerted from within my electorate and pointed it out to the parliament, so too are farm families—and others as well, I might add—being excluded from Austudy entitlement.

The actual means test treats debt—even a loan for the kids to go to university or an overdraft to get through a drought—as income. The test is inflexible and pedantic. It does not look at how people operate their farm or business in the real world. My youth officer, Tim Payne, has done more than anyone, I would confidently assert, to draw the attention of the department and Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to the shortcomings of the actual means test.

I am preparing a submission for the minister on this matter, including detailed case studies, and I urge the government to consider it carefully. I have no problems with the intent of the actual means test. There is no doubt Austudy has been rorted in the past, but I am concerned to hear similar stories of undeserving applicants receiving Austudy while those I have spoken of miss out. The government must rectify this.

While a move in the budget to encourage savings is welcome, the rebate on savings measures will mostly benefit the higher income earner. The scheme will not encourage enough people to start saving because the rewards at the bottom end of the income scale are just not there and people on lower incomes are just not able to save anyway for a home deposit, let alone for any other nest egg.

But I do agree with the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and others no doubt, including analysts, who believe that at least the rebate for the first $3,000 in personal contributions to super means that middle income households will gain, although I doubt lower income earners will see much benefit. The government suggested the rebate could be used to fund private health insurance, but a $450 maximum rebate, which only the well‐off savers would attract, does not go far towards the annual premium for family private cover. Far more innovative measures, including a wider tax rebate, are needed to arrest the private health cover decline.

The rewarding of those who choose to defer their pensions for up to five years is a welcome move that should result in significant savings to the public purse while encouraging those with much to offer the economy an opportunity to maintain their professional input while also maintaining their superannuation contributions. Also welcome is the decision to preserve super contributions until the age of 60 by the year 2025, given the very sobering statistics on the number of our population that will be over 60 by that year and the huge demand on our welfare system if we do not do something about it now.

There is very little in this budget that will do anything to simulate employment growth. We have four per cent economic growth but we do not have any signs of employment growth. We have even the most optimistic forecasts suggesting barely any downward movement in the unemployment figures by this time next year. One might ask whether keeping a certain percentage unemployed is in fact part of our budget strategy to meet the requirements of our creditors. As B.A. Santamaria recently observed, are we as a nation being asked to preserve the value of the money lent to us by eliminating inflation, balancing budgets, selling off public utilities and assets, cutting wages and social services and maintaining a pool of unemployed to guarantee the policy result?

The work for the dole program, without a serious training component, is more about blaming the victims of unemployment for the crisis than dealing compassionately and constructively with the crisis of unemployment itself. This morning I listened to a radio interview with Dr Bob Gregory of the Australian National University. He detailed the phenomenon that is becoming apparent in the community, city and country town alike, where those with jobs and are well off live in one section of the community and those without jobs and the poor live in the other sections.

`Has it ever been any different,' I hear you ask. Yes, indeed it has. In years past there was a more pronounced scattering of the unemployed throughout the community. The haves and have-nots were not so obvious and marginalised. To top it off, we now have many with work who are in fact the working poor, who desperately want more work but the work is not available.

And do not be fooled by the apparent reduction in unemployment in the United States where economists boast the success of their downsizing and rationalist policies by pointing to a five per cent or thereabouts unemployment figure. That five per cent unemployment figure in 1997 is vastly different from a five per cent unemployment figure in the 1960s or 1970s, because back then 95 per cent of the work force had full-time work or individuals were working as much as they wanted to work. Today there may be 30 to 40 per cent only in that position. That is the difference. So America is not five per cent away from full employment, nor are we 8½ per cent away from full employment. We are probably seven per cent short of an accurate unemployment rate anyway, for starters, with one hour per week regarded as employment.

BREAK.PARA: People do not want workplace agreements, they want work agreements, and there is nothing in this budget to suggest they are on the way. As the member for Curtin pointed out, an injection of investment expenditure is necessary to help reverse the decline in public sector savings and its associated unemployment rates. Simplifying withholding tax obligations is good as far as it goes, but small business will not of its own deliver the jobs we need in this country. To believe small business is the answer to solving our economic woes is to think small, notwithstanding the contributions small to medium enterprises make to the economy.

We need—and here I suspect the member for Curtin and I part company—public investment in major infrastructure in this country as well as to facilitate joint public-private investment in projects like the Parkes inland freight airport. Do not laugh; wait for the feasibility study in a couple of weeks—done privately, after the government reneged on its commitment to that. Other initiatives that come to mind include the inland Melbourne-Darwin, via New South Wales and Queensland, rail freight line that several members in this House are keen to promote. Also, the federal government needs to dramatically upgrade the Great Western Highway through the Blue Mountains and across the sandstone curtain, as I pointed out in my first speech in this place.

It is only through upgrading transport routes at public expense that private enterprise can follow the way, decentralise and use the stable resources, particularly labour, that the regions offer. So, too, should rail lines be upgraded once again, with far more than the $175 million over four years set aside in this budget. Then, too, private operators would follow and invest, particularly if state governments like New South Wales offered a realistic freight access charge for the line.

The government boasts about the 90 per cent of roads budget being spent in regional Australia. It fails to mention that, in the case of New South Wales, much of this has been spent on the north coast on one highway and the encouragement of the heavy road freight industry, including greatly increased gross tonnages that are going to cost local and state authorities more in road and bridge damage. Independent consultant Sinclair Knight Merz has indicated that, for local government, the least cost to bring all existing overstressed bridges up to current mass limits will, for New South Wales, be approximately $430 million and, for the increased mass, an additional $160 million.

In a letter from a central west council expressing frustration at the Commonwealth road funding arrangements, one manager told me today that recent initiatives of the federal government, such as black spot and roads of national importance, have been at the expense of the national highway system. The Commonwealth, he says, collects over $11 billion from fuel tax and excises and returns less than 15 per cent to roads.

I have spoken elsewhere on the heritage trust and the pea and thimble trick the government has pulled on its environmental commitment. There are simply not enough funds in the trust to tackle the enormous task of the Murray-Darling Basin salinity and degradation, let alone the other environmental challenges around this nation. Local government also received a setback in this year's budget with financial assistance grants reduced by 1.2 per cent in real per capita terms, despite assurances from the government to the contrary. Smaller councils like Rylstone, Evans and Oberon are heavily dependent on these grants.

The government says that it is only asking local government to make a contribution to the budget bottom line, and I am pleased that the minister says that the per capita formula will hopefully be reinstated next year. But the councils are right to ask why they should put scarce resources into competition policy reforms when the government reduces financial commitment in such an arbitrary and short-sighted fashion.

The government in this budget has maintained its commitment to provide assistance to those farms continuing to experience severe drought. Existing drought exceptional circumstance assistance measures, including drought relief payment and interest subsidies under the rural adjustment scheme, will remain available for the duration of the drought and the 12‐month post-drought recovery period. I welcome that funding.

But let me tell you a story from my electorate that highlights the inadequacies of our drought policies and attention to the critical area of farm finance. A farmer in my electorate near Oberon has been receiving exceptional circumstance drought relief payments. Thanks to the foresight of the government, this help was extended 12 months after his district went out of drought exceptional status. But in this man's case the payments cease on 30 June. That is when the 12 months of extra payments come to a close in the Carcoar PP board area, where he resides. The only trouble is that the area is again drought declared after one reasonable spring—not enough to begin recovery. There has been virtually no rain in the 12 months since the district was in exceptional circumstances.

The neighbouring Bathurst land board went into exceptional circumstances later. It is still there. So this man's neighbours, just a few miles away, are covered by special assistance as his assistance runs out. He has an overdraft of $160,000 and a term loan of $270,000 from the Commonwealth Bank. The bank is charging him 11½ per cent plus a one per cent facility fee on his overdraft. His term loan costs him 10½ per cent. What are his alternatives? Wool company and stock and station agent money costs 15 per cent. That flies in the face of the statement to the Land on 29 May by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) that the 0.5 per cent cut in interest rates could be worth as much as $90 million to the farm sector. Not to my constituent.

For the first time in years farmers are starting to feel a bit of a `surge in confidence', the minister told the Land. Some might—that is, those lucky enough to be in a position of strength with their lender—but the great majority are not in the `surge of confidence' territory by a long way.

My constituent has also had his property recently declared infected by Ovine Johnes disease. He can sell the wool and his sheep for mutton if he wants, but he cannot sell any commercial breeding stock. He is afraid his bank will adopt the same tactic of another major lender and start charging a penalty rate of 1½ per cent interest for every Johnes affected client. He is faced not only with this huge interest bill but with buying in extra fodder for the winter.

That is the type of situation out there which requires a far more flexible approach than has been displayed by the former government or by this government. We cannot afford to talk up the rural situation too much when the reality is otherwise, when from all indications we have another El Nino on the horizon. As I said earlier, in a debate on the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill, we need to encourage new ways of farm financing. The minister said at the time in response:
At the moment it is largely debt financed and it may be that more innovative approaches are needed for the future.

They certainly are—finance that reflects a market price far closer to the home mortgage rate from financiers empathetic with the family farmers out there who are still the major players in our agricultural future.

Just a few quick words in relation to aged care. While there are still issues that are concerning the older population about the reforms proposed for the nursing sector—and I have raised them at other times—I must say this government and this minister have listened to my submissions and those of my communities, and to the electorate generally. I highlighted the concern and economic irrationalism of dismantling the rural dementia counselling services. The minister investigated this and accepted a late submission from the aged care assessment team in my electorate. I was delighted to see the more than $10 million set aside in the budget to not only retain this service through the Alzheimers Association but also provide additional funding for dementia assessment and support for carers. It must be remembered that carers save this economy $8 billion a year. To not support such people will end up costing far more as their loved ones move into the nursing home system.

This budget consolidates the government's strategy and was never meant to be a repeat of the document brought down last August which caused so much pain in the community. But unless the government changes its attitude to cost cutting alone as the best economic tool and pays attention to revenue and tax reform and to creative expenditure then it will never generate the type of economic activity that this country requires to begin to attack our greatest economic and social ill: the levels of unemployment, particularly among our youth and particularly in rural areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March 1996, the people of Australia wanted a government that was committed to putting into place a plan of economic credibility, a plan for families, a plan for small business, a plan to get people back into work and, in particular, the people wanted a government that was totally committed to sticking to its guns in implementing its plan for their future and, more importantly, for their children's future.

SPEECH.PARA: The Howard government's budget, for the second year running, carries us very much along that same road with the same definite commitment to the future. This is a budget with a commitment to families, jobs and small business and to their future. As the former United States President Thomas Jefferson once said:
I like the dreams of the future better than the history of the past.

This budget does not set about dreaming about a plan to produce better outcomes for young families, for small business, for retirees, for the unemployed and particularly for the people of the Hunter. Simply, this budget delivers. This plan, like any jewel, has many facets and, like any jewel with well‐cut and polished sides, it sparkles. One of the facets of this plan is the fact that it is focused on jobs.

Plainly and simply it is putting the plan into place which has been in action since 2 March last year. The plan has seen the Australian Bureau of Statistics data indicate that in the month of April the Hunter's regional unemployment rate fell to 11 per cent—the lowest mark this year—from a level of 12.1 per cent at the beginning of 1997. But, most importantly, the coalition has achieved a reduction of 2,500 unemployed people in the Hunter in just one month. This reduction in unemployment is despite attempts by Premier Bob Carr's New South Wales Labor government to increase the unemployment figures by playing the politics of the timber industry and not the science.

The plan for jobs in the Hunter was to meet the challenge of the region's historic less than flattering record on job creation. Let us take a look at them: 17 per cent unemployment in the Hunter in 1993, reduced to 13 per cent by March 1996. Most importantly, that trend line is continuing to go in one direction—coming down. Whilst the Hunter is still some 2.3 per cent above the national average, a plan is in place and is working—a plan that has helped facilitate from the economic lever of fiscal policy a fourth official cut in interest rates on 23 May 1997 by the Reserve Bank. This has occurred only under the leadership of Peter Costello who has taken over the Treasury reins. That is a net saving of $290 a month on the average mortgage for each and every Hunter family home owner.

Remember that great Australian dream of owning your own home or buying the farm—a dream was taken away from so many Australians by the Labor government in their 13‐year interest rate roller‐coaster ride to financial ruin. That roller-coaster ride was full of screams and, yes, we heard those screams. Remember the recession we had to have. Let me tell you: the people of the Hunter do. I remember the recession and I remember the screams. The coalition is about restoring that dream—a dream of pride in home ownership.

The sensible, responsible budget delivered is just one down payment to a better position for the Hunter for the 21st century. It is designed to lift the spirits of families, instil more confidence to invest and spend, to deliver an improved environment for small business confidence and to boost retail trade in the Hunter. That confidence has had cause to become dented with BHP's announcement back on 29 April 1997 that integrated steel making at the Newcastle steelworks would cease at the end of 1999, displacing 2½ thousand workers.

Over and above the ink of this budget, the Commonwealth is committed to ensuring that the people of the Hunter and the people of Newcastle feel in no way short‐changed by this decision of BHP. There will be a financial boost of at least $10 million for specific assistance initiatives which will facilitate fresh job and investment growth and unlock real, new employment opportunities in the Hunter to replace the lost BHP jobs. For example, there will be $1.2 million for an additional 100 NIES training places to the 300 places already announced in the budget. There will be $498,000 in funding for a business incubator to look for, source out and promote new business activity in the Hunter. It will be based not in Paterson—the most marginal seat in the Hunter—but in Cessnock, because this government is committed to delivering jobs irrespective of whether it be in a marginal Liberal seat or a safe Labor seat; it puts the dollars where they are needed. The sum of $150,000 will go to the Area Consultative Committee to do a skills assessment to find out what is needed to attract new employers to the area. There will be $350,000 towards upgrading the metal skills of our artisans in the Hunter so that they can fill the jobs without having to introduce new people to the Hunter.

The fact is that, as concerning as BHP's decision is, it is not the death knell for the Hunter. In many ways it is the defibrillator for private enterprise and for governments of all persuasions—a shock to kick‐start the heart of the Hunter and give industry a new lease of life. Industries like engineering, tourism, resources and particularly our defence industry, now the biggest global employer in the Hunter, will get a new lease of life under the coalition government. The Howard government's second budget helps facilitate this.

The sum of $140 million has been allocated for Hunter roads. Again, this government continues to pour funds into road infrastructure in the Hunter, recognising that the Hunter has roads of national importance. I seek to remind the House that these roads were long deserted by the Labor government over the previous 13 years, despite the promises. But, as our Treasurer alludes to, they probably would have fixed the problems in the 14th or 15th years. They were gunna, gunna, gunna, but never did.

The coalition has a plan for roads and transport. The Pacific Highway got the first big red tick with $196 million for the Bulahdelah to Coolongolook deviations, $2 million for the proposed Metford traffic enhancement proposals and $651,000 in black spot funding for East Maitland and Millers Forest—all forgotten about, all deserted by the former Labor government. Fresh funding will generate another 1,000 jobs in roadwork development in the Hunter. The government is injecting $140 million over the next 12 months, including another $12 million to the Raymond Terrace Bypass for its completion by the middle of next year.

Confirmation has been given by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, John Sharp, that only red tape stands in the way of constructing, after a 15‐year campaign by local residents such as Lloyd Gregory, traffic lights at the intersection of Arthur Street, Rutherford and the New England Highway. It is one of the biggest shopping centres north of Maitland, yet there is no traffic light access to the highway—not for the club, not for the schools, not for the preschools. Yet people are expected to navigate their way and enter on to the New England Highway.

The first $16 million has been allocated for the Belford Bends on the New England Highway. Yet I still hear the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) bellowing that it is not enough, not good enough. But I do seek to remind him that under the 13 years of Labor government when the seat of Hunter was held as a Labor seat how much did they deliver. The answer is zero. And there is a federal commitment—ironclad—to meet the $52 million cost of completing the F3 link at Leneghans Drive by early 1999.

I had the pleasure a couple of months ago of going up to see the commencement of the roadworks at the start of the Bulahdelah deviations to Coolongolook with Minister Sharp. Present also were Bob Carr, the New South Wales Premier, and Carl Scully. That was roadwork which should have commenced some six years ago but which was put off again and again, abandoned, but brought up by this government. It was only when it was brought up as an election promise by this government that the former government jumped in and decided that it was a good idea and that they were going to go on with it. Again, they were going to. The difference is we have delivered. We have turned on the tractors, we have started the bulldozers, we have loaded the trucks and the roadwork is well ahead. As I said, this is a budget not about dreams but about delivering.

Another facet to the jewel is the defence industry. The recent defence efficiency review augured good things for Williamtown RAAF base to become a super base. The misleading statements by the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), who kept pushing the line that Williamtown RAAF base was to close, ignored the fact that page 42 of the review quotes its findings of `the attraction of Newcastle (Williamtown) becoming a prime air base'—a base that would effectively double in personnel from 2½ thousand to 5,000.

With 2,500 people, the base injects some $2 million each and every week into the local economies of Raymond Terrace, Medowie and Port Stephens. When the number goes up to 5,000, $4 million each and every week will be injected into the local economies. That is secure income each and every week—secure income that businesses can plan on, that businesses can attract and, most importantly, that businesses can develop and employ people from.

Comparable to this is the increasing emphasis and profile being placed on Williamtown airport, where Hunter Aerospace and British Aerospace Australia have secured the $1 billion lead‐in fighter project that will lead the way for a hoped rapid new growth in aeronautics and high‐tech associated avionics industry via a host of new players. With this in mind, the budget has met the plan of burgeoning defence industry interests and action in the Hunter head on.

BREAK.PARA: Our investments in the area recently included some $7.7 million to be spent on capital works for RAAF Base Williamtown, with a further $6 million to be spent in the following financial year on the $12.5 million eastern regional operations centre along with $1.4 million to construct an oxygen storage facility. We are investing $356,000 to upgrade overflow accommodation at Fort Wallace for RAAF Base Williamtown.

New capital facilities development at RAAF Base Williamtown, as part of a $45 million investment spread over five projects, will provide support facilities for command and control activities. Other specific areas of funding for the people of Paterson are included during the year.

The government has committed another $10.7 million in 1997-98 to commence the regional forest assessment process which will benefit timber workers in Gloucester, Bulahdelah and Stroud and allow them to access the timber resource which has been locked up by the Carr Labor government for the past 10 months. That Labor government decision, which wiped out the employment numbers with the stroke of a pen, had a far more devastating effect than the closure of BHP in Newcastle. Losing 130 jobs in a town like Gloucester with a population of 1,000 is far worse than losing 2,500 jobs out of a population of 250,000 people in the Hunter.

But the federal government will not be pushed around or shoved around by this process. Our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, have stood up to be counted many times in support of the people in small regional and rural towns affected by the decisions of the Carr government.

Another facet to the jewel in the Hunter is that we have achieved $50,000 in funding for Hunter retirement living and community aged care. That will go to the Uniting Church at Salamander Bay and will provide another 30 home and hostel care places to be monitored and run by that organisation.

I was also delighted to find out that $31,000 had been granted to Maitland palliative care to increase the hours of the coordinator from 21 to 35 hours a week and of the assistant from six to 28 hours a week. When the euthanasia debate was on, this government said it was committed to palliative care. By increasing the number of hours available for coordinators, it shows that it is not delivering rhetoric; it is delivering dollars and commitment.

Yet another facet is the delivery of effective digital mobile phone services for Gloucester, Dungog, Vacy and other parts of the Lower Hunter. By the third quarter of this year, much of the Lower Hunter will have access for the first time to digital phone services. It is hard to believe that, with the ongoing payment of 8c a day for the ABC—as has been quoted—people in areas such as Vacy have never been able to receive television reception, yet they are not more than 70 kilometres away from a major town such as Maitland. They will have their television reception by March 1998.

In East Maitland, the town where I live, television reception has been very poor, and it has been poor for at least two years. Indeed, one of the local television stations based not more than 25 kilometres away cannot be received in East Maitland because of the transmitter. During the February break the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, came up to East Maitland, had a look at the area and met with the residents. He gave the instruction that, if the transmitter was not able to be rectified within two months, a new one would be installed. That transmitter will be installed by November this year at a cost of $1 million.

Yet another facet to the jewel is Medicare. This government has announced that patients will be able to electronically lodge claim forms directly from doctors' surgeries to save inconvenience and to speed up claims processing, especially for those living in outlying areas such as the Hunter.

The list goes on. There was a boost in AQIS funding of $78 million. That is of utmost importance to the people in the Hunter when you consider that, as a part of the push for the supermarket to Asia, a premium price is paid for our goods because of the clean and green food that we have in the Hunter Valley. We will continue to pursue that.

As I have said, another facet of the plan is the positive outcomes for small business emanating from the Howard government's second budget. I am hopeful that, for small businesses right across our Hunter, the policy direction and fresh initiatives that have been outlined in the budget will stimulate greater consumer confidence and, most importantly, create jobs.

Importantly, for the second year running, there are no tax increases, no sales tax increases, no lift in the petrol excise, no rise in the company tax and the retention of the diesel fuel rebate. They were all promised in the plan and they were all delivered. That not only helps small businesses but keeps prices down for consumers.

My government has to date tried to set the standard that it is prepared—unlike any former federal administration—to cut red tape, to provide capital gains tax relief, to keep interest rates down and to get a flexible and fair industrial relations structure in place for small business. But its full reforms have not been able to be achieved because they have been stymied over and over again by Labor and the Democrats in the Senate.

Something the former Labor government would not do was deliver for small business. The members of the Labor government believe that profit is a dirty word and that perseverance and reward for effort just do not fit within their dogma. In the coalition, we believe that small business is the answer to unemployment and a brighter economy and that all the benefits for the long-term security of families come from having a vibrant small to medium business sector. That policy stance will continue.

For the sake of the nation, we have to get the nation's books back in fiscal order.
