Now, more than ever, it is important that we continue to create the right economic environment to enable businesses to enhance their profitability and to foster growth. It must be remembered that the government does not spend at the tills of the small businesses that manufacture Australian jobs and products. It is up to the consumers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and to support the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), which I formally seconded on 27 May, having reserved my right to speak. I now exercise that right.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to concentrate on what I regard as the most important social and economic issue in Australia at the moment—that is, unemployment. That, of course, includes long‐term unemployment. As the amendment moved by the member for Holt indicates, the budget does nothing for jobs, `the nation's most overwhelming current economic and social problem'. Unemployment—or employment—is the most important social and economic issue that confronts us in this country at the moment.

I have a strong conviction that the most important thing you can give a person in our society is the opportunity for a job. The opportunity for a job brings with it the opportunity for members of one's family to have an education. The opportunity for a job brings with it the opportunity for a family to have decent living standards and to be able to take care of some basic provisions in life, such as decent health care. The opportunity for a job goes to a community's confidence about notions such as the capacity of people to educate their children, to provide decent health care and a decent standard of living for their family.

There are two aspects to unemployment or employment. In the first instance, the number of people you are able to employ goes to the economic growth in your society. It is the responsibility and the role of government to seek to maximise economic growth, to seek to do everything that it can within the rigours of being a national government to maximise economic growth, because the maximisation of economic growth brings with it the maxi misation of job opportunities. It is also incumbent upon governments in this day and age, when faced with an unemployment problem, to do everything they can to assist the long‐term unemployed.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, experience in Australia and mirrored in comparable countries is that if you want to reduce the number of long‐term unemployed then you simply cannot rely on economic growth by itself. You have to take further steps. You have to take additional measures. You have to take what I describe as growth plus measures to give long‐term unemployed people the opportunity of getting access to training or employment.

Regrettably, in both these areas—in the maximisation of economic growth to bring with it the maximisation of employment and in the need to take special measures to reduce long‐term unemployment—the government, from the moment it came to office, including the budget which the Appropriation Bill deals with, has failed miserably. This is not a government which seeks to maximise economic growth and, therefore, it is not a government which seeks to maximise employment opportunities. It is certainly not a government which seeks to take special steps to cater for the long‐term unemployed.

It is worth recounting a number of economic and employment related statistics to enable the House and the community to put what I would describe as the most pressing and significant social and economic issue before us in its context. The government has recently revised its forecast for growth for 1996‐97 down to 3¼ per cent. As they say in the trade, the resident galah in the pet shop and the current Governor of the Reserve Bank, although I certainly do not attribute that description to him, say that if you want to have sufficient economic growth to create employment you have to have economic growth at four per cent or above. The government's own forecast for the 1996‐97 financial year ceases at three‐quarters of a percentage point of growth in GDP below that level which is required to increase employment.

The most recent labour force figures for April this year show that the trend in employment is dead flat: it is exactly 0.0 per cent. Earlier, in January of this year, the government revised its forecast for unemployment from 8¼ per cent to 8½ per cent. Now the forecast unemployment rate for the June quarter of 1997 has been increased to 8¾ per cent.

Since the coalition came to government virtually no full‐time jobs have been created and the number of unemployed people has risen by 31,500. We saw, just over a week ago, that long‐term unemployment had risen to its highest level for two years. The government's most optimistic forecast for growth of 3¾ per cent is still a quarter of a percentage point in growth below that which people generally regard as being the amount of economic growth required to have an impact on unemployment.

Some comparisons are worthy of note as well. The current rate of growth in GDP under the coalition, if you annualise that to December of 1996, is under two per cent. The average rate of growth in Labor's last term of office was just under 4½ per cent. The average rate of employment growth in the coalition's first year of office to March of this year was one per cent. The average rate of employment growth in Labor's last term in office was just under three per cent. The number of jobs created in the coalition's first year in office to March of this year was 90,000. The average number of jobs created in each year of Labor's last term in office was 225,000. The number of full‐time jobs that we have seen lost since the 1996 budget is just over 34,000.

A couple of weeks ago, when the figures were released which saw long‐term unemployment hit its highest level for just under two years, my colleague the shadow minister for employment, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), made the point that between March and April we saw the single biggest jump in long‐term unemployment—16,200. There are now just under 250,000 people on the long‐term unemployed queue. The member for Batman made the point that in May 1996, shortly after the government came to office, it announced it was cutting the funding to labour market programs in the order of $2 billion. Long‐term unemployment was then 206,400. Since that time, over 40,000 people have become long‐term unemployed. That array of statistics is a searing indictment of this government's course of conduct since they came to office, both in failing to maximise economic growth and to take any steps to give long‐term unemployed people the opportunity to get back into the work force.

If you are a country of just over 18 million people nestled in the Asia‐Pacific region, as we are, what sorts of things do you need to do to maximise economic growth? The great future for Australia is as a modern trading nation. That means you want to be doing everything you can as a government to maximise your trade performance, your industry development performance and the natural economic strengths that your nation has. In the course of my contribution this evening, I will touch on some of those areas—trade enhancement, industry development measures and capitalising on some of our natural strengths, particularly in the minerals and resources area.

I will deal with trade and industry enhancement measures first. What have we seen since the government came to office, and what do we see repeated in this Appropriation Bill which reflects the budget recently delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Costello)? We have seen a range of trade and industry enhancement measures either abolished or gutted by the government—and most of those in express breach of election commitments. To go through the litany of sins, in the trade enhancement area, for example, we have seen the abolition of the international trade enhancement scheme, ITES, the abolition of the innovative agricultural marketing program, the abolition of the Asia‐Pacific fellowship scheme, the abolition of the Asia business links program, the discontinuation of the market Australia program, the cessation of the trade blazer project, the gutting of the export access program, the gutting of the export market development grants scheme—with a $426 million cut over four years—and a cut of $90 million to Austrade's budget in 1996‐97.

TALK.START.PARA: —What didn't they gut?

—I cannot give you that list: my contribution would be over. In the course of this budget, we have seen that focus on reducing the trade enhancement measures continue. General reductions in incentives and assistance to exporters which have occurred are in the order of $20 million over four years. User‐pays fees have been increased for those exporters using Austrade's services. There have been accelerated repayment measures introduced into the international trade enhancement scheme. The cuts to and capping of the EMDG scheme, the export market development grants scheme, remain. One of the primary national focuses which draws attention to the need for trade enhancement measures, the National Trade Investment Outlook Conference, NTIOC, has been cancelled.

BREAK.PARA: When you look at the trade figures, you see that in the last year of the Labor government exports grew at the rate of about 11 per cent. This financial year, under this government, the figure is down to seven per cent and it is forecast that it will remain at that level for 1997‐98. In the last year of the Labor government, 1995‐96, the contribution of exports to growth and GDP was plus one per cent. In 1996‐97, under this government, that contribution fell to minus half a per cent, and it is forecast to be minus a quarter per cent for the next financial year. So, at precisely that point in the cycle where the government's own forecasts say there will be a negative net export contribution to growth in GDP, the government guts trade enhancement measures. That is not even to deal with the array of trade and industry debacles that we have seen by way of the incompetence of the government or its ministers—whether it is the DIFF debacle, the Howe Leather debacle or the Australian‐European Union Trade and Investment Framework Agreement debacle, the litany of sins goes on.

When it comes to industry enhancement measures, I will not detail to the House the array of bounties that have been abolished by the government, whether it is the shipbuilding bounty, the robots bounty, the computer bounty or the book bounty. I make the point that in very many respects the most damaging of all the decisions made by the government to remove industry enhancement or incentive measures was the reduction of the research and development taxation concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent—again in breach of an express election commitment. It has been the case in Australia over many years that, while our public contribution to research and development has been good, our private contribution has been bad. The 150 per cent R&D concession was making substantial and significant inroads into that, to be cut off in its prime by a decision of this government. In the course of this term we have seen the government as well taking out the axe to chop away at our public science and research and development organisations, CSIRO in particular.

How do these things blend together? If you want to maximise economic growth for a country like ours, you have to maximise your strength, you have to maximise your trade and industry development performance. At exactly the time when we need that to occur, this government has gone in precisely the opposite directions. I indicated that you also need, as a country, to highlight and focus on some of your strengths. What are some of our strengths? We are a country which has a world class minerals and resources industry. What do we need to do to capitalise on that strength? We need to continue to ensure that our minerals and resources industries are internationally competitive. We also need to do everything we can, particularly in the employment context, to maximise the opportunities for downstream processing in those industries.

By way of an aside, we have seen today indications that the government is proposing to break its agreement with the minerals and resources industry and cap the diesel fuel rebate scheme. We have heard the natural response from the Minerals Council of Australia that to go down that road is to make it very difficult for the Australian minerals and resources industry to be internationally competitive.

Of course, that was not announced in the budget. It was kept under the bleachers for an appropriate period of time. In the budget you find a couple of measures which go to the heart, or are the key, of not doing everything you can to seek to maximise the capacity of our minerals and resources industries for downstream processing.

There are a couple of areas I will draw attention to. One is the area of infrastructure and the government's decision in the course of the budget to gut the infrastructure borrowings program from a $200 million program, as it was under Labor, to a $37½ million program in its first year and a $75 million program in its final year. Also excluded from consideration for that program is energy infrastructure projects, by restricting that infrastructure program to road and rail.

I noticed today that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) welcomed the talks between Comalco and Chevron on the feasibility of a $2.5 billion alumina refinery at Gladstone. Senator Parer made the point that there is a linkage between the proposed Chevron pipeline from PNG to (ultimately) Gladstone, if it is successful, and the proposed embarking by Comalco of an alumina refinery. There is a choice here for Comalco as to whether to establish a refinery at Gladstone or in Malaysia.

On the one hand the minister welcomes the announcement of the feasibility study but, on the other hand, we do not see the minister berating his colleagues over the removal of the infrastructure borrowings program from energy proposals. If you speak to Chevron representatives who are seeking to get this project up, or to representatives of the Australian Gas Association, you will find consistent comments which indicate the very severe disappointment of the gas industry and people who have the vision to seek to embark on these projects about the government's gutting of the infrastructure borrowings program.

That particular gas pipeline proposal has the great potential to reduce the cost of energy. That gives the great potential to getting up the alumina refinery. Of course, you have the prospect of cheaper energy costs all the way down the north‐east Queensland coast, which adds to the prospects for downstream processing in the resources area. We find the minister is happy to welcome the proposal but is not prepared to do anything which might actually assist.

The second issue which arises in the energy and resources area is the government's decision to abolish the Energy Research and Development Corporation, which, again, has adverse consequences for those interested in making sure Australia is at the cutting edge of energy research and development. I noticed the other day that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) welcomed the development of a ceramic oxide fuel cell, which is designed to turn heat from the burning of natural gas directly into electricity rather than through steam generation.

It is all well and good for the Minister for Science and Technology to welcome a scientific advance, but what the Minister for Science and Technology and the Minister for Resources and Energy will not tell the community is that this particular scientific advance was made as a direct result of a combination of the Energy Research and Development Corporation and CSIRO. What have we seen in the budget? We have seen the cutting of funds to CSIRO and the abolition of the Energy Research and Development Corporation. There is a linkage between all these matters.

If you are serious about trying to make inroads into unemployment and if you are serious about trying to do what you can to give long-term unemployed people the opportunity of employment, then you have to do everything you can to maximise growth. In the Australian context, that means you have to maximise your trade enhancement measures, maximise your industry advancement measures, capitalise on your international strength and maximise and capitalise on the potential and prospects for downstream processing. That means that, at every port of call, at every step in the process, you have to do precisely the opposite of that which this government has done since it came into office and precisely the opposite of what we find in this budget reflected by the Appropriation Bill. I support the amendment moved by the member for Holt. I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The most effective way any government can increase national savings is to increase public saving. As well as reducing the budget deficit and thus increasing our public saving, this budget will create savings incentives for Australians who were locked out of Labor's compulsory super scheme. Retirees, the unemployed and women at home all will be able to take advantage of the savings incentives. At the same time, only last week, my home state of South Australia recorded a historic budget surplus of $1 million. I congratulate the Treasurer, Stephen Baker, on this historic achievement after the debt legacy he was left with by the Bannon years.

SPEECH.PARA: Addressing national savings remains one of the nation's primary goals. Almost every issue in every department—the debate on taxation and health care—can be related to the need for us to increase our national savings. Without increasing the amount that we save as a nation, we will never be able to grow fast enough to significantly reduce unemployment without running into a balance of payments crunch. The previous government racked up $69 billion in debt over the last five years. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Costello) for shouldering the burden of reducing public dissaving and forecasting an underlying budget surplus in 1998‐99.

After public saving, improving household saving is harder because, by offering incentives for private savings, there is a substitution effect between different forms of saving rather than a net increase. Most East Asian countries boast national savings rates of over 30 per cent. Ours hovers around 17 per cent to 18 per cent. So the coalition has shown how to increase the savings of the public sector. But how to increase private savings is going to require a dramatic and generational change in attitudes.

There are still two issues which need to be addressed. Both the taxation system and the flow of Commonwealth benefits to middle and upper income earners influence savings behaviour. The most sensible way to tax savings, as identified by Vince FitzGerald in his 1993 national savings strategy, is not to tax the contributions or the interest accrued but to tax the savings on the way out. The United States 401K savings vehicle adopts that principle. Unfortunately, in 1988, when Labor first began to tax super, they levied it on the contributions rather than on the exit point. Now, to change those arrangements would be complex to say the least.

The second issue, as Vince FitzGerald pointed out in the Financial Review on 8 May this year, is the provision of government benefits to middle and upper income Australians, which reduces the necessity and incentive for private household saving. It is estimated that $20 billion of benefits flow from the Commonwealth to middle and upper income earners in the form of transfer payments and other benefits. That reduces the incentive to save as well as to pool risk through such measures as insurance.

For example, Medicare, by providing free health care to all regardless of income, removes any incentive for high income earners to provide for their own health or hospital care. As Alan Mitchell highlighted in the Australian Financial Review in March this year, the Australian Bureau of Statistics household expenditure survey showed that the top 20 per cent of households on an income scale received $3,000 a year in health care assistance from federal and state governments. In the area of higher education, 38 per cent of government benefits are received by the top five per cent of families based on income.

The top 20 per cent of households receive $4,000 a year on average in education benefits. Middle and high income earners well aware of the benefits of education are hardly likely to need the subsidy and should be able to contribute more towards the education of their children. While it is arguable that secondary education is middle class welfare, there is no doubt that tertiary education is. In fact, a tertiary education increases the lifetime income of someone by $300,000. The free education experiment of Whitlam—rather than opening up the universities and changing the socioeconomic mix in the tertiary sector—actually ended up providing extensive Commonwealth subsidies to the middle class.

BREAK.PARA: Over the next 10 or 20 years, Australia needs to clearly outline what the role of government should be so that government spending will have its greatest benefit and will reach those who really need it. The core roles of government should remain specific social objectives which are demanded by the community, to intervene where there is clear evidence of market failure and for the assignment and regulation of property rights.

As the 1996 National Commission of Audit highlighted, government programs should be targeted at those in greatest need and should not be provided to those who can provide for themselves. This group, in effect, would end up funding their own benefits through higher taxes. That process known as churning, where middle and high income earners are actually funding their own benefits through the tax system, is actually a particularly wasteful way of churning around the money.

The government provision of services always needs to be reviewed. Where the original rationale for a subsidy, such as the operational subsidy for child care, is no longer apt, the government's support should be reviewed and reconsidered. To highlight an example, it is worth recounting the story of the channel observers which were set up by the British government during the Napoleonic Wars. As Gordon Pirie recounted in a speech in the mid-1980s, that post was officially abolished in 1948. Often government expenditure can have a self‐perpetuating nature and can persist even after the original rationale has gone.

I am proud that in the areas such as child care, in recognising that the elderly, if they are able to, should be able to contribute to the cost of aged care in nursing homes, in tertiary education, in export market development grants, this government has really addressed the issue and the rationale of whether government assistance should be provided in those areas.

Last month, the British Labour Party won a historic victory at the polls. With a new Prime Minister in Britain, much has been made of his Australian connection—living as a child in Adelaide, studying at Oxford with Australians Geoff Gallop and Reverend Peter Thomson and his using the Australian Labor Party, of Hawke and Keating, as the template for New Labor. Some of the young turks of the ALP have now made a pilgrimage to New Labor to see what they can learn. Calling themselves the `economic globalists', the young turks have made some savage attacks on what they call the `economic nationalists' of their party. Make no mistake about it, we are witnessing now a nasty and intemperate push for power by some of the younger members of the opposition benches.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe that.
—Are you old Labor or New Labor? I think you are old Labor. You are 1950s Labor. As stated by Glenn Milne in today's Australian :

BREAK.PARA: The new alignments defy the old divisions of Left versus Right in the ALP and look forward to a generational change in the intellectual leadership of the party that echoes Tony Blair's positioning of British Labour as the party of the `radical centre'.

The alignments and association are Byzantine in nature. It is well known around this parliament the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) is of the view that not one member who was a minister in the Keating government will form part of the next Labor government, not if he can help it anyway.

After the crushing defeat at the last election, the member for Werriwa knew it was vitally important that he begin soliciting support for his ambition to become the next Labor Prime Minister. Not finding a terrific amount of support in New South Wales, the member for Werriwa happened on the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). The member for Melbourne was a willing participant.

After all, fresh from his experience as the former President of the ACTU, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) had forced his way into Victoria—he is a New South Welshman, of course—and, to the chagrin of many, made himself the leader of the Left faction. For that, I think the member for Batman does deserve some respect because there are so many different left wings in Victoria that it is not funny. It was, however, the member for Melbourne who was clearly miffed because it was he who had filled the gap when Brian Howe had left and here was the member for Batman, someone from interstate, arriving to replace him as left wing king.

Well, the member for Werriwa has the vision and the ambition. And why not? For it is the member for Werriwa's solemn belief that he is the only man in the Labor Party who can fill the boots of the great Gough. That is what drives him—the great social reformer, the social liberaliser. If Gough was the Che Guvera for the 1960s, the member for Werriwa is our home‐grown Tony Blair.

Just as Blair used the ALP as his template for modernising the British Labour Party, it seems that the ALP, under the economic nationalists of Beazley and Crean, are determined to replicate the wilderness years of British Labour. Rather than Kim Beazley being some sort of antipodean Tony Blair, he is in fact the antipodean Michael Foot. He is the antipodean Neil Kinnock. He is the man who is determined to keep the Labor Party out of government for over a decade by retreating to the left and retreating to the policies of the 1950s. The opposition have retreated from their responsibility to form an alternative government and have retreated to the old values of 1950s Labor.

It is interesting to note that there are quite a few similarities between the ALP and British Labour. Britain's New Labour government has promised to abolish hereditary positions in the House of Lords. That gains a lot of currency amongst the young turks of the ALP, locked out by the troika of Beazley, Crean and Ferguson, who all followed their fathers into politics. They actually like the idea of abolishing hereditary peers.

In the Australian's higher education supplement of 14 May this year there appeared an article entitled `The gospel according to Latham'. In readily assuming the mantle of Labor's new higher education prophet, the member for Werriwa is reported as saying:
You listen to Blair's speech—it's education, education, education.

As the member for Werriwa has traipsed around the nation's university campuses over the last two months, the title of the speech he has been repeatedly delivering on education philosophy is `Freedom to achieve: New Labor thinking for post‐secondary education'. In his speech, Latham argues that under a Labor government there would be universal access to post‐secondary qualifications—the old Whitlam idea that you actually encourage and support higher education. Rather than targeting it to those who need it, you actually open it up.

As I have said before, the experiment of free education in terms of changing the socioeconomic mix of university students never achieved its goal. University campuses remained the preserve largely of the middle socioeconomic groups. That is why when we came to government the amount of Commonwealth government spending on the top five per cent of income families was 38 per cent.

According to that article, the member for Werriwa's plan for education fits into a broader rethink of social democratic goals which reject the concept of higher learning and begin to thaw on the frozen Dawkins, left‐of‐centre thinking. The member for Werriwa has stated that he reflects the paradox of New Labor—he is a right‐leaning economist with Labor roots. He wishes to draw on the revolutionary spirit of the Dawkins era in changing tack. He has said that the education policies of the next federal Labor government will need to be quite different from those pursued in the 1980s.

For Daleks like the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and for the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), it is actually sad to report that around the world most social democratic parties or parties of the centre left are actually looking to the future, not the past. We had Bill Clinton's bridge to the 21st century. We heard every day during the American election how he wanted to build a bridge to the 21st century. With Tony Blair we had New Labour, new Britain. What do we have in Australia? We have the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Hotham in a way hopping into a DeLorean and travelling back to 1955. They have gone back in the time tunnel to the values and policies of the 1950s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about your own government?

—Why don't I talk about members of the Labor Party? The member for Melbourne has described them as walking arm in arm down memory lane with the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). That has come from your own side. That has come from the ALP. They have described these old‐fashioned policies as walking arm in arm down memory lane with the member for Oxley.

BREAK.PARA: According to the member for Melbourne, we must move beyond our 1980s love affair with market forces. However, we must avoid—I think the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) will find this interesting—becoming economically irrational, lapsing into mindless populism, recycling the policies of 1950s and defining ourselves by what we do not like. If we adopt such a stance, we will be virtually indistinguishable from Pauline Hanson on economic issues. This is the great ALP—the ALP of Hawke and Keating. You now have a member of the opposition front bench saying, `If you follow this path down to the 1950s, you will become on economics the—

TALK.START.PARA: —What path?

—The path is the one down memory lane with Pauline Hanson. Going back to the comments of the member for Melbourne, we should not delude ourselves that there is no link between the virulent racism of the member for Oxley and economic nostalgia. The two are very closely related and difficult to separate.

BREAK.PARA: In warning of the pitfalls of retreating down the time tunnel, the member for Melbourne is not only knocking out the deadwood of the old Keating ministry but also confirming the arguments the Governor of the Reserve Bank made in an address to the Sydney Institute back in February of this year entitled `The economics of nostalgia'. In that speech Ian Macfarlane stated:

There can be no quibble with the proposition that macroeconomic performance in the immediate post‐war period was far superior to any period before or after. This has led a lot of people to use it as a basis for proposing economic policies for today. They look back at how things were done in the 50s and 60s and say, `If only we did it the same way today, our macroeconomic performance would be as good as it was then.' This approach has some merit but, if we are to use it, it is very important that we get our facts straight about what the policies actually were in the 50s and 60s.

According to the Governor, the success of the golden age in achieving sustainable growth with low inflation is attributable to a background of macro-economic policies that did not try to be too ambitious in the short run. The Governor is keen to remind those such as the member for Hotham, who would have this nation cowering behind economic nationalism policies more befitting the One Nation Party, that during the period 1945 to 1965 Australia's macro-economic performance was conducted in an environment of unprecedented political cohesion among Western countries.

Such cohesion witnessed a remarkable revival of liberalism in international transactions and a greater emphasis on the need for economic growth than existed in previous decades. Unlike the US Democrats or the British Labour Party—sister parties, if you like, of the Australian Labor Party—the Australian Labor Party is not even looking at the next century in four years time. What it is doing is retreating back to the isolation and comfort of the 1950s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Boothby (Dr Southcott), in this appropriation debate is living testament to just how ashamed the backbenchers of the coalition are of the second Howard budget. SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the honourable member for Boothby being absolutely ashamed of this budget, because we are too. We are even more ashamed of what you have done to the Australian people in this particular budget, as you did in the first budget. The second budget delivered by the Howard government is a very sad reflection of the failed leadership of the Prime Minister, John Howard. The budget lacks vision, it lacks direction and, above all, it fails to address the fundamental problems facing citizens in the electorate of Corio today, namely, the problem of unemployment.

Only 14 months out from a substantial election victory, the Howard government has already frittered away the golden opportunity to consolidate the social and economic gains given to it by Labor. The rot has already set in, and it is rot right from the top down. In the core policy area of industry policy, which determines the living standards and employment opportunities of all Australians, young and old, his indecisiveness and procrastination have earned him the condemnation of one business leader after another.

More recently, his failure to respond decisively and compassionately to the stolen children report has propelled the nation into a position of paralysis on the issue of reconciliation with our Aboriginal brothers and sisters; a position where the nation is finding it extremely difficult to progress and to leave the past behind us.

However, it is in the great manufacturing regions of this nation that the deep sense of betrayal at the continued assault on their communities by the Prime Minister and this coalition government is felt the most. Job losses and job insecurity have increased substantially under John Howard's government. Regional business lacks the confidence to invest heavily in the face of the policy uncertainty surrounding Geelong's major car and textile clothing and footwear industries.

The social fabric of my electorate, the social fabric of that multicultural community which encompasses the Geelong region, has been put under very real pressure by the inaction of the Prime Minister in dealing with the damaging views of the member for Oxley. The process of betrayal of the regions of Australia, like the one that I represent in this parliament tonight, has continued in the second Howard budget brought down in March by the Treasurer (Mr Costello).

The first Howard budget brought down in 1996 was a fiscal statement that was bound to fail with the electors who had put their trust in the Prime Minister and the coalition, because it was based on a naked electoral lie behind which the coalition sought to disguise the implementation of its discredited Fightback agenda in 1993. That electoral lie was the government's portrayal of the Commonwealth government budget deficit as a catastrophe.

The Prime Minister left Labor in 1983 a current dollar equivalent deficit of $25 million, yet he and the coalition attempted to portray a $10 billion deficit as the end of the Australian way of life as we know it. He sought to deceitfully equate the budget deficit with the nation's debt, which, as the Prime Minister knows, belongs largely to the private and not the public sector. The Prime Minister sought to build around the budget deficit an air of fake economic and political crisis.

But they made one fatal political mistake. It is the most fatal political mistake that any political party or group of politicians can make. They began to believe their own propaganda. The situation was made all the worse because the propaganda they were peddling was false. That was the tragedy for Australia. The first Howard budget was based on propaganda and an electoral lie. The consequences of that situation were somewhat predictable. The government became incapable of recognising programs put in place by the previous Labor government that were actually working and meeting their objectives. They stupidly set about dismantling projects that were actually working.

The second predictable consequence of their action was to talk the Australian economy down, as they set lower targets for growth and lower targets for job creation. As economic confidence dissipated, especially in regional areas like that of Geelong, social confidence was battered with the emasculation of social programs that were meeting urgent needs in the community.

BREAK.PARA: The biggest disappointment of the first coalition budget was its low economic growth target and its expectation of low jobs growth, especially since the previous Labor government had left the coalition with an economy that had grown over the previous four years by over four per cent.

But it was not just this fact that set back the growth of key regional areas such as Geelong over the term of this government to date. It was the emasculation of the regional development program, the labour market programs and the business support programs which had delivered much to the people of Geelong in recent years that fuelled the lack of confidence that we are now experiencing in the region. It was the assault of the government on the students and staff of Deakin University that diminished that great tertiary university and the assault on child‐care funding which has left working families in Geelong with higher costs for their child care.

Regrettably, that assault on the great regional areas of this nation and the people who live in my electorate has continued in this second coalition budget brought down by the Treasurer recently—a budget forgotten by the media within three days of delivery and a budget that the member for Boothby and other members are so ashamed of that he comes into this House and delivers five minutes of his appropriation speech on the positive aspects of his own coalition government's budget and he dissertates for 15 minutes on the policies of a new Labor government that will be elected at the next election. It is a budget submerged by controversy surrounding the Prime Minister's lack of leadership on Wik, on cross-media ownership and on immigration issues.

On the issue of jobs, unemployment and economic growth, this budgets offers nothing for Geelong. It is a tragedy which is only now beginning to unfold. What an admission of failure when we read today in the newspapers of the declining rates of growth that are being predicted for the Australian economy in coming months. If the coalition government had delivered that target in their first and second budgets, we would be well on the way to getting rid of the government deficit without the corresponding cuts to economic programs that have been the hallmark of these two budgets to date.

When Labor left office the unemployment rate was 8.5 per cent, and we had a plan in place to reduce that and we had set a target for the reduction in unemployment. Contrary to the promises that were made by the Prime Minister in his pre-election policy statements to address this problem, the unemployment rate has gone up to 8.7 per cent and unemployment in the great regions of Australia has increased accordingly as well.

The raw figures tell a sorry tale of despair as the Prime Minister has literally caved in on addressing Australia's No. 1 problem. The number of unemployed has increased by 31,500. The number of long-term unemployed has increased by 30,100 and the youth unemployment rate, sadly, has increased under the two coalition budgets that have been delivered by this government.

The unemployment rate in the Geelong region stands in excess of 12 per cent and shows no sign of abating, especially in the face of local job losses in the public sector that are a direct casualty of the policies of this government to date and, more recently, 450 jobs that the government abolished at ASTAAS at the stroke of a pen.

If we are going to look briefly at the average rate of employment growth in Labor's last term in office—a growth rate of 2.9 per cent—the coalition can only average a rate of employment growth of one per cent to March 1997. The upshot of the government's caving in on the unemployment crisis in regional areas and failing to engineer higher growth rates has been a dramatic drop in consumer and business confidence in Geelong and across the nation.

The Treasurer comes into this parliament day after day touting the benefits of lower inflation rates for the Australian economy. None of us on either side of the House would begrudge the Australian economy a low interest rate regime. But as any high school economist would know—we know that the Treasurer is barely at the level of year 12 high school economics—when you break the back of the underlying inflation rate in any economy interest rates will flow down. If the interest rates overseas are in a state of decline, they will decline in Australia. If you depress the Australian economy by failing to address the fundamental problem of unemployment and you engineer a lower growth regime and lower total demand in the economy, you will depress the pressure on interest rates as well. The Treasurer claims credit for a reduction in interest rates that have been caused and are a direct result of the failure of the economic policies of this government.

That lack of confidence in my region is further exacerbated by the failure of the government on the industry policy front to send the correct signals to Australian car manufacturers in this country as it considers the final report of the Industry Commission on the car industry. I was bitterly disappointed in the response of the Prime Minister on this issue today on the floor of this House when he failed to give any succour to the community of Geelong and the community delegation that is going to visit Geelong tomorrow to argue the case for holding the tariff levels at 15 per cent at the year 2000. I implore the Prime Minister tonight on the floor of this House to meet with that delegation and to hear the real concerns of people in regional areas who fear for their jobs and who fear for the livelihood of their families if the government were to get its policy settings on this particular industry wrong.
I was further disappointed in the government today when it gagged the shadow minister for industry and regional develop ment, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), and me when we attempted to bring—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to read from the report Bringing them home , which was prepared by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission—a body which was attacked in financial terms in the last budget with a 40 per cent cut. I ask members to remember the fact that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has suffered that cut as we reflect upon the stories recorded in their report. One story says:

SPEECH.PARA: When I first met my mother—when I was 14—she wasn't what they said she was. They made her sound like she was stupid, you know, they made her sound so bad. And when I saw her she was so beautiful. Mum said, `My baby's been crying' and she walked into the room and she stood there and I walked into my—I walked into my mother and we hugged and this hot, hot rush just from the tip of my toes up to my head filled every part of my body—so hot. That was my first feeling of love and it only could come from my mum. I was so happy and that was the last time I got to see her. When my mum passed away I went to her funeral, which is stupid because I'm allowed to go see her at her funeral but I couldn't have that when she requested me. They wouldn't let me have her.
The next statement, by the same witness, goes to the issue of an apology and restitution:

The Government has to explain why it happened. What was the intention? I have to know why I was taken. I have to know why I was given the life I was given and why I'm scarred today. Why was my Mum meant to suffer? Why was I made to suffer with no Aboriginality and no identity, no culture? Why did they think that the life they gave me was better than the one my Mum would give me?
And an apology is important because I've never been apologised to. My mother's never been apologised to, not once, and I would like to be apologised to.

Thirdly, I've been a victim and I've suffered and I'll suffer until the day I die for what I've never had and what I can never have. I just have to get on with my life but compensation would help. It doesn't take the pain away. It doesn't take the suffering away. It doesn't take the memories away. It doesn't bring my mother back. But it has to be recognised.

And I shouldn't forget counselling. I've had to counsel myself all my life from a very young age. And in the homes I never showed by tears . . . I've been told that I need to talk about my childhood. I need to be counselled for me to get back on with my life.

The stories told within this report Bringing them home are ones that need to be thought about and read throughout the land in recognition of our history as a whole—both the good parts and the not so good parts. Accordingly, I believe that copies should be made available to the community so they are able to go through this dialogue as part of this process of recognising what our past entails.

It is unfortunate that copies are not available for the community at large. I think they have run out. There was only a fairly small print run. I believe that copies should be made available to schools, libraries and community groups at a nominal charge to aid this process of healing, which is so important for our future and for social cohesion to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is distressing indeed to listen to the words of the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel), and it is hard not to be deeply and sadly moved. In the great universe of things that hold us all, my concerns that I must bring to the notice of this chamber really do pale into insignificance, but the record must be put straight.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the adjournment debate speech of Senator Forshaw on 15 May 1997, in which he defamed my good name and character, and the Daily Telegraph of Saturday, 17 May 1997, which included a by-line which read `Lib MP deceived her electorate' and which printed selected extracts from two letters which were sent from my office. Senator Forshaw and the Daily Telegraph erroneously stated that I deceived my electorate in a letter I sent to constituents regarding a meeting at Engadine in my electorate on 30 April 1997. This meeting was organised by the state Labor member for Bulli, Mr Ian McManus, as a protest against the Holsworthy airport option.

The first I knew of the details of any such meeting was when I read an article in the St George and Sutherland Shire Leader of 22 April 1997. In an article entitled `People before politics', the state Labor member for Bulli stated that I and he would be together on the podium at this meeting, yet at that time I had received no previous communication whatsoever from the state member for Bulli asking me to join him and speak at that meeting. I was extremely surprised when I read the article, which said I was to be there.

The letter I wrote to my constituents was true and correct. The letter I wrote to the state Labor member for Bulli on 24 April 1997 was the incorrect letter, and this is a fact about which the member for Bulli is fully aware. And, if Senator Forshaw and the Daily Telegraph had asked him whether he had actually sent me an invitation to join him and speak at that meeting, he would have had to say no because he knows he never sent me such an invitation.

At about 2.20 on the afternoon of 22 April 1997, the same day the Leader article appeared, my office received a faxed copy of a `Dear resident' letter about the coming meeting. Subsequent scrutiny of this faxed copy gives no indication as to whether or not it came from the office of the member for Bulli. This faxed copy of a form letter to residents could in no way be construed to be an invitation to speak at the meeting, as held out by the Daily Telegraph, and it was certainly not received by my office a week before I read about the meeting in the local newspaper, again as stated by the Daily Telegraph.

Mr Speaker, the dates and times on the face of the document will clearly verify this fact. I made two errors in this matter. The first and the most serious was to trust the state Labor member for Bulli, Mr Ian McManus, when he said he wanted to put people before politics and to fight together on the Holsworthy airport issue, which is vitally important to our mutual constituents. The second was for me to describe the faxed `Dear resident' flier as a kind invitation from him in a misguided spirit of cooperation and good faith.

BREAK.PARA: Through this incident, I have discovered that the state Labor member for Bulli is bent on scoring some kind of cheap political advantage and I regret to say he has acted without principle and without conscience. He has touted these two letters around to the media. He has spoken out against me in the state parliament in an act which is nothing less than bearing false witness against me.

The state member for Bulli knows that he did not send me an invitation, yet he has sufficient unmitigated deceit to claim I deliberately deceived my electorate when he is the grossest deceiver. I say this because the state member for Bulli is fully aware of the good faith in which I wrote those words to him. He knows that I believe that the vexed issue of Holsworthy airport is becoming the defining moment in the psyche of our neighbourhood communities and that it is bigger than him and it is bigger than me.

He knows that I believe for him to be fighting me when we as elected representatives should be fighting on behalf of our constituents is nothing less than an insult to our constituents who have their backs against their front doors fighting for their very homes. He knows that, in the spirit of putting people before politics, I wrote to thank him for the kind invitation he never sent; yet he took my kind words, my good faith and my desire to establish a working relation with him and used them all against me. It is obvious he would prefer to keep the airport if he could get rid of Danna Vale. I put the state member for Bulli on notice that, at another place at some unpredetermined time and in some unpredetermined space in the highest court of all, I will charge him with bearing false witness against me.

Is it any wonder that private citizens feel that politicians cannot be trusted? I have learnt at my personal cost that the state member for Bulli is certainly one that cannot be trusted upon his word. He is a disgrace to himself, a disgrace to his family and a disgrace to his party. I say that because there are members of that party whom I know to be honourable and decent human beings and who are working to make a valuable contribution to our country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The following is one of the many telling excerpts from chapter 10 of the report Bringing them home of the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Mr Ronald Wilson, on the matter of children's experiences—a matter that has touched the hearts of many of us in this place in recent days in the poignancy of that particular report:

SPEECH.PARA: We were told our mother was an alcoholic and that she was a prostitute and she didn't care about us. They [foster family] used to warn us that when we got older we'd have to watch it because we'd turn into sluts and alcoholics, so we had to be very careful. If you were white you didn't have that dirtiness in you . . . It was in our breed, in us to be like that.
Let me briefly read some other equally telling and disturbing excerpts from chapter 10, which is on children's experiences:

I grew up sadly not knowing one Aboriginal person and the view that was given to me was one of fear towards [my] people. I was told not to have anything to do with them as they were dirty, lived in shabby conditions and, of course, drank to excess. Not once was I told that I was of Aboriginal descent. I was told that with my features I was from some Island and they [foster family] knew nothing of my family or the circumstances.

That was from a submission from a South Australian woman who was removed to a children's home at 18 months of age in the 1960s and was subsequently fostered by the caretakers. Another excerpt, this time from a child who was removed from her parents in 1967 in Victoria, states:
I got told my Aboriginality when I got whipped and they'd say, `You Abo, you nigger'. That was the only time I got told my Aboriginality.

Another equally poignant excerpt, this time from a man in the Northern Territory who was removed to the Kahlin compound at three years of age in the 1930s and subsequently placed at a foster home called the Bungalow, states:

There was no food, nothing. We was all huddled up in a room . . . like a little puppy‐dog . . . on the floor . . . Sometimes at night time we'd cry with hunger, no food . . . We had to scrounge in the town dump, eating old bread, smashing tomato sauce bottles, licking them. Half of the time the food we got was from the rubbish dump.

What I want to say, and I am sure what the overwhelming majority of the members of this House want to say—perhaps with the notable exception of the member for Swan (Mr Randall), who submitted by way of interjection the other day that the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Brand, Mr Beazley, was a sook because he demonstrated some emotion when speaking on this same report—is that we had no idea; we really are genuinely sorry. Above all else the Aboriginal people, in my view, just want us to know and to at least feign some understanding of their pathetically sad story.

If the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) were just to have for one moment the wherewithal or the intestinal fortitude to say on behalf of the whole country, `Hey, we think we've got some idea of what you went through and we really wish it hadn't happened,' I am sure that not only would this House be uplifted but the whole nation and the whole standard of politics as is perceived in this country would indeed experience a similar uplift. What is required, in my view, is a simple resolution in parliament to acknowledge that these events occurred, that they are part of our history and that they were unacceptable. As I say, this would have an incalculably positive impact upon what I believe to be a magnificent race of people.

The second thing that needs to be done is to make some restitution, whether it is financial, by way counselling or both. If it takes the Prime Minister's own legal advisers and officers to word an apology to get him to do it, I think, Mr Howard, for the sake of our nation, you ought to reconsider the government's decision of today and, in the words of that sports shoe ad, just do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to pay tribute to two very special people in the electorate of Riverina. Until a few weeks ago, when I moved house, Luigi and Teresa Suine lived across the road from me. On 14 May this year Lui and Teresa celebrated 65 years of marriage. I am sure all members of the House will join me in congratulating this marvellous couple who presently have five children, 18 grandchildren and 20 great grandchildren.

SPEECH.PARA: The story of Lui and Teresa is typical of many migrants who have come to Australia over the years and made it the great nation that it is. The Suine's contribution to the early settlement of Griffith within the Murrumbidgee irrigation area has been significant. Both Lui and Teresa were born in Cavaso, not far from the famous city of Venice, and they knew each other as youngsters in Italy. However, when Lui was aged 17, he travelled to Australia to seek a new life with his father, Peter. This was in 1927.

Recently Lui and Teresa purchased a silver medal from the Australian Mint which commemorated the opening of the provisional Parliament House. Lui told me he did so because he has been in Australia as long as that building has.

On arriving in Griffith he stayed with friends in one of a row of shanties known as barraccas. Although he could not foresee the future, his future wife's father lived next to him and Lui immediately looked for work. He states with pride that there were only three months of the 70 years he has been in Australia that he could not find a job and at that time he survived by shooting ducks and rabbits and catching fish.

As with many migrants, Lui endured many trials during his early years in Australia and two years before his marriage to Teresa he requested of Teresa's father that he might write to her. This he did and after months of correspondence and an engagement, Teresa arrived in Australia. She arrived by ship in Sydney and was put on the train by the brother of Lui's best man. Eighteen hours later Lui and Teresa were married at the Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Griffith with about 15 family members in attendance.

For their honeymoon Lui and Teresa walked from the church to Hanwood, then back to Murrumbidgee Avenue to visit Teresa's aunty, before walking to another farm where they had dinner with Teresa's father. They arrived back at their new home, which was a hut in Hanwood, at about four the next morning, having walked 20 miles on their wedding day.

The hut was made of logs with hessian lining. It was rather up market because it had a cement floor, while many others at the time had earthen floors. Gradually over the years the Suine's made their way in life through plain hard work and endeavour. They nurtured their family as Lui worked as a builder and farmer. Like many migrants, they wanted to give their children the opportunity for those things they never had.

Above all they gave their family an example of what it means to be good citizens and contributors to the community in which they lived. Every morning, Lui, who is now aged 87, still rises at 5 a.m. and walks on Scenic Hill with his little dog Jemma leading the way. His walk normally takes over an hour. I have never seen a day go by, except when either of them may not have been well, when Lui and Teresa are not working around their home. I have often sought Lui's advice when about to launch a project of my own, while Teresa is the gardening expert.

One of the things I admire most about the Suine family is their unity and the total respect the younger generations have for Lui and Teresa. There is hardly a moment of the weekend when some members of the family are not visiting them to bring them up to date with family occurrences—a birth here, a graduation there.

While I know all of the Suine family have celebrated this great occasion, I believe it is something that all of those who know Lui and Teresa can rejoice in. In fact, it is an anniversary the entire Griffith community, and indeed the nation, can be proud of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my Labor colleagues, I wish to read from the report Bringing them home of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families, colloquially known as `the stolen children report'. I do so because a lot of people in the community who do not have access to this report—it is out of print—will wonder what the fuss is about. Through some of the stories in this report, I want to bring home to people why there is a need for an apology from this parliament and for people to understand that, although we cannot erase these past wrongs, it is necessary for us to understand them as a precondition to going forward together. So to the story of William:

SPEECH.PARA: I can remember this utility with a coffin on top with flowers. As a little boy I saw it get driven away knowing there was something inside that coffin that belonged to me. I think I was about six years old at the time. This was the time of our separation, after our mother passed away. My family tried to get the Welfare to keep us here . . . trying to keep us together . . . My uncle wanted to keep me and he tried every way possible, apparently, to keep me. He was going to try and adopt me but they wouldn't allow it. They sent us away.
When St Francis [orphanage] closed up, they sent us out to different
places. My second eldest brother and I went to a Mrs R. And my only recollections of that lady was when we first went there. We were

greeted at the door. The welfare officer took us into this house and I can remember going into this room, and I'd never seen a room like it. It was big, and here me and my brother were going to share it. We put our bags down on the floor. We thought, `This is wonderful'. As soon as the welfare officer left, Mrs R took us outside that room and put us in a two bed caravan out the back.

I was sleeping in the caravan. I was only a little boy then. In the middle of the night somebody come to the caravan and raped me. That person raped me and raped me. I could feel the pain going through me. I cried and cried and they stuffed my head in the pillow. And I had nobody to talk to. It wasn't the only night it happened.

. . . it seemed like night after night. It seemed like nobody cared. I don't know how long it went on for, but night after night I'd see the bogey man. I never saw the person. I don't know who that person was.

Then we were all taken away again to a new home, to another place . . . And when I did have a friend I was shunted off somewhere else, to some other place. Wanting my mother, crying for my mother every night, day after day, knowing that she'd never come home or come and get me. Nobody told me my mother died. Nobody . . .

They shifted us again and that was into town again. And then they put us in with this bloke . . . They've got records of what he did to me. That man abused me. He made us do dirty things that we never wanted to do. Where was the counselling? Where was the help I needed? They knew about it. The guy went to court. He went to court but they did nothing for me, nothing . . . I remember the child psychologist saying, `He's an Aboriginal kid, he'll never improve.

I hit the streets of Adelaide. I drank myself stupid. I drank to take the pain, the misery out of my life. I couldn't stop. I smoked dope, got drugs. I tried everything. I did everything. I just couldn't cope with life. I lived under cardboard boxes. I used to eat out of rubbish bins. I'm so ashamed of what I've done.

I suffer today. I still suffer. I can't go to sleep at night. It's been on for years. . . . I wake up in the middle of the night, same time. My kids have asked me why I get up in the middle of the night and I can't explain it, I can't tell them—shamed. . . . I often wish I was dead. I often wish I was gone. But I can't because of my children. You can't explain this to your kids. Why did this happen? I had nobody.
I've had my secret all my life. I tried to tell but I couldn't. I can't even talk to my own brothers. I can't even talk to my sister. I fear people. I fear `em . . . It's rarely I've got friends.

I wish I was blacker. I wish I had language. I wish I had my culture. I wish my family would accept me as I am. We can't get together as a family. It's never worked. We fight, we carry on. I've always wanted a family.

That comes from a man removed from Alice Springs to Adelaide in the 1950s. It is because of that and so many other accounts in this report that we need, as a parliament, to pass a resolution to say to the people around Australia that we are sorry, and that is a precondition to moving forward.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Member for Hughes University of Southern Queensland

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, can I say to the honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) that, listening to her earlier contribution, she may be very small in stature but she is certainly big in heart and she is even bigger when it comes to the commitment to her electorate. She should always remember that, even in the political processes, honesty and ethics will eventually prevail. I commend her for what she had to say this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of months ago it was an honour and a pleasure for me to attend the inaugural address at the University of Southern Queensland given by the new Vice‐Chancellor, Professor Peter Swannell, and to listen to what he had to say. It was a brilliant speech, it was a very witty speech, it was intuitive and it was indicative of a chief executive of a tertiary institution who really wants to have total excellence when it comes to tertiary education in our nation. With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, I would like to read in part from that speech and put forward a few of the points that were made in that very lengthy speech to the university. The professor said:

This university—a regional, flexible and international university—is one of the undiscovered treasures of the Australian university system. It has remained largely undiscovered by those who live and move and have their beings in Canberra, or east of the Kenmore shopping centre—
which is in Brisbane—
for many reasons.
He went on to say:

Attainable goals, whatever they may be, must also be perceived to be just that—attainable. The land of attainable goals is then a natural outcome of what we are good at. It must also be described in a way which is interesting, inspirational, innovative, inviting, individualistic yet integrating, interpretable internationally, intentionally intriguing, in place, in touch and in tune with the imperatives which have been put in place for all institutions in the next decade. It is an `in' thing that I am talking about.

What we are good at is what we are. We are regional and we are also flexible and what we are is international. We are regional because we have the good fortune to be sited in one of the great productive key areas of Australia and the focus for the education of regional Australians for many, many years.

We are regional because we try very hard to be a university where indigenous Australians can increasingly contribute to its intellectual, social and cultural life. We recognise our special responsibility towards Aboriginal people as part of our commitment to the provision of educational opportunities to disadvantaged people, irrespective of race or social circumstance.

We are regional because we are part of the national scene, part of a diverse multicultural country and as much part of that region of the world called Australia as are Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Canberra and the rest. We are regional because we function in the Asia‐Pacific rim, the home of the most significant economic and social movers and shakers in the modern world.

We are regional because we do regionally significant things. We provide a focus for theatre, for music and the visual arts in the region. We provide educational programs which recognise the needs of regional and remote Australians, nurses in isolated communities, teachers in country schools, farmers who need to sort out their accounts, small business people, land managers who really care about sustainable development, engineers who are happy to build roads and provide power, sewerage and infrastructure for the outback. We do leading edge research in agricultural engineering and environmental biotechnology, in literacy and learning, in the literacy of Australia, in the languages and literature of Asia. The things we do and provide in business and management education for the armed forces, for industry executives and for people who are just pressing on with their careers demonstrate that regional excellence means national significance.
We are international because we probably know more about providing educational opportunities for students worldwide than almost every other university.
He went on to say:

At present we have some 3,000 international students studying in their own countries and a further 900 international enrolments on campus in Toowoomba. That places us in the top five international providers overall among Australian universities.
It is with pleasure that I read into the Hansard record those excerpts from an excellent speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Early this evening and last week a number of my colleagues read into the record stories from the report Bringing them home , which is the heart‐rending report on the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families. In the short time left to us, I would like to read a couple of extracts from that report. This is a report that every Australian should read, and you cannot but have your heart broken when you read it. In confidential evidence to the inquiry, a person from Victoria said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why me; why was I taken? It's like a hole in your heart that can never heal.
Another person said in evidence:

BREAK.PARA: Actually what you see in a lot of us is the shell, and I believe as an Aboriginal person that everything is inside of me to heal me if I know how to use it, if I know how to maintain it, if I know how to bring out and use it. But sometimes the past is just too hard to look at.
Another person who spoke to the inquiry said:

I've often thought, as old as I am, that it would have been lovely to have known a father and a mother, to know parents even for a little while, just to have had the opportunity of having a mother tuck you into bed and give you a good‐night kiss—but it was never to be.
That was said by a woman who was put in a foster home at two months of age. Another person said:

It never goes away. Just `cause we're not walking around on crutches or with bandages or plasters on our legs and arms, doesn't mean we're not hurting. Just `cause you can't see it doesn't mean . . . I suspect I'll carry all these sorts of wounds `til the day I die. I'd just like it to be not quite as intense, that's all.

These are stories that Australians need to know. These are stories about people who were hurt by people who often had the best of intentions. No-one is saying that many of the people who were involved in the stories of these Aboriginal people when they were young had bad intentions. But what all Australians need to understand is the hurt and the damage that was done to those people. We need to ask ourselves: what would we do if someone took away one of our children? What sort of anger and hurt would we have?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development upon notice, on 20 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to state what percentage of fatal motor vehicle accidents involve fires.
(2) What options, including fuel cut off valves and stronger petrol tank reinforcement, are available to reduce the incidence of serious fires in vehicle collisions.
(3) Will Australian design rules be amended to reduce the risk of fire in vehicle collisions: if so; what amendments are proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The most recent data available is for the year 1992. In that year about 2.6 % of fatal motor vehicle accidents involved fire; there were a total of 1,736 fatal motor vehicle accidents, 45 of which involved vehicles which caught fire. The total number of fatalities for that year was 1,974.

In some cases, death was due to the severity of the impact rather than the fire. There were some cases where no one was caught in the fire while in others, post‐mortems determined that an occupant died prior to being burnt. There were a total of 49 vehicles involved in these 45 fire affected fatal accidents.
A breakdown of the 49 vehicles which caught fire is given below:
Thus, there were 24 vehicles involved in fatal crashes in 1992 where the resulting fire was a cause of death to occupants. This is 1.4% of the 1992 total.

(2) In addition to fuel cut off valves and fuel tank reinforcement, options for reducing the incidence of serious fires in vehicle collisions include attention to design details such as routing of fuel lines to ensure separation from electrical cables and exhaust system components and design of connections to avoid leaks and separation during impact.

In Australia, fuel systems for some medium goods vehicles and all heavy goods vehicles are required to comply with an Australian Design Rule that addresses issues such as the location of fuel tanks, pressure testing and provision of safety vents. Also, fuel tanks that would be either fully or partially exposed to side impacts are required to pass an impact test involving a free fall drop through a prescribed height on to a hard unyielding surface.

Vehicles fuelled by Liquefied Petroleum Gas are required to comply with the Standards Association of Australia Automotive LP Gas Code which attends to design details such as gas pipe routing, gas leak containment, separation of gas pipes from electrical wiring and exhaust system components. The code also addresses gas pressure regulation as well as the provision of gas cut off valves. Also, the storage tank is required to comply with the Australian Standard for "LP Gas Fuel Vessels for Automotive Use".

The effectiveness of measures such as fuel cut off valves and fuel tank strength, mounting and location etc can be evaluated during Fuel Systems Integrity testing. Such requirements are currently applied in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the United States of America.

Fuel Systems Integrity standards involve testing the vehicle in simulated crashes involving frontal, rear and side impacts to examine fuel spillage rates during and following impact. Also, a vehicle inversion test may be specified, to examine spillage rates in rollovers, as well as a fuel tank pressurisation test and special tests for non‐metallic (plastic) fuel tanks. The available standards differ in the selection of the tests as well as the pass/fail criteria.

One other option is to adopt Interior Materials Flammability standards which seek to ensure that materials used in the passenger compartment do not have a high burning rate. However, there are practical limits to what can be achieved through flammability standards as they are mainly aimed at limiting the spread of fires caused by cigarette lighters and matches rather than fuel fed fires.

(3) The Australian Design Rules are currently undergoing a complete review. Regulatory Impact Statements will need to be prepared to examine the feasibility of any proposal. The adoption of appropriate fire risk reduction standards will be considered as part of this review.

A survey of Australian passenger car manufacturers reveals that a number of them currently equip their cars with fuel cut off valves and have adopted in‐house Fuel Systems Integrity standards comparable to those mentioned above. Therefore the introduction of regulations in this area may not result in significant changes in the vehicle fleet or a substantial reduction in the number of fatal motor vehicle accidents involving fires.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 March 1997:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Defence owns 20 golf courses. In addition, there are two private golf courses at Swan Island and Mt Macedon in Victoria on land leased from Defence.

(2) Defence golf clubs provide a sporting and social amenity for Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel and participation is encouraged with varying levels of financial support provided. Membership of private golf clubs is generally unattainable for ADF personnel over the period of a posting due to membership waiting times and the high cost of joining fees.

Defence golf clubs are also used by spouses and dependants, Defence civilians, ex‐ADF members and the public. The clubs are administered by duly appointed or elected officials and their accounts are subject to audit. Clubs derive income mainly from membership, competition and green fees. Most golf club buildings are owned by Defence although responsibility for maintenance of assets varies. Similarly, responsibility for course maintenance and ownership of equipment is shared or rests with either Defence or the clubs.

Golf course areas are used for other purposes such as training and recreational areas, buffer zones, fire breaks, green belts, wildlife refuges and designated emergency landing sites. Hence, areas utilised for golf courses would need to be maintained, although not to the extent that a golf course itself requires. Clubhouse facilities are also used by other Defence sporting and social clubs.

In many instances, Defence costs can only be approximated as utilities are not always separately metered and course maintenance can be part of a wider base contract. The total estimated cost of maintaining, running and administering the 20 golf courses is $3,390,000 of which Defence's contribution is estimated to be some $710,000. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

(2) Do legal sanctions exist for producers who supply unfit live sheep for export.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the antibiotics Gentomycin and Fluoroquinoline banned from the use in Australian poultry industry; if so, why.
(2) Is he able to say whether the antibiotics are used in poultry production in other countries; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Both gentomycin and enrofloxacin (a member of the fluoroquinolone group of antibiotics) have been restricted in Australia to use only in non‐food animal species on the advice of the National Health and Medical Research Council's Working Party on Antibiotics (previously known as The Expert Panel on Antibiotics). The Working Party on Antibiotics consider that the use of gentomycin and enrofloxacin in food animals could potentially lead to a transfer of resistance from animals to humans and could compromise the use of gentomycin and the fluroquinolone group of antibiotics in human medicine. The antibiotic enrofloxacin is not used in human medicine in Australia.

(2) Both gentomycin and enrofloxacin have been used in poultry production overseas. Both antibiotics are used therapeutically and not for growth promotion. Overseas countries consider that both gentomycin and enrofloxacin are valuable therapeutic antibiotics for use in poultry and other animal diseases, particularly food‐borne diseases such as Salmonella and Escherichia coli (E coli). Overseas Regulatory Authorities do not seem to have the same concerns over the potential transfer of resistance from animals to humans as does the Australian Working Party on Antibiotics. Moreover, Overseas Regulatory Authorities do not consider that the use of gentomycin and enrofloxacin in food animals contributes significantly to the resistance that is already development by the use of these antibiotics in human therapy.
